PROCTEXT.PARA: COMMONWEALTH OF AUSTRALIA
PARLIAMENTARY DEBATES
SENATE
Hansard
FIRST SESSION OF THE THIRTY-SIXTH PARLIAMENT
(SIXTH PERIOD)

PARA.TAB: The Senate, on 25 June 1992, adjourned to 18 August 1992, unless the President fixed an earlier day of meeting.
Pursuant to the Resolution of the Senate passed on 25 June 1992, the Senate met on Tuesday, 18 August, at 2 p.m.
The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for the opportunity to make a short statement. Next week marks six years since I was appointed as a senator for Victoria, and today I take my place in the sixth different seat in which I have sat in those six years. This movement reflects the constant change which is an integral feature of life in this Parliament. Indeed, change is for me an essential feature of politics. My political life has been dedicated to achieving change and reform and my new status today is very much a consequence of that process. I take my seat today as an independent senator for Victoria, having resigned from the Australian Democrats on 31 July during the parliamentary recess.

PARA.TAB: My decision to move on from the political party of which I was a founding member 15 years ago was not taken lightly or precipitately, nor was it a decision made for personal or emotional reasons. It was a result of long and careful consideration about how best I could continue to serve the people of Victoria in pursuing my strongly-held philosophical and political viewpoint. At a time when 20 per cent of Australians are saying that they reject the old party system, I, too, am saying that a new kind of politics is needed—the politics of consideration and cooperation which will be truly in touch with its community base and work to meet the real needs of the people it represents.

TALK.START.PARA: —It took you a long time to learn about the Democrats.

—In the six years that I have been in this place I have valued most highly the cooperative work that I have been able to do with colleagues on all sides of the chamber. I say to Senator Macdonald that, for example, I reflect on the magnificent work done by former Senator Peter Baume which played a large part in enabling the passage, unopposed, through the Parliament of my private member's Bill which banned the print advertising of tobacco products. On the other side, I look forward to a successful result on the question of discrimination against homosexuals in the armed forces as a result of important strategic cooperation between myself, Senator Margaret Reynolds and other Labor Party backbenchers.

PARA.TAB: I want to assure the Senate that I intend to continue to work cooperatively with all senators. I expect that to be especially the case with the Australian Democrats as I continue to subscribe to their basic philosophy and the consequent policies which I played a role in developing over the past 15 years. I am sure Senators Harradine and Chamarette will have wise counsel to offer me as experienced independent senators and I assure them that I welcome their advice.

For the information of the Senate, I also wish to advise that, following in the footsteps of former Senator Jo Vallentine and Senator Brian Harradine, I have applied for registration in accordance with the provisions of the Electoral Act as I will be contesting the next Senate election. This will provide me with certain entitlements in relation to the Senate ballot paper. As required by this Act, I have submitted a set of objectives which were developed with Victorian colleagues almost two years ago and which we will pursue into the future.

I thank all officers and staff of the Senate who have already ensured a smooth start to my time—which I hope will extend well into the future—as an independent senator representing Victoria in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion to take note of the statement of Senator Powell.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important that the Parliament debate the self-destruction of the Australian Democrats, but I ask that I be given permission to conduct that debate after Question Time.
—You have leave to continue your remarks. We will talk later about when.
—I seek leave to continue my remarks after Question Time.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion to take note of the statement.
—You have already got that.
—I do not know what the Democrats are saying no to. Anyway, we will assume that they have given leave for me to move to take note. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: More out of sorrow than anger we note the retirement of Senator Powell from the Australian Democrats, and, not surprisingly, the Australian Democrats would also have noted that they have plummeted in the polls to a record low. I think some 5 per cent of Australians now are offering support for the Democrats. That is not surprising. If they cannot keep their Party together in the way that they have demonstrated of recent years, it is not surprising that the people of Australia have so rapidly lost confidence in them.

PARA.TAB: I remind you, Mr President, that this is not the first of the Australian Democrats senators to resign and to condemn her colleagues in the form that she did the other day, although she did not do it today. I remind you of former Senator Siddons, who I think was a Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats, who some years ago resigned from the Party and said terrible things about his colleagues of that time and about the Party of which I think he was also an inaugural member.

I remember also from my own State the very highly respected Senator Vigor, who resigned and at that time said terrible things about Senator Powell or Senator Haines. The point is that this was the party that was not going to be a party in the form of others. As Senator Powell said to us today, she now feels the need to again reject the `old party system', to use her words, in which she now incorporates or includes the Australian Democrats.

The Australian Democrats have not kept the bastards honest, as the then Senator Chipp promised. They have not been prepared to come into this place and introduce new standards of behaviour or requirements that they said were deficient in the major parties—the Liberal Party, the National Party and the Australian Labor Party. They have failed to be able to maintain any form of common entity, as has been shown by the disillusionment that they demonstrate in each other, and really they have forfeited their right to any confidence of the Australian people.

The fact that they have now plummeted in the polls demonstrates that the Australian people have lost confidence in the Australian Democrats. There is no worthwhile function for them any longer in Australian politics. If they do not divide further and split off—we thought another one might go with Senator Powell but it does not seem to have happened just yet—it would be better if they threw in the towel, because they are not setting the standard they claim to have set and, therefore, are serving no useful function within the Australian democracy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to highlight the absolute disunity of the Australian Democrats. They are certainly not the party of Don Chipp. They have come a long way—all downhill, all backwards. I simply say to the Democrats: they ought to run their party with the unity and cohesion that the Liberal and National parties have shown in the last couple of years—a real example of how parties can work with unity and cohesion for the benefit of Australia. The Democrats would do well to learn from that, as with other things.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Given the Treasurer's assertion yesterday that it is not in the Government's interest to publish forecasts which have no credence or which are shown in time to have been based on other than sound professional judgment, why did the Government publish forecasts only a few months ago in the One Nation statement of 4.75 per cent growth in GDP for the year 1992-93 which it knew to be wrong and, to use the Treasurer's own criteria, which have been shown in time to have been based on other than sound professional judgment? If the figures in One Nation were so obviously rubbery, why should the public have any confidence in the forecasts that the Government will publish tonight?
—First of all, it is quite clear that the world economy has not progressed to the extent that we might have hoped and believed—
—Two months ago?

—No, in February 1992 when the forecasts in the One Nation statement were put down. But I notice that a number of Liberals, including the gruesome twosome, Dr Hewson and Mr Reith, have had a go at this issue in the past few days. In fact, Dr Hewson—the very brittle Dr Hewson—has had a go at every issue in the past few days. Anybody who has criticised any of his policies has been attacked by him in the past week or two. On the question of forecasts, the Opposition has had something to say.

PARA.TAB: I want to make some general observations about forecasting, and the Opposition is in this business too. There are all sorts of projections and forecasts in the Fightback package which are absolutely ludicrous—and everybody knows that to be so. However, the forecasts of recent years have underestimated the strength of the boom in the Australian economy. That was true for official forecasts in Australia, for other Australian forecasts and for forecasts of the international economy.

The technical fact is that the worldwide deregulation of the financial system meant that old yardsticks in relation to forecasting were no longer applicable. In these circumstances, the assets price boom and decline had a greater than anticipated effect. For example, the OECD has been quite out of kilter in its forecasts relating to world growth in the late 1980s and in terms of the world decline in the early 1990s; the forecasts here have mirrored that fact.

The Opposition immediately jumps to the conclusion that forecasting errors, which are a consequence of world deregulation of economies, are some sort of plot—and of course they are not a plot. The attack on the integrity of the Treasury is another in a sequence of attacks by the Leader of the Opposition on the institutions of government. He has made them on the Reserve Bank as well as the Treasury. He attacked the Reserve Bank and argued that every reduction in interest rate was politically motivated—a deliberate attack on the integrity of the Reserve Bank. In all these measures, the Leader of the Opposition has jumped to conclusions about forecasting, which is an imprecise art in terms of timing, if nothing else. Forecasting in respect of timing is not a precise art, and that is true of private sector forecasts as well as of government or public sector forecasts.

In conclusion—and I understand that this matter will be discussed further in the Budget Papers to be presented tonight—the Treasury forecasts have got the picture better than the average of private sector forecasts in this country in the past three or four years.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and it concerns the Australian Wallabies tour of South Africa. Does the suggestion that the African National Congress may withdraw its support for the Australian rugby tour following the incidents at the New Zealand-South Africa test match now put the Wallabies' tour in jeopardy? Has the Australian Government played any role in this dispute, and is the Minister in a position to make any observations regarding the manner in which the ANC has approached this issue?

—Honourable senators will be aware from media reports of the particular incidents which have precipitated the question mark that has now been placed over the Wallabies tour. In short, they involved a group of white South African rugby supporters interrupting in a manifestly crass way the observance of the proposed minute's silence called as a mark of respect for those who died in recent violence in South Africa; doing so by launching into a singing of the official South African national anthem; that then being followed immediately by the playing of that national anthem by the local rugby officials in direct, overt and deliberate breach of an agreement and understanding that had been reached between the South African Rugby Union and the officials of, respectively, the New Zealand and the Australian visiting teams. The object, of course, of that agreement is that potentially divisive political symbols not be intruded into a situation where it was generally accepted that the matches should go ahead in the spirit of reconciliation at a time of real tragedy and real suffering throughout the country.

PARA.TAB: It is highly regrettable that a group of white rugby supporters and officials should have reacted in that deliberately divisive way, thereby casting a shadow over the tour and, indeed, South African rugby's continuing participation in international competition. It is worth appreciating that the South African Rugby Football Union has directly and explicitly disassociated itself from these various actions and has expressed regret over the incidents. SARFU has confirmed that it will honour the understandings that were similarly reached, without any direct involvement, I should say, by governments in any way so far as the Wallabies' tour is concerned.

As to what the outcome will in fact be about the future of the tour, I can only say this: the ANC is still considering its position and will have further meetings this week with the peak South African sporting body, the National Olympic and Sports Congress. Mr Joe French of the Australian Rugby Football Union has expressed his optimism that the Australia-South Africa game will still be played. My own belief, on the basis of communications with our Ambassador in South Africa, who has been in close touch with all of the key participants in this exercise, is that that optimism is pretty well founded.

The ANC and black Africans, although legitimately very upset about what happened in Johannesburg, are approaching the issue I believe in a mature and responsible way. Certainly, the Australian Government very much hopes that the Wallabies tour can go ahead in a climate of goodwill and in that spirit of reconciliation among South Africans that has enabled, after all, the country to return to international sporting competition. But I repeat that it is entirely a matter for the discretion and the judgment of the footballers and their officials—the players and the ARFU—whether they decide to continue with the tour. It is not in any way a matter for the Australian Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer Senator Button to the Government's appalling track record in economic forecasting in recent years, both in respect of Budget outcomes and economic growth and related forecasts—for example, the combined error of a staggering $10.8 billion in the deficit in the last two Budgets. I ask the Minister: in the light of these huge errors and the fact that the forecasts in One Nation are now totally discredited and have been discarded by the Government after less than six months, how can the Government expect the people of Australia to believe any of the forecasts in its final Budget to be brought down tonight?
—I thought the Opposition would do a bit better than this sort of recycled Senator Hill question.
—You are a bit touchy.

—Not at all, Senator. I just regret the waste of Question Time. As Senator Short well knows, I have already answered this in part in talking to the question put to me by Senator Hill. There were anticipations in February this year about the growth rate of the Australian economy which have not been fulfilled. Those anticipations related to the world economic outlook, which has changed. It is in the light of that, substantially, that the forecasts have been revised downwards.

PARA.TAB: As to the size of the deficit, Senator Short has taken an aggregate figure over two years and asked how that could possibly happen. As I said in answer to Senator Hill, all projections in respect of the growth of the Australian economy in the late 1980s missed the very high level of growth which was taking place. Since then, projections about the rate of growth have also been inaccurate, by all forecasters; there has not been anybody in Australia who has got it exactly right. Part of the reason for that is that we have a substantially deregulated economy compared with the economy which we inherited.

The causes of the increase in the Budget deficit—do not nod your head too much, Senator Kemp, or it will fall off—are substantially the ones which we have identified in Question Time and debates in the Senate over time. Of course we have had a weaker economy and lower than previously expected inflation. We have also had lower interest rates and higher unemployment because of reduced activity in the Australian economy. Everybody knows that; there is nothing new about it, and Senator Short would know it as well as anybody else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the non-answer to both my question and Senator Hill's preceding question, I ask the Minister whether he is prepared to state clearly whether the key forecasts in the Budget to be presented this evening were made by the Treasury and the joint committee on economic forecasting or whether they have been cooked by the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and their officers, as has occurred in recent Budgets and in the recent One Nation statement.

—The forecasts have been prepared by the Treasury in respect of the Budget which will be presented tonight. When we are talking about the dismal art of forecasting, I make the point that, in respect of the 1991-92 Budget, apart from less growth than we anticipated in the economy, there were a number of other variables in economic indicators for which the forecasts were right or wrong. For example, there was a projection for much higher inflation than we in fact had. That was a consequence of the lower level of growth in the economy.

—Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of a workplace bargain struck between General Motors-Holden's and the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation? Can this long term closed agreement act as a model for other companies and unions wishing to take advantage of the Government's workplace bargaining framework?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it can. We are witnessing in Australia and in Australian workplaces a quiet revolution as we devolve the centralised wage fixing system more and more to the workplace setting. This latest agreement, which was ratified by the Industrial Relations Commission on Friday and which occurs under the reform amendments which we made in the Senate in the last session and which were proclaimed by the Governor-General on 22 July, is a good example of workplace bargaining under our model. It occurred without industrial disruption. It is an agreement that is closed for two years and economic adjustments are built into it. It is also an agreement that contains payment for productivity that will be generated during the life of the agreement.

PARA.TAB: It is an agreement that covers one of the largest companies in Australia—General Motors-Holden's, which has a huge work force—and thus must be counted as a significant model for other companies in the private sector that wish to go down the route of workplace change. We saw a number of workplace agreements go before the Commission before the Act was changed. There were 120-odd covering between 150,000 and 200,000 Australian employees. This is one of the most significant agreements to go before the Commission since the Act was changed, and I now expect that a flood of others will follow.

From the Government's point of view, we have opened negotiations with the public sector unions for workplace—or, as some call it, enterprise—bargaining within the Australian Public Service. At this stage it is too early to call as to date of conclusion or shape of the outcome, but the early signs are that considerable progress will be made. As a consequence of the sorts of changes we envisage, the Australian Public Service will be a model for other public services in the world and a benchmark as a best practice public service for others to follow.

In the case of the General Motors-Holden's workplace agreement, as I have said, it is closed for two years. It excludes General Motors-Holden's employees from national wage case increases. The productivity measures that are included in the agreement include just in time production methods, improvements in work organisation and improvements in maintenance procedures. The agreement provides wage increases related to both productivity and economic factors, and provides for an 8 per cent rise in wages over two years and an additional 2 per cent payable over the life of the agreement, which is linked directly to measurable improvements in customer satisfaction. The agreement is similar to other closed agreements covering Toyota and Ford and, as I have said, the proposed Australian Public Service agreement.

This is a quiet revolution that is taking place. It is a managed decentralising of the centralised system. It is occurring by consensus. It is proof that our industrial relations model works. It is to be contrasted to the big bang theories of the Opposition—theories which a number of Australia's leading businessmen have rejected in past weeks and theories which are fundamentally rejected by the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to an article which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on 15 August by Alan Ramsey entitled, `How to strike pay-dirt with the Budget'. According to the article, the Government is able to reduce the deficit by almost $1 billion by transferring the Budget costs of a single pay day from 1992-93 to 1993-94. Is it true that the Government has adopted this very creative accounting measure to reduce its deficit by almost $1 billion, and what other creative accounting measures has the Government adopted to try to make the Budget appear responsible?
—I have not read the article by Alan Ramsey. I sometimes read them. Sometimes they are enlightening and other times not.
—Did you get a briefing note on it?
—I did not get any briefing note on that issue. It seems to me from what has been said that Alan Ramsey probably had an off day.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The first pay day for 1993-94 occurs on 1 July. I ask the Minister whether it is true that a directive has gone out that the pay on that day be listed in the 1993-94 year and not in the 1992-93 year, as would normally occur?
—I ask that Senator Coulter wait until the Budget is published tonight and then he can have another go at that question later.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to a recent aviation agreement concluded between Australia and New Zealand. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the details of this agreement and what benefits it may have for the tourist industry in Australia?

—We were having a chat about this, but I feel I should share it with the Senate. I am pleased to advise the Senate that on 1 August—the beginning of this month—I signed a memorandum of understanding with the New Zealand Minister for Transport, Mr Storey, on future aviation arrangements between Australia and New Zealand. The objective of achieving more competitive trans-Tasman links between our two countries was outlined by the Prime Minister in his One Nation statement in February.

PARA.TAB: The memorandum of understanding does in fact represent a significant step by both countries for the common objective of a single aviation market and it is good news for the tourism trade and the travelling public. The memorandum provides for multiple designation of Australian and New Zealand airlines by November this year. This will provide the opportunity for another Australian carrier to provide some services across the Tasman from November, with an increased range of services next year and full access by November 1994.

Both countries are actively addressing important facilitation and terminal issues to assist in passenger and freight processing arrangements across the Tasman. The agreement also facilitates an expansion of beyond rights for both Australian and New Zealand carriers over the next two years. This will be of particular benefit in assisting marketing for the two countries as a joint destination, particularly in the major Asian and Pacific regions that are becoming so important to our tourism industry.

In relation to tourism, the agreement will clearly enhance Australia as a tourist destination from New Zealand, which forms a major market for Australia. New Zealand, I might add, remains the favourite overseas destination for Australians.

The successful conclusion of the memorandum with New Zealand marks another important step in the Government's aviation policy strategy announced earlier this year. I might add that the people who should be told about this are, on my count now, the 10 people who purport to represent the Federal Opposition on aviation issues. Mr Peacock was the last one to publicly buy into the debate when he said—and it is interesting to have a look at Mr Peacock's statement in relation to the successful completion of this agreement with New Zealand—that the Australian Government should simply give to Air New Zealand whatever it wanted. This is the so-called open skies policy being proposed in the Fightback! document by the Opposition with a total disregard for the very legitimate interests of the Australian carriers involved. This negotiation, which was a tough negotiation, which commenced in February this year and has only just been concluded, is proof positive of the absolutely un-Australian nature of such a proposition contained in the Fightback proposal.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. Tonight's Budget statement will be the seventeenth major economic statement by the Australian Labor Party since 1983. In that period, the incidence of unemployment and underemployment has risen to a figure of around two million people. Foreign debt has blown out from about $24 billion to about $150 billion. In the 1990 Budget Speech, Mr Keating said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the current account deficit will markedly improve and employment will pick up. . . delivered without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession.
Since then, official unemployment has risen from 592,000 to almost one million and we have had the worst recession in 60 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I am asking you to ask the question, not give a speech.
—In case the Minister did not hear, I said that unemployment has risen from 592,000 to one million.
—Order! Do not ignore the chair.
—My question is: why should the Australian public have any faith in this Government's seventeenth major economic statement when all of the others have failed dismally?

—The various economic statements made by this Government have not failed dismally. Let me begin by making the point to Senator Macdonald that this economy has grown significantly over the period of this Government.
—Two million unemployed.

—I am saying that the economy has grown significantly over the period of this Government. We created one and a half million new jobs. The rate of manufacturing growth between 1983 and 1991 was 2.5 per cent a year compared with the best a coalition government could ever do of one per cent—and people come in here today asking questions about forecasting, alleging bad motivation by the Government in terms of forecasting over the years and particularly trying to pre-empt the forecasts of the Budget which will be produced tonight.

PARA.TAB: I remind Senator Macdonald that every interest rate cut that this Government has made in the past 12 months has been opposed by his Leader. The recession which we now have, and out of which this country is now coming, would be twice as bad as it is if any government or any adviser had taken note of Dr Hewson's view in the past 12 months.

I will give Senator Macdonald a couple of figures. When we came into office, the unemployment figure for that year—July 1982 to June 1983—was 9 per cent; it was, in fact, higher. In 1991-92, it was 10.4 per cent—higher. The level of CPI inflation in 1991-92 was 1.9 per cent. When those opposite left office, the figure was 11.5 per cent. When those opposite left office, the level of employment growth was minus 1.7 per cent. Even last year it was only minus 1.6 per cent. The current account balance, which Senator Macdonald referred to, was minus 3.8 per cent of GDP in 1982-83; it is minus 3.1 per cent in 1991-92. Senator Macdonald can go through figure after figure and refer to the miserable performance of his Government during all the years it was in government.

Finally, I make the point that in 27 years in government, those opposite were never able to record a Budget surplus. The only four Budget surpluses in the history of this country since 1953 have been recorded by Labor governments. The dismal, miserable performance of those opposite is exactly the same as this dismal, miserable attack they make in the Senate. It is mediocre in the extreme. If the people of Australia are as concerned about issues as those opposite say they are, why are those opposite not at a 70 per cent level in the polls? Why are they lumbering along at a miserable level? If people take the dismal view of this country that those opposite take, why are those opposite not doing better in the polls? It is because they are incompetent and narrow-minded.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce while he is still in very good form. My question is about the Government's recent, very well-received agrifood statement. What action has the Government taken to implement the initiatives announced in the statement and when will the first meeting of the Agri-Food Council be held?

—The question of the so-called agrifood industry is an important one for Australia. The Government has been doing a lot of work on the food processing industry in conjunction with food processing companies, the National Farmers Federation and others. Resulting from that work, a so-called Agri-Food Council has been established which will help with liaison between the industry and governments in developing the export potential of the food processing industry in Australia, which is huge. Exports from the food processing industry are currently worth about $2 billion a year. There is no reason why they should not be much more significant in the years to come.
—Have you told Wally Curran that?

—The interjection, `Have you told Wally Curran that?' is interesting, coming from somebody who does not know anything about it. Last Thursday I attended a large seminar on the food processing industry in Melbourne. John Elliott—I understand he is an old friend of those opposite—chaired the seminar. The Leader of the Opposition in Victoria, Jeff Kennett, was there. Mr Prescott and other members of the Liberal Party were there, as well as people from the union movement. There was a very useful discussion about the development of food exports from Australia, which was pretty much on a bipartisan basis. I think it was very useful.

PARA.TAB: Senator Giles asked me when the first meeting of the Agri-Food Council meeting would be. I think it will be at the end of the month—31 August 1992. That will give the very distinguished membership of that Council an opportunity to progress some of these issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Will the Minister produce and table, by close of business tonight, a copy of the instructions concerning the purchase of private vehicles given by Mr Peter Davin of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to former ambassador Brian Burke on 31 August 1988?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to do that. In doing so, might I put this particular matter in context. It was the subject of a screaming headline in the Sunday Times in Perth, which I had no doubt at all would excite Senator Knowles. There was a suggestion that there had been a misleading of the Australian Parliament by me and by a senior officer of my Department in the Estimates Committee last September. There is no foundation for that assertion, but it is a serious one and it justifies a serious response. I give it that response.

PARA.TAB: The answer to the suggestion that I myself was involved in misleading the Senate Estimates Committee in any way is quite straightforward. All I said was:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . as the officer has already indicated, the evidence is that Mr Burke did not know what his obligations were.
In other words, I was referring to evidence given by the officer of my Department in question, Mr Forrester. I was not making any independent judgment about the accuracy of the matters in issue.

PARA.TAB: The question then, accordingly, turns on the nature of the evidence given to that Committee by the senior officer of my Department. I am able to say with complete confidence that there was no misleading of the Senate Committee; no cover up in any sense as alleged by the paper.

Mr Forrester had examined very carefully the question in issue; that is, whether Mr Burke was aware of the relevant content of the administrative circular relating to car purchases. Mr Forrester had formed the honest judgment that Mr Burke was not aware of the administrative circular. The reasons why he formed that judgment were actually conveyed and outlined to the newspaper on whose report Senator Knowles bases her question, in answer to questions received from that paper, but the newspaper chose not to give Mr Forrester's side of the story at all. I am happy to do so now.

At my request, Mr Forrester has prepared a very full account of why he reached the conclusions he did and why he replied as he did to the Senate Committee. I now table that report and seek leave to incorporate the text of it in Hansard. I made some extra copies of it in case those opposite wanted to take advantage of it at this stage.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

You asked me to report to you on the allegation in the Perth Sunday Times that I had misled the Senate Estimates Committee on 4 September 1991 when I said: "I satisfied myself, in particular through an officer I sent to the post at the time, that Mr Burke did not know about, and had not had distributed to him, that Administrative Circular. The advice to me, from the officer I sent to the post at the time was that Mr Burke was not aware, and I satisfied myself that that was the case".(B41)

ANSWER.PARA: 2.Earlier in the same session (B40) I said: "I am satisfied that he (Mr Burke) did not understand them (his obligations under Departmental rules) and that above all, when they were brought to his attention, he took steps to conform to them immediately".
3.For your information I attach ('A') the full text (with attachments) of Administrative Circular 180/87, to which I was referring in the Estimates Committee.

4.On 18 June 1991 Steven Brady, then an officer of the Australian Embassy in Dublin, telephoned me to say that he was concerned that Mr Burke was seeking to dispose of duty-free vehicles which seemed to exceed his entitlements as set out in the Department's Administrative Circular 180/87. I determined that an officer should be sent from Canberra to establish the facts, and chose for this purpose Mr Peter Davin who had been Senior Administrative Officer in the post from 1986 to 1989.

5.I discussed matters with Mr Davin on or about 20 June, before his departure for Ireland. He told me then that he recollected discussing with Mr Burke the terms of Administrative Circular 180/87 relevant to Mr Burke's wish to purchase a third vehicle duty-free. It is this recollection of his which I recorded in para 9 of my note of 20 June (attached at `B') to Mr Dauth, then your Principal Private Secretary: as will become apparent below, the conclusion I drew here about Mr Burke's knowledge of the Circular was overtaken by the outcome of Mr Davin's further discussion with Mr Burke on 25 June and also facts which came to light about administrative failures in the post.

6.On 20 June I spoke to Mr Burke for the first time by telephone about the issue. He expressed surprise at my description of the terms of the Administrative Circular which led me, as I recollect events, to then read out the relevant parts of it to him. He maintained that he thought the rule was that he could own three vehicles duty-free at any one time, and that there was no particular limitation on the total number of duty-free vehicles that could be purchased during the course of a posting. In that first discussion, he also acknowledged that he had to conform to departmental requirements and asked what could be done to regularise the situation.

7.On his arrival in Dublin, Mr Davin conducted a search of the relevant files, with which he was familiar, and came across the note in which Mr Burke sought his advice on the purchase of a third vehicle. In response to Mr Burke's request for advice on policy on the purchase of a third duty-free vehicle, Mr Davin on 31 August 1988 had attached the text of Administrative Circular 180/87, but apparently without its attachments which provide sample certifications (including a form of acknowledgement that the instructions relating to the purchase of cars have been conveyed, and a briefing upon them given). Mr Davin's handwritten annotations of 31 August 1988 on that note focused on two aspects. First, he wrote that approval for the purchase of a third car had to be sought from Canberra. Secondly, in response to a specific question in Mr Burke's memo, Mr Davin went on to outline the importance of ensuring vehicles are sufficiently used so that no impression is created of profiteering and purchase simply for resale. In submitting the Administrative Circular (less its attachments) to Mr Burke, Mr Davin highlighted one sentence of the text, namely the last sentence of paragraph 9, which concerns this matter of sufficient use and reads as follows:

PARA.TAB: "Thus a car which was held for a short part of posting or held in a garage and proposed for sale with less than a minimum reasonable distance on the speedometer in circumstances where resale at a large profit was possible, would be assumed not to be for personal use unless demonstrated to the contrary".

ANSWER.PARA: On 31 August 1988 Mr Burke responded to Mr Davin by annotating the latter's memo in the following terms:

I have asked Mr Dowling to arrange for a recommendation as to the vehicle I should purchase. Cd you please liaise with Mr Dowling to see what he has done and then place a firm order after discussing with me. BB 31/8

8.When Mr Davin in Dublin brought this exchange to my attention and the fact that Administrative Circular 180/87 (less its attachments) had been attached to the note, I told him to bring it to Mr Burke's attention and to seek his explanation as to how under these circumstances he could claim no detailed knowledge of the Circular's requirements. Mr Burke's comments are recorded by Mr Davin by hand on the same document on 25 June 1991. Mr Burke told Mr Davin "that he has no recollection of seeing the guidelines but assumes his attention was focused on the highlighted section not the Administrative Circular in its entirety". (The highlighted section—as stated above—is the last sentence of para 9, the answer to his specific concern about "limited mileage".)

9.Administrative Circular 180/87 and the procedures set out in it were designed to ensure that all officers of the Department are aware of their obligations with respect to access to duty-free purchases. Elaborate mechanisms were established by the Administrative Circular to ensure that officers certify that they have not only been given copies of, but have been briefed on, the contents of the Administrative Circular and their obligations. Records are to be kept of the details of the information provided to officers, when this information was provided and who provided it. Officers are also expected to record the details of their purchases and sale of duty-free vehicles. These procedures are designed to ensure both that officers are properly informed of their obligations and that there is a record that they have been so informed. I therefore asked Mr Davin to provide me with the details of Mr Burke's certifications, which would show that he had been properly informed of his obligations. Mr Davin advised me that, while as Senior Administrative Officer he had required all other officers in the post to complete these formal processes, he had not required Mr Burke to complete them. This was an oversight on his part.

10.I then asked what had been the practice in the post after Mr Davin's departure in September 1989. Mr Davin advised that the next Senior Administrative Officer had brought the Administrative Circular to the attention of no one and the procedures set out in it had not been observed.

11.A critical process established by the Department to ensure that all staff know of all their obligations in respect of purchase of duty-free goods had therefore never been carried out with Mr Burke according to the procedures established by the Department, even though a part of it had been drawn to his attention in August 1988 in so far as it concerned the purchase of a third duty-free vehicle. Against the background of this new knowledge, I had to assess Mr Burke's consistent advice to me and to Mr Davin that he did not know about our rules and that he thought that he could own three duty-free vehicles at any one time. On three occasions in June he maintained that he was unaware of our guidelines or our rules (except in so far as his attention may have been focused on the last sentence of para 9 of the Administrative Circular):
(i)in his first telephone conversation with me on 20 June 1991;

(ii)in his note of 24 June 1991 agreeing to pay taxes and duties on his two most recent duty-free purchases, where he reiterates that he was "unaware of this regulation when I purchased the two vehicles I acquired most recently"; and
(iii) in response to Mr Davin's questioning of him on 25 June about the exchange of 31 August 1988 (para 8 above).

12.If our records had shown that Mr Burke had been formally advised and counselled in accordance with the provisions of Administrative Circular 180/87, and if our records had shown that he and those briefing him had signed the necessary undertakings and certifications that such a briefing had taken place, I would have concluded without hesitation that Mr Burke had had distributed to him in accordance with established procedures the necessary material to ensure that he knew of our rules and had no basis for arguing that he did not know the rules. Given that these procedures had not been followed as they should have been, and given that the record shows that only two elements of our rules on this matter (those concerning purchase of a third vehicle) had been drawn to his attention in 1988, I concluded that, on the grounds of fairness and natural justice, I had no option but to accept Mr Burke's consistent advice in June 1991 that he was not aware of our rules.

13.This conclusion is not recorded on the file, which I acknowledge as an omission. My priority at the time was to ensure that Mr Burke conformed to Departmental rules in respect of the disposal of the two most recent duty-free purchases, which he did immediately our rules had been brought to his attention. When this had happened, the matter was, in my view, closed.

14.In the Senate Estimates Committee on 4 September 1991 I answered questions against the background of my knowledge that Mr Burke had never had distributed to him Administrative Circular 180/87 in accordance with our procedures, and of my conclusion—recorded in paragraph 12—that, on the grounds of fairness and natural justice, I had no option but to accept Mr Burke's consistent advice in June 1991 that he was not aware of our rules.

PARA.TAB: ATTACHMENT `A'

ANSWER.PARA: DEPARTMENT OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND TRADE
DISTRIBUTION ALL HEADS OF MISSIONS AND POSTS REGIONAL DIRECTORS OF STATES

This circular reminds all officers of the long standing requirement to adhere to the regulations enforcing diplomatic and consular privileges overseas, sets out some new requirements, and prescribes specific duties of missions in general and heads of missions in particular in enforcing them.

2.This circular should be brought to the attention of all Australia-based officers of the mission. In addition, each mission should update its own instructions and procedures in the light of this instruction and issue them to all Australia-based staff before 1 February 1988.

3.An officer posted overseas in any capacity is expected to display a high standard of integrity, honesty and discretion. Officers overseas must have regard for the possible public consequences of their activities both in an official and in a private capacity. They must be scrupulous in their regard for the laws of their country of posting and should be alert to the consequences for Australia and for the Department of any lapse in their conduct. Any abuse of diplomatic and consular privilege has the potential to damage our bilateral relations with the country in which the abuse occurs as well as harming the Department's reputation in Australia and Australia's standing internationally. Abuse of diplomatic privilege prior to the time it is discovered by Australian authorities also leaves those indulging in it open to compromise, especially by local authorities who are very likely to know of it. In addition, officers overseas should be fully aware that abuse of diplomatic and consular privileges will have disciplinary consequences.

4.None of this should be new to officers, being set out in Volume 1 Section 9 of the Departmental Instructions which was drawn to the attention of staff in Administrative Circular 61/85 and which officers would be well advised to consult.

5.The principle underlying diplomatic and consular privileges embodied in the Vienna Conventions on Diplomatic and Consular Relations is that one sovereign State should not tax the sovereign activities of another State, including that State's official representatives. Exemptions from local taxation laws are not granted for the personal benefit of individual officers—this is expressly stated in the preambles of both Vienna Conventions. Diplomatic and consular officials have a primary duty, both in customary international law and under the terms of the Vienna Conventions, to respect and abide by the local law even though they are immune from its jurisdiction.

6.The Vienna Conventions set out what are generally accepted as appropriate exemptions from duties and taxes, and those States which are not party to one or other of the Conventions generally accept the standards set by the Conventions. But each country sets down its own regulations governing the exercise of diplomatic privilege and in particular the re-sale in that country of goods purchased free of duty under diplomatic privilege. Some countries, where protection against imports is high or foreign exchange scarce, present opportunities for profit on resale of imported goods and thus may have specific rules prohibiting import of certain goods or their resale or restricting the circumstances where it can be done. Such regulations must be obeyed by officers and officers have a duty to be fully aware of what those regulations are. The areas where problems and temptations seem most likely to arise are:
Abuse of these and any other diplomatic and consular privileges makes officers liable for disciplinary action under the Public Service Act.

7.Use of the black currency market is prohibited. Where the official rate or rate at which officers transfer money to a country differs from the "real" or black market rate all Australia-based officers must obey the regulations and exchange all moneys at the prescribed rate. Allowances are calculated on the basis that officers use the official rate of exchange.

8.Due to the high tax on alcohol and cigarettes imposed by some countries, and their ready availability for sale, it is necessary to stress that such items must be purchased only for personal use and official representation.

9.Cars have on occasions been the subject of abuse of diplomatic privilege and it is reiterated that officers have a duty to ascertain and adhere to local laws regarding the purchase and resale of cars. It is expected that cars imported or purchased will be for personal and family use during the period of posting. Thus officers may purchase and import a car only in their own name. It is a breach of diplomatic privilege, and a disciplinary offence under the Public Service Act for an officer to import a car in the name of another officer. Purchase for the sole purpose of resale, even within local regulations, is an abuse of diplomatic privilege. Thus a car which was held for a short part of posting, or held in a garage and proposed for sale with less than a minimum reasonable distance on the speedometer in circumstances where resale at a large profit was possible, would be assumed not to be for personal use unless demonstrated to the contrary.

10.The purchase of more than two cars in a posting exercising diplomatic privilege is also an area for possible abuse and could have adverse implications for the Department. Therefore I have decided, and now advise all staff that heads of mission are not authorised to approve the purchase by any officer of more than two cars under diplomatic privilege in the course of a posting. This covers cars purchased under diplomatic privilege by an officer, his or her spouse or family member. Any proposal for the purchase of a third car under diplomatic privilege must be referred to the First Assistant Secretary, Corporate Management Division. In general such proposals will not be approved apart from exceptional circumstances of family need, e.g. where vehicles have been involved in accidents.

11.I would like all Posts to undertake a thorough and prompt review of procedures for the administration of the import, purchase and disposal of goods duty-free or tax-free under privilege and their conformity with current local regulations. As a first step, Posts should ensure that they have complete and up-to-date records of the host State's laws and regulations on exemptions from duty and tax including rules on the use and disposal of goods purchased duty-free or tax-free. Where necessary, these laws and regulations should be translated and clarification sought from the local Foreign Ministry as to the operation of particular rules.

12.Each Head of Mission or Post is to ensure that instructions setting out the regulations regarding import, purchase and disposal of goods duty-free and tax-free are made known to each Australia-based staff member and are given to each new member of staff. These instructions must be signed by the head of mission and issued before the end of this year.
13.These instructions will vary from post to post depending on local circumstances. It is important however that the procedures in force in the mission:

(a)ensure that any officer purchasing a vehicle duty-free has the conditions of resale brought to his or her attention and signs an undertaking that he/she understands the conditions (sample attached);

(b)ensure that there is only one point in the mission through which applications for duty-free purchase or registration of the vehicle are passed to the local authorities and that all staff understand this; any direct approach outside that mechanism would be regarded as a breach of lawful instructions subject to disciplinary proceedings;

(c)maintain a complete register of all vehicles purchased and disposed of under diplomatic privilege; this would record details of the vehicle as set out in the attached form, as well as the registration number and mileage on disposal; details of this register would not be sent to Canberra but would be checked by internal audit teams and would be available on request;
(d)include my instruction that no more than two cars may be purchased duty-free in the course of a posting without reference to me or my delegate.

13.At some posts, borrowing money may expose officers to pressures from financiers to bend the rules or to grant unacceptable favours. In many countries, there will be little scope for compromise, apart from the question of officers overcommitting themselves. However, in those countries where a risk of compromise is possible, the head of mission or post should ensure that the attention of officers is drawn to identified risks.

14.I am confident that with the co-operation of all officers overseas, effective and efficient procedures can be developed for every post which will ensure that each officer fully understands and implements regulations in a way which raises no problems for the conduct of our foreign policy overseas.

PARA.TAB: An issue has arisen in Dublin as to the number of vehicles Mr Burke has purchased under diplomatic privilege.

ANSWER.PARA: 2.Admin. Circular 180/87 set out specific rules about how many cars officers may purchase in a posting. A copy of the Circular is attached.

3.Paragraph 10 of the Admin. Circular states that Heads of Mission should not authorise the purchase by any officer of more than two cars under diplomatic privilege in the course of a posting. Paragraph 13(d) says that instructions in every post should make it clear that no more than 2 cars may be purchased in the course of a posting without reference to the Secretary or his Delegate.

4.On the evening of 18 June Steven Brady telephoned to say that he had some concerns about Mr Burke's car purchases under diplomatic privilege and their conformity with the requirements of this Admin. Circular. The Senior Admin. Officer had just sent a diplomatic note to the Irish Foreign Ministry requesting permission to sell three cars without payment of tax or duty. Mr Brady had examined the relevant files and found that Mr Burke had in fact in the course of his posting appeared to have purchased 6 cars duty free.

5.There is an explanation for the purchase of 4 of them. Mr Burke was given permission by the Department to purchase a third car duty free because the number of children of driving age in his family. This approval was given in accordance with the last two sentences of para. 10 of the Admin. Circular.

6.One of these three cars was written off in a crash and a replacement purchased. This would have been consistent with the last two sentences of para. 10 but the files in Dublin do not indicate that approval was sought from my predecessor. In any case, we believe he may have paid all taxes owing to Irish authorities on the vehicle that was written off.

7.A problem arises with the purchases of the fifth and sixth vehicles. The vehicles were purchased on the sale of vehicles 1 and 2 after he had owned them for two years. One of the new vehicles appears to have 18 kilometres on the odometer.

8.There may be special circumstances in the purchase of vehicles 5 and 6 of which we are unaware and on which Dublin's files are silent. The information we have so far, however, could indicate that Mr Burke has purchased two more vehicles than he should have.

9.The intent and purpose the Admin. Circular was known to and understood by Mr Burke because Peter Davin tells me that he discussed it with him. This discussion was the basis of the approach to Canberra to buy a third car. The purchase of the fifth and sixth vehicles came after Davin's departure.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not go into all the detail now, but the main points made by Mr Forrester in that report, in summary, are as follows: the administrative circular was, as a result of an administrative failing within the post, never properly distributed to Mr Burke in accordance with specified procedures. He was not briefed on it as he should have been, nor was he required to certify that he read it as he should have been.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, it is the case that a highlighted portion of the circular was brought to Mr Burke's attention on one occasion as an attachment to a memo which he noted on 31 August 1988. But that was in the context of a particular query about a particular purchase and Mr Burke has subsequently denied having any recollection of the terms of the document as a whole.

Thirdly, Mr Burke's denial of any recollection of the relevant content of the circular has been consistently maintained: in a telephone conversation with Mr Forrester on 20 June last year, in a note that he wrote on 24 June and in discussion with the investigating officer, Mr Davin, in Ireland on 25 June. Mr Forrester concludes in his report—I will conclude on this basis; I see no reason for second guessing my officer in this respect—that:

In the Senate Estimates Committee on 4 September 1991 I answered questions against the background of my knowledge that Mr Burke had never had distributed to him Administrative Circular 180/87 in accordance with our procedures, and of my conclusion . . . that, on the grounds of fairness and natural justice, I had no option but to accept Mr Burke's consistent advice in June 1991 that he was not aware of our rules.

ANSWER.PARA: The material that I have tabled—Mr Forrester's report—does contain the full text of the administrative circular with its attachments. I will also table—when I find it—in response to Senator Knowles's specific request, a copy of the administrative circular in the form in which it was actually shown to Mr Burke as an attachment to a memo. I will table the memo in question as well. There is a highlighting of one particular part of that document that does not show up in the Xerox, but Mr Forrester's report identifies the passage in question that was so highlighted.

PARA.TAB: I think that this material gives a full explanation of what, on the face of it, does require some explanation; I frankly acknowledge that. The explanation that I have given, with the documents thus tabled, is a very full one and I believe that it completely puts to rest any suggestion that there has been any misleading of the Senate, either deliberate or inadvertent, certainly by me and certainly also by my officer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Now that Senator Evans has blamed Mr Forrester yet again for the mistakes, I just ask the Minister—before having the opportunity to look at the documents that he has tabled and incorporated—where his responsibility as Minister begins on this issue.

—My responsibility is not to mislead the Senate. I did not do so on this case, nor did I mislead the Senate Estimates Committee, nor would I ever mislead the Senate or any of its agencies—nor have I ever done so.
—You're a disgrace!
—Order! I remind Senator Walters again that it has been ruled consistently by myself and my predecessors that it is not in order to refer to another senator as a disgrace.

—I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to claims in recent weeks that the United States is planning a confrontation with Iraq in an effort to boost President Bush's re-election chances. I ask the Minister: what negotiations has the Australian Government had in recent weeks with the United States and/or the United Nations on the Iraqi issue? What is the current state of Australia's military commitment in the Middle East? What would be Australia's involvement if Saddam Hussein continued to deny United Nations inspectors access to military installations?

—If I might be permitted to return now to the less significant areas of my portfolio responsibilities, might I say the following in response to Senator Jones. The international community, including the United States, has for the past two years consistently called on Iraq to comply with the UN Security Council resolutions or to face the consequences, and the Australian Government fully endorses that approach. Through our contacts at the UN and through consultations with senior officials in Washington and other capitals, we have kept ourselves closely informed about developments relating to Iraq.

PARA.TAB: We are greatly concerned that Iraq persists in flouting the authority of the UN resolutions by not cooperating with the UN's plans for disclosure and destruction of its weapons of mass destruction; by continuing to violate the human and political rights of the Kurds and the Shiah, contrary to resolution 688; by failing to renew the Memorandum of Understanding with the UN under which the humanitarian program in Iraq operates; by refusing to allow oil to be exported in accordance with Security Council resolutions 706 and 712; by refusing to participate in UN-sponsored talks on setting the Iraq-Kuwait border; and, indeed, by repeatedly asserting its claim to Kuwait in contravention of resolution 687.

The UN resolutions, particularly resolution 687, authorise such further steps as may be required to implement all the provisions of the resolution and to secure peace and security in the area. The United States Government has said on many occasions, and certainly not just since the presidential election campaign has heated up, that it does not rule out any option to force Iraq to comply with the will of the international community as expressed in those resolutions.

As to the second part of Senator Jones's question about the current state of Australia's commitment, if I can answer in this respect on behalf of Senator Robert Ray, whose responsibility it is, Australia has been a longstanding contributor to the multinational naval force carrying out sanctions duties in the Gulf and the Red Sea. HMAS Darwin completed its latest tour of duty in the Red Sea in July. There is presently a gap in our commitment due to operational reasons.

There is a small office in Bahrain which supports Australia's ship deployment in the Middle East and Australia's contribution to UNSCOM inspections in Iraq. We have contributed a number of military and civilian specialists to the work of UNSCOM, the UN body that is charged with locating and rendering harmless Iraq's weapons of mass destruction and missiles. At the moment there are five Australian Defence Force personnel serving with UNSCOM in varying capacities relating to the location and destruction of those weapons and missiles. Two of the personnel are scheduled to depart Iraq in the near future. In addition, there are several ADF personnel serving on exchange with US and UK forces and it is possible that some could be asked to deploy to the Middle East with their host units. Approval has already been given for three ADF exchange officers to be deployed to the Middle East. Australia also has 12 military observers attached to UNTSO on UN peacekeeping activities covering Israel, Syria and Lebanon.

As to the final part of the question—what Australia's role might be in any future enforcement exercise in the Middle East—it is simply not appropriate for me to speculate about the further steps that Australia might take were Saddam Hussein to continue to deny UN inspectors access to military installations. Certainly, it would obviously be preferable for all concerned if the Iraqi Government were to see sense now and comply with the resolutions, as it is obligated to do. Saddam Hussein would be very ill-advised to underestimate the will of the international community to enforce compliance in all these respects.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to the very public allegations of sexual harassment involving a senior diplomat within his Department and a fellow officer whilst stationed in Bangkok. Will the Minister inform the Senate what steps have been taken to ascertain the precise facts of the case? Is it true, as has been reported, that a process of conciliation is to be carried out prior to any investigation as to the facts? If so, why has the Minister not chosen a process to establish the facts of the matter as opposed to trying to conciliate, which could lead to pressure being put on the claimant to abandon the matter? Who is responsible for overseeing the matter and reporting to the Minister?

—A complaint alleging sexual harassment by a former departmental employee against Mr Richard Butler was lodged with a member of the Department's workplace harassment contact group on 24 February 1992 and subsequently with the Secretary on 8 May this year. The complainant was fully briefed on all the options available to her under Public Service regulations but asked that the matter be treated informally by the Department in the first instance. The Department is, accordingly, handling the complaint informally with the cooperation of the parties and in accordance with Public Service Commission guidelines.

PARA.TAB: It remains open to the complainant to lodge a formal grievance under the Public Service regulations or to the Merit Protection and Review Agency or to make a complaint to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission under the Sex Discrimination Act. In order to protect the privacy of the parties, it would be quite inappropriate for me to comment any further until this matter is resolved or taken further in one or other of these directions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I asked the Minister particularly who was in charge of the investigation and who was reporting to him. I asked that for a very specific reason. We have seen a number of examples in this chamber of where the Minister ducks his responsibility as a Minister. He ducked the issue of the Burkegate affair that Senator Knowles has just raised and said that he was not aware of the law. He ducked the Marshall Islands affair.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. If Senator Bishop is to ask a supplementary question, I do not think we should be subjected to a speech before she gets to that question. I ask that she be called to order.
—Order! It has to be a supplementary question on the original question, Senator Bishop.

—The point of the preamble to the supplementary question is the fact that I asked the Minister a very simple question. I asked him who was responsible and who was reporting to him because we want to know in this chamber that he is actually paying attention to what happens in his Department as distinct from trying to blame yet another public servant in his Department. Once again we have seen it here this afternoon with the Minister trying to blame Mr Forrester. I want to know who it is, and at the same time I want to know the nature of the complaint. If there is an allegation of harassment, the options are that it must be by way of a formal grievance or one of the others the Minister outlined. I want to know. I ask who is in charge of the investigation and want to know what stage it is at.
—I do not have quite the same salacious interest in the details of these matters as Senator Bishop obviously has. I do not know who is handling the matter.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President; this is a serious matter. The Minister is trying to slide away from his responsibility by using the word `salacious' as being applicable to people on this side. Mr President, I would ask you to ask him to withdraw.
—Order! I do not think it is unparliamentary, but would you just answer the supplementary question, Senator Evans.

—On the point of order, Mr President, there is a standing order that very explicitly says that one cannot cast improper motives upon those on either side of the House. The clear intent of that snide little remark by Senator Evans was that somehow Senator Bishop was not asking a bona fide question but was trying to satisfy some internal concern of her own. That is an improper motive and I ask you to direct that Senator Evans withdraw it.

—Mr President, on the point of order, can I suggest that if you are to take up the point of order by Senator Alston—and there might be some case for it—you also rule out the supplementary question which was full of inferences and allegations against Senator Evans.
—Order! I regarded it as a debating point and I did not think it was unparliamentary. For the better ruling of the chamber, it might be better if it be withdrawn. That is up to Senator Evans.

—I am happy to defer to you, Mr President. I am reminded of the exchange I heard recently in Parliament House when someone said, `Why do so many people take an instant dislike to Senator Bishop?' to which the answer was, `It saves time'. The short answer to her question is that the Secretary of the Department has reported to me on this matter, as one would expect to be the case.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer and it relates to the removal of the sales tax exemption on some recycled paper products. Why has the Government, with its stated commitment to recycling, changed the rules overnight and deliberately chosen to threaten the viability of an emerging Australian owned industry which adds value to wastepaper? Will the Minister confirm whether the two large multinational companies which already have an 80 per cent share of the market benefit most from this decision? Why was this change announced out of the blue without consultation on 26 June? Did the timing have anything to do with the new political donations disclosure laws coming into effect on 30 June?

—Mr President, if I can have a go at what Senator Evans fell foul of, it is a sort of salacious question about multinationals and all that sort of stuff. It is a Democrats' salacious question. Let me say on the principal issue that the Australian pulp and paper industry's recycling performance has been very good by world standards, and probably Senator Kernot knows that.

PARA.TAB: In absolute terms wastepaper usage increased from 560,000 tonnes in 1980 to 911,000 tonnes in 1991. Recycled facial tissue forms only a small part of this industry—a very small part. Available evidence suggests that the sales tax exemption for recycled toilet and facial tissue, exercise books and paper bags has contributed little to the objective of saving native forest. Rather, it had led to distortions in the wastepaper market, with high quality waste being directed to tax exempt and often single use products.

A sales tax exemption is only one means of promoting environmentally sound practices. There are a number of other initiatives in place: for example, the recently announced national waste minimisation and recycling strategy will provide a direct means of encouraging recycling.

In so far as there are two major companies concerned, I think Senator Kernot was probably referring to Bowaters and Kimberly-Clark. They are, in part, multinational companies. There is nothing intrinsically evil about that, although the implication was that there was something evil about it. Amcor, an Australian company, as I understand it, is a very significant shareholder in Kimberly-Clark. It is not an exclusively foreign company in that sense. Both those major companies are strong growth businesses exporting from Australia—I think that is to be encouraged—but that was not the reason, as I understand it, for the decision at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask the Minister a supplementary question. What was the reason? He still has not told us. He has not given a reason for the timing, but he has talked about environmental responsibility. I have been told also that the reason has something to do with imports, yet the Government does not even know; it does not even have desegregated figures which show how much recycled paper comes into Australia. What is the real reason for this policy change?

—Senator Kernot asked me whether it had something to do with company disclosures in relation to electoral laws and the answer is no. As to the precise timing of the announcement, I will obtain information from the Treasurer. I remember the issue coming to Cabinet at that time. I do not think there was any reason given for it being brought to the Cabinet at that time, but I will find out about that for the honourable senator.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I draw his attention to the fact that the migration review office in Brisbane has now been closed and that since June this year cases have been and will be dealt with from Adelaide. Is the Minister aware that this change is causing massive disruption to both clients of the Department and departmental officers in Queensland, as they have to continually ring Adelaide for some sort of service? Is he also aware that officers in the Adelaide office refuse to accept reverse charge calls from clients based in Queensland when trying to find out the status of their cases? In view of the fact that Queensland is the third largest State in Australia, will the Minister take action to provide a migration review office in Brisbane? Otherwise, can the Minister take steps to ensure that the Department provide a 008 number for constituents so that Queenslanders are not unduly penalised by having to continually make interstate calls to find out the progress of their cases?

—I personally was not aware of the closure of the migration review office in Brisbane. Quite clearly, I think Senator Bjelke-Petersen's observation that this would cause disruption and quite a deal of difficulty to those who would otherwise use that particular office must be correct. To have the added burden of having to phone Adelaide without any reverse charge or 008 facility would seem to be a burden which should not be imposed on those who have to make genuine inquiries of such an office. I will bring this matter to the attention of the Minister and seek to get a response for Senator Bjelke-Petersen as soon as possible.

—I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to the Prime Minister's announcement in Adelaide last week of a $12m refurbishment of the Indian Pacific train, $4.4m to upgrade the Islington railway workshops and $3.5m for the Port Augusta workshops. Firstly, can the Minister advise what this considerable injection of funds will mean for South Australia in terms of becoming the rail hub of the nation? Secondly, can the Minister advise of any details of the Federal Government's request to Australian National to provide a detailed business plan outlining an appropriate structure for AN in the future and, in particular, its consequences for South Australia?

—The announcement is very good news for South Australia and came about as a result of the transfer of some 60 per cent of Australian National's current operations to the organisation now known as National Rail, which of course cast some question mark on the future operations of the remainder of Australian National's operations.

PARA.TAB: The question that was pre-eminent in terms of the passenger operations of Australian National was the future viability of the Indian Pacific train. I know that Senator Tambling would be aware that that viability also hinges on the Ghan because the two services very much operate together. If Australian National were to lose one, that would seriously jeopardise the continued viability of the other. So I must say that personally I am extremely pleased with the Government's decision to provide this very substantial level of support for the continued operation of the Indian Pacific. As Senator Button would know, the Government gave serious, very detailed and lengthy consideration to this issue. I am pleased that the decision was taken to refurbish this train.

The upgrading of the Islington and Port Augusta workshops will put them in the best position possible to compete for ongoing National Rail maintenance business. These initiatives together will create substantive spin-offs for South Australia. Not only will they secure and maintain the jobs of 1,000 employees but also they will improve the efficiency of rail activities operating in the State generally and, hence, will create new opportunities for expanding those activities. This will do no harm at all to South Australia's aspirations, referred to by Senator Schacht, of becoming a major rail hub.But the greater impact will come through the National Rail initiative and the decision to standardise the Adelaide-Melbourne line. Efficient mainline freight operations will improve the potential for landbridging of freight through Adelaide.

The Government's recent decisions clarify a number of issues affecting the future of AN's non-national rail activities. The question remains as to how best to organise these activities to maximise the ongoing viability of the residual Australian National operations. Accordingly, the Federal Government, as part of the same decision, has asked the Commission to provide its views on how best to do this through a detailed business plan, which will be submitted to the Government by the end of October. The Government, of course, will give careful consideration to that plan once it is received from Australian National.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the nature and extent of Australia's humanitarian assistance to the distressed peoples in Somalia and Bosnia-Herzegovina?

—John Kerin, the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, announced last week a special emergency grant of $3 1/2m to Somalia, primarily in the form of food aid easily and quickly dispersable. I think that had less attention than it should have received in the media. We are extremely conscious of the distress in Somalia at the moment and we are very keen to join with others in the international community to respond in a helpful way. We will continue to monitor the situation there.

PARA.TAB: So far as the situation in Bosnia-Herzegovina is concerned, my recollection is that to date we have made some $750,000 available in humanitarian emergency refugee relief aid. I will have to check whether that has been wholly devoted to the situation in Bosnia-Herzegovina or whether it is elsewhere in the Balkans.

We have also made a number of places available under the refugee component of the immigration program—I think some 750 last year and some 1,250 in 1992-93. Again, I will need to double check those figures. Along with the question of our possible future further financial support, this is a matter that is under continuing review by the Government. We are very conscious of the way in which the situation is deteriorating. It is extremely distressing. We want to assist, as best we possibly can, within the limit of the scarce resources available.
