TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. I refer the Minister to the shipment of 18 tonnes of toxic waste that left the port of Fremantle on 28 or 29 July 1992 on the ship Maria Laura. I ask: first, was a licence issued for the export of this waste? If not, why not? If so, what conditions were placed on the licence? Do these conditions satisfy Australia's obligations under the Basle Convention? Secondly, what is the proposed method of disposal of this waste? When, and to whom, will a certificate of destruction be issued? Thirdly, was the Minister contacted by the Western Australian Government prior to the ship leaving Fremantle? Fourthly, if it is necessary, will the Minister allow the waste to be brought back to Australia? Fifthly, does the Minister intend to take any further action on this matter? Finally, will the Minister permit any further exports of this type?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chamarette did give me some notice of this very detailed question shortly before Question Time. I have obtained an answer for Senator Chamarette which is as detailed as her question. As a result, I seek the leave of the Senate to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
b)See a)

c)Conditions relating to type of wastes to be exported; period of export; maximum tonnage; ports of export; method of transport; safe transport by sea; country of import; method of destruction; safe transport by land; facility for destruction; compliance with State and Territory laws; consent by the importing country; provision of advice on each export movement; provision of evidence of destruction; compliance with environmental standards in the country of final destruction.
d)I am advised that these conditions, which were applied to the permit holder, were understood to satisfy the requirements of the Basel Convention.
b)Once destruction is carried out, evidence is required to be provided to the Australian Government on destruction.

ANSWER.PARA: 3Yes. The WA Government sought export of these wastes.
4Now that the wastes have left South African waters for France all the indications are that there will be no need to bring them back to Australia

6The Commonwealth Government is working with State and Territory Governments for destruction facilities for all of Australia's hazardous wastes. It is not envisaged that there will be further permits granted for export of this type of hazardous waste.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Lest I be accused in any way of misleading the Senate, in answer to Senator Bishop's question I said that it was the Secretary who had reported to me directly, on my recollection, on the Butler harassment matter. I have now been corrected; my recollection was astray. It is, in fact, the Deputy Secretary, Mr Geoff Forrester—whose name has come up elsewhere in Question Time—who is engaged in conducting this conciliation process and who has signed off the couple of reports that I received on this matter some little time ago. I apologise to the Senate for misleading it in that way; it was quite unintentional.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Bishop on 18 August 1992 relating to an investigation of allegations of sexual harassment.

SPEECH.PARA: I begin by taking note of the cheap shot by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) when he chose to play the woman as distinct from the issue. I do so quite deliberately, as this particular issue deals with harassment alleged by a woman against a senior man in his Department. I can only infer from his attitude of joviality and his jocular manner in dealing with the issue today that that is the real way he views the question at hand.

PARA.TAB: The Minister stood up glibly after Question Time and virtually said, `Gosh, golly, gee, I have misled you again', without ever answering my question as to what mechanisms have been put in train to determine the truth or otherwise of the serious allegations that have been made. To try to blame poor Mr Forrester yet again, as distinct from any other departmental officer, just will not do.

These are the guidelines that set out how the Minister is meant to deal with the issue. I dare say that he has not even bothered to read them. I asked for a copy of his Department's personal version of them, and I received a two-page note, the most important paragraph of which says:

SPEECH.PARA: Staff are reminded of their right to make complaints.

It then has a list of the sorts of things that might comprise the complaints. However, it is utterly silent on the question of how they are to be dealt with. So I can only conclude that they are to be dealt with in accordance with this publication, which remains valid.

PARA.TAB: This document says, `Mechanisms for Resolving Cases of Sexual Harassment'. At no stage does it say that an officer shall conciliate. What is meant by `conciliation'? Does it mean that the complainant has to compromise? There is not a single, solitary syllable about conciliation in this document.

The document says that the matter is to be investigated. I asked the Minister how he has established this investigation. First of all, he said that the Secretary of the Department just might have whispered in his ear that one was going on. Then he told us that no, it was the Deputy Secretary. What is the formal nature of the inquiry? Yes, these guidelines provide for informal and formal grievances to be lodged. They also require the Department to act, even if the complainant does not wish to go on.

There is an implied inference in all of the reporting of this matter that Senator Evans, as the Minister, would like the matter to just go away. The fact is that, immediately, we read an article in the paper which says:

SPEECH.PARA: A spokesman for the Department said last night that it had a good system for dealing with allegations of sexual harassment. "It allows people to make their concerns known without fear of victimisation".
Where in the so-called conciliation process can the woman who has made the complaint see justice? Obviously she must have felt very strongly about the matter to have raised it in the first place.

PARA.TAB: This is now the third example where we have seen the Minister, Senator Evans, simply closing his eyes and deciding that he does not want to see what is going on in his Department. He has done it with regard to Burke. He simply says that Burke did not know the rules, therefore that is the end of the problem. The Minister says he is terribly sorry that Burke did not know the rules, but it is not Senator Evans's responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —He knew but he forgot.

—He forgot. Then we had the example of the Marshall Islands where the Minister very carefully and strangely did not even bother to talk to the officials in his Department and get on top of the matter. We have the instance where the Minister gained knowledge and then did not come back into this chamber and inform the Senate, having denied any knowledge earlier.

PARA.TAB: In other words, what is the Minister paid for to be a Minister? He is responsible for his Department and what goes on in it. His cheap, snide personal shots at me, at the officer concerned or my colleagues on this side of the chamber, will not take the place of a satisfactory, substantial answer. I want to know what steps the Minister personally took to set up an inquiry concerning these allegations.

Where are the written instructions and guidelines that he gave to the officer he appointed? What investigatory methods has the Minister adopted? Whom has he questioned? Where has he taken evidence? Where is the report to the Minister on the state of that inquiry, and when are we going to hear an update in this chamber on what has become a very public allegation and issue? For the Minister to behave in his rather off-handed, rude way will simply not do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether this question deserves a reply because it got a reply in Question Time on the substantive issue, namely that the complainant was fully briefed on all the options available to her under the Public Service Regulations, but asked that the matter be treated informally by the Department in the first instance.

PARA.TAB: The guidelines available to Senator Bishop—and if she does not have them already, we will make sure that she gets them—make it perfectly clear that, apart from the options of going immediately to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission or the Merit Protection and Review Agency, or on the other hand, seeking legal counselling, going to the police and so on, the other immediate option available is to contact the workplace harassment contact officer for advice and then, as the charter suggests, confront the alleged harasser. If after having done that the complainant wishes to pursue the matter, the complainant can then lodge a grievance under regulation 83 of the Public Service Regulations.

All of those options are available. None of those options has been excluded at this stage. At the request of the complainant, the matter is being treated informally and is being addressed in a wholly sensible way, I am prepared to assume—although I have not been involved in any of the detail of it, nor would I expect that I would be at this stage—by the senior officers of my Department. If the complainant in question is dissatisfied with this process and wants to pursue it in any of

SPEECH.PARA: the other ways that I have mentioned, that option is entirely open to her and no doubt it will be pursued, in which case formal inquiries will be constituted and the rest of the process will be set in train.

PARA.TAB: I will see if there is anything further I can usefully add to my answer in the light of Senator Bishop's subsequent contribution, but I do not believe there is. I have not taken any personal role in this, nor do I believe that it is appropriate for me to do so in a departmental personnel matter, unless and until some matter properly comes to me for decision in the proper course of procedure. I am not sure whether that is part of the procedure at any stage in these matters. I will need to check that, but it certainly has not got to that stage yet because—I repeat—so far the complainant has wanted the matter to be dealt with informally.

It would be better all round in matters of this degree of delicacy and sensitivity if, instead of careering around in the public domain in the way that Senator Bishop seems determined to do, she allowed this matter to take the course that it is properly taking within my Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the same motion. I also wish to protest the failure of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) to answer the question calmly, clearly or in any way convincingly. There is an aspect that is common to the three matters Senator Bishop has referred to. I refer first to the Burke matter, on which the Minister sought to give an answer with regard to Senator Knowles's question today—I refer specifically to those matters relating to Mr Burke that the Minister has been required to answer for the last 18 months—secondly, the Richardson matter with regard to the Marshall Islands, and, thirdly, this one.

PARA.TAB: What is common to these three matters is that the Minister has a personal interest. Burke is a former Premier, a Labor leader in Western Australia, and was the appointee of this Minister to the post of Ireland and the Holy See; secondly, Senator Richardson was a close colleague in Cabinet of this Minister; and thirdly, Mr Butler, who has undoubted diplomatic skills, has developed a closeness to this Minister which I think the Minister would honestly own.

When these people, who are close mates of the Minister, are subject to a question in the Senate, the Minister's reaction on all points—Senator Bishop is correct in the protest she makes in moving this motion—is that he goes over the top. He is not calm, he is not clear and he is not convincing. Yet when a question is asked about Australian aid to Somalia or the Australian position with regard to Bosnia-Herzegovina, the Minister can give a clear and calm answer. But when it comes down to mates, this Minister, instead of giving a calm and clear answer, goes over the top, makes totally reprehensible remarks about a member of the Senate which are quite uncalled for—I grant that he withdraw them—and shows that he is unable to give a competent answer in a matter for which he ought to be responsible.

The Minister makes the appeal that we ought to be able to allow this matter to take due process. Instead of being personally involved and embroiling his inadequate answer with the personal association he has with such people, why cannot the Minister in this case give dispassionate and calm answers? The Minister is failing in his responsibilities as Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade by the way in which he is quite incapable of answering to this Senate on matters for which he should be responsible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Teague says that Senator Evans has answered different questions in different ways; that he has at times abused people. In using the word `mates', Senator Teague would seem to be approaching quite close to the sorts of things he is accusing Senator Evans of. I simply point out that when we get up to make accusations in this chamber, it is often worth looking to see whether they apply to ourselves. It seems to me that there is a difference when Senator Evans talks about Somalia or the situation in the former Yugoslavian republic or somewhere else, because they are matters he is directly involved in and has responsibility for.
—He is responsible for the administration of his Department.

—Of course he has to look to his Department, but we have a very big public service to do just that, and one cannot expect a Minister to be over the details of everything that happens in his office. When he is berated—I think that is not too strong a word—again and again about mates and what have you, he cannot be expected, off the top of his head, to be able to answer those sorts of questions in the way in which he can when asked questions about something that is directly within his immediate responsibility.
—He turned a blind eye to Richo and he turned a blind eye to Burke.

—What Senator Hill said is exactly what I am complaining about. He said that Senator Evans turned a blind eye to Richo, which is a fairly derogatory statement in intent. To say that he turns a blind eye to his mates is a derogatory comment in intent. Senator Evans has such a calm disposition; we all know he is a person whom it takes a lot to provoke. We might call him the St Francis of Assisi of this Senate. In spite of that, given the sort of provocation that comes from those opposite on issues that are very peripheral to his main concern, we cannot expect even a person of his disposition to restrain himself from now and then making a riposte.

PARA.TAB: Those opposite say that Senator Evans has done this with his mates, Richo being one of his mates. Well, I hope he has because Senator Evans sat in Cabinet and in this chamber with Senator Richardson for a long while. No matter what those opposite say, Senator Richardson was an excellent Minister and no doubt Senator Evans admires, as I do, the way that Senator Richardson carried out the many portfolios that he held.

What I say will make no difference to what happens. Those opposite are going to get up and try to provoke Senator Evans. On rare occasions they will succeed. All I say is that Senator Evans has carried out his administration in an exemplary fashion. Nobody has been able to show that his integrity has been in any way compromised by anything he has done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the motion moved by my colleague Senator Bishop. I rise because of an issue that Senator Cooney raised—that is, whether we would have expected Senator Evans to have been across this particular issue. This issue has been in the press for a number of weeks and it is surprising that Senator Evans came into this Parliament so poorly briefed.

PARA.TAB: An article appeared recently in the Sydney Morning Herald which gave us some detail of the work which Senator Evans's Department carries out in briefing Senator Evans for Question Time. Over a six-month period, the Department prepared—and Senator Evans will correct me if I am wrong—707 possible parliamentary questions. Those questions were prepared for Senator Evans to make sure that he was well briefed on the issues that we wished to bring forward to him. Out of the 707 possible parliamentary questions, there were apparently none about the Marshall Islands affair, which is interesting. The article in the Sydney Morning Herald, which I suppose Senator Evans has not read because he is so poorly briefed about so many matters, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The long and short of it was that Senator Evans had not been told a lot of details about these cables—
These, of course, are the cables relating to the Marshall Islands—
No-one had foreseen the strife ahead and no PPQs had been written. Questions without ready answer in the Parliament left Senator Evans variously flat-footed, embarrassed and furious.
But Senator Evans was not going to leave it there. The article continues:

Departmental officials have now been told, in plain language, that this time their entire careers could hang on the quality and inspiration of their PPQs. Departmental and government officials insist that the creation of PPQs is valuable democratic work.

So 707 PPQs later, we have a very serious issue which Senator Bishop raised today. One would have thought that the 708th PPQ might have actually dealt with this matter. But Senator Evans came in here and, as usual, tried to bluster and bumble away and indulge in abuse of senators who raise these issues. I again draw attention to the grave concern that we on this side of the chamber have about Senator Evans's very poor performance as Foreign Minister and about his lack of capacity to give straightforward answers in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) has really scored the trifecta today with Burke, the Marshall Islands and Butler. Senator Kemp has adequately pointed out the amount of work that appears to go on in the Minister's office—which is useless—and that it somehow manages to avoid the main issues of the day. Quite clearly, from the attitude of Senator Evans during Question Time, he obviously regards the question of a woman making a complaint against an ambassador of this nation, somebody whom we send overseas to represent the interests of Australia and whom we expect to behave in a particular way, as flippant and without any substance or, indeed, the need to treat in a serious vein.

PARA.TAB: As I said, the comments he made indicated the way in which he was treating the matter. If he were a man who took the issue seriously, he would have seen the reports in the press; he would have heard the interviews that Mr Butler carried out; he would have asked his Department for a proper briefing; and he would have been on top of the matter and the way in which it was being investigated. Quite frankly, whether the complaint is formal or informal, I expect that the woman concerned has made a statement; that Senator Evans has given the matter to a particular officer to investigate; that that officer has sought to take evidence or at least have discussions with people who may have been witnesses or to whom she would have spoken after the event; that Senator Evans would have sought to have spoken with Mr Butler after the event; that he would have sought to have complied with the regulations as set out in this document; and that he would have had a serious view on how the matter was in fact proceeding.

Unlike Senator Evans, there are people who consider this matter to be very serious and, indeed, consider the cavalier way in which he treats the matters of Burkegate, the Marshall Islands and now the Butler affair as things that can be swept under the carpet as in fact meaning that he is not carrying out his duty as a Minister under the Westminster system. There are many people who ask questions about whether Senator Evans's temperament makes him suitable for the job he has. The way that he is failing to carry out his duty in this matter can only add to that speculation. I want to know who the officer is who has been placed in charge of the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have told you.
—The Minister did not. He could not remember at first. He told me that the Deputy Secretary had given him a bit of a briefing.
—And I said he was in charge of the conciliation. Don't you listen or are you busy writing your speech?
—I will be interested to see the written briefing that has been given to the Minister.
—It is none of your business.
—To the contrary, the moment this is a public issue is when it is raised in the public press and concerns an official ambassador of this country representing the interests of all Australians—
—You are an official disgrace.
—Are you going to pick him up, Mr President?
—Order! I did not ask you to withdraw, Senator Walters. I was hoping we might get through the first day in a better atmosphere, but calling somebody a disgrace is unparliamentary.

—I would have thought that Senator Walters's description was fairly mild compared to the things that we hear muttered by those on the other side. My point is that again the Minister is evidencing that he thinks this matter is of no consequence, presumably because, aside from his friend Mr Butler, the other person does not matter very much. That is not the point that other people are concerned about. People are concerned that there has been a very public report of this matter which the Minister chooses still to call informal. I do not know whether that means because a formal grievance has not been filed under section 83 of the relevant regulations. However, to make an informal complaint there would also be a statement, and it would have to be dealt with as these regulations require.

PARA.TAB: The Minister now, in his interjections, is saying that the Deputy Secretary, poor Mr Forrester, who was lumbered earlier today, has been charged with the responsibility of actually carrying out that investigation. Because it involves a very senior diplomat who represents Australia overseas, it is of interest to all Australians. Secondly, one does not wish to come to the conclusion that a conciliation could, in fact, result in the powerful being preferred and the woman without power being harassed or pressured into taking away or abandoning her informal claim.

In other words, this is a matter which we on this side of the chamber and, indeed, the people who have come forward and asked questions about this matter, will continue to pursue until we get answers that are better than the ones we got on Burkegate and better than the ones we got on the Marshall Islands affair. Hopefully, we will get some decent answers concerning this most unfortunate affair of Mr Butler.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 July I boxed some material in response to a press release issued by Senator Calvert concerning the provision of legal aid to some of those accused of the attack on the Iranian Embassy. I had a discussion with Senator Calvert concerning this matter some two weeks ago. I wish to say to my friend and colleague Senator Calvert that, in so far as he finds any expression used in that letter offensive, I unreservedly apologise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the Minister for his statement. I was rather disappointed in what happened. I certainly have taken legal advice as to the defamatory statements made by Mr Chris Murphy that were boxed by Senator Tate's office. I am taking further legal advice. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I inform the Senate that the schedule of amendments made by the Senate to the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992, which was forwarded with the Bill to the House of Representatives on 24 June 1992, mistakenly included four amendments which were in fact not agreed to by the Senate. The presence of these amendments in the schedule was not detected when the House of Representatives agreed to the Bill as amended by the Senate later on that day, and was not detected until both Houses had risen for the winter adjournment.

PARA.TAB: The Clerk of the Senate took the view that, as the intention of the two Houses was clear, the problem could be overcome by the correction of the erroneous documentary record and the Bill could proceed to royal assent as amended by the Senate. The Government, on contrary advice, came to the conclusion that the Bill could not proceed to royal assent and that it would be necessary for the error to be corrected by some action by the two Houses.

The view initially taken by the Government's advisers was that the Senate would need to correct the error by resolution, either by asking for the Bill to be returned to the Senate or by formally advising the House of Representatives of the corrected schedule of amendments. Subsequently, however, the view was expressed that the problem could be overcome by me signing a substitute message forwarding a substitute schedule of amendments to the House, without any further action by the Senate.

On the advice of the Clerk, I took the view that it would not be proper for me to do this, and that the Senate should be acquainted with the problem and asked to take remedial action. I took this view particularly because the proposed date of commencement of the Bill, 1 July 1992, had then passed, and there is a question as to whether the Bill would operate retrospectively if it is now passed or whether further amendment is required to provide that retrospective operation. Having been acquainted with the problem, it is now for the Senate to take the appropriate action to have the Bill reconsidered.
I table the reports which were made to me by the Clerk on the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the President's statement and the corrected schedule of amendments to the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992 agreed to by the Senate on 24 June 1992 be forwarded to the House of Representatives and that the House be requested to reconsider the Bill with the corrected schedule of amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we would all agree that this is not one of the high points in the history of the Senate; it will not go down as one of our more glorious achievements. Nevertheless, the unanimous intention of the Senate with regard to the clauses in question is clear, and the correction by this motion will correctly convey the intention of the Senate. I do not wish to delay the Senate long with what I regard as essentially a formal matter, notwithstanding the verbose and inaccurate amendment which has been moved, to which I will respond subsequently.

PARA.TAB: I am not convinced that this motion is necessary. It is my view that Mr President could have acted to advise the House of Representatives of the error because all he was being called upon to do was to advise the House of Representatives of the decisions of the Senate. There was, and is, no contention about that. Everybody knows what took place and everybody agrees with what took place. There was a clerical error. It would not have been changing any decision of the Senate; it would merely have been accurately conveying to the House of Representatives the decision which was unanimously agreed upon by all the participants in the debate. I do not believe that it is necessary for us to be proceeding in this way, but now that the President has so reported, this motion will resolve the matter.

It probably also would have been quite possible for the House to have acted on its own initiative and passed the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill in the same form as passed by the Senate. That would have met the requirements of section 58 of the Constitution—that is, the Bill would have been passed in the same form by both Houses—but it would have left the procedural situation within the Parliament unresolved. I do not think that is of constitutional significance but, nevertheless, it is something the Parliament ought properly to consider.

Now that Mr President has reported in this manner, and to ensure that nobody can be in any doubt not only that the Bill in its final form as passed by the House complies with the Constitution but also that the process complies with the requirements of the Standing Orders of both Houses, I have moved the motion which I read earlier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we all understand how this situation came about. It is not unique. It is very understandable that under the pressures of business, particularly the pressures to which the officers of the Senate are from time to time subject when a government insists on guillotining Bills through both the House of Representatives—
—The time was extended.

—Indeed, time was extended on that occasion but Senator Kernot should bear in mind—I do not want to be sidetracked for too long on this issue—that the Table Office, which is primarily responsible for maintaining the schedule, had worked through the preceding night. It was pretty heavy stuff in terms of workload. I think we all understand that and no-one is critical of the circumstances of that occasion; what we are concerned about is to remedy the matter as effectively as possible.

PARA.TAB: The Government had several choices. One was to actually bring the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill into the Senate to have the offending non-existent amendments deleted. The reason why the Government has not done that is that it is clearly terrified that what is left of the nervous nellies might decide, on second thoughts, to move some fairly substantive amendments to the Bill. Clearly, whether or not we did that, even if we were so tempted or minded, would not really matter unless the Democrats agreed with us. Clearly, the Government's concern was that the Democrats might go to water and, therefore, seek to move a number of amendments which might actually start to cut this Bill, as it now is, to shreds.
The Democrats have already signalled that they are most unlikely to agree to the contribution level being increased beyond 4 per cent after 1 January for businesses with payrolls in excess—

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't mean we have gone to water.

—No, it does not and I am not saying that the Democrats have; I am saying that the Government thinks they might. That is what it is about and that is why we are proceeding in this fashion. Otherwise, it would have been a simple matter of the Senate excising the amendments.

PARA.TAB: The Government is worried that the Democrats might also be tempted to move other amendments, such as our preferred course in relation to a variable contributions tax or rebates, which we all agree—and I think every commentator in the land agrees—is a much more equitable manner of proceeding. The outfit that is chock-a-block full of verbal compassion these days certainly will not have a bar of it when it comes to superannuation. It is in the business of not giving low income earners anything like a fair break. It is in the business of flat rate contributions taxes, which we all know will have a devastating impact on the results that will ultimately flow through to low income earners from compulsory superannuation. That is part and parcel of my amendment and I will come to that in a moment.
I have an important question that I want to put to Senator McMullan, if I can distract him for a moment. In his statement, the President says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there is a question as to whether the bill will operate retrospectively if it is now passed or whether further amendment is required to provide that retrospective operation.

I have no doubt that Senator McMullan has taken advice on this matter. He would know that a Bill is presumed to have prospective operation only. There is, in other words, a presumption against retrospectivity.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, the normal course of events is to clearly and unequivocally prescribe the intention that a Bill has a retrospective effect. The courts have frequently declared that, in the absence of some clear statement to the contrary, an Act will be assumed not to have retrospective operation. It can be done. There is nothing to stop the Parliament legislating retrospectively. There are very good public policy reasons why it does not and why, if it does, it does so at its peril because there is usually a large number of members of the public who are quite severely outraged by retrospective action, particularly if they are directly affected by it. The courts, naturally enough, are very reluctant to allow an Act to have retrospective effect.

In this situation we have a guarantee Bill which says that it starts on 1 July. It is quite clear from the Acts Interpretation Act that the commencement date of the Bill will be the date on which the Bill is passed and that will be, at the earliest, 18 August. We cannot simply backdate it automatically because of the fact that it went through the Parliament on a day after the date that it was supposed to have commenced. Therefore, I would have thought we very much need to have an express provision that shows the clear intent of the legislature that it should commence from 1 July. If we do not, we proceed at our peril.

As Senator McMullan would well know, there are a number of groups out there—indeed, I would have thought the majority of the business community, particularly the small business community—who know that the Government's compulsory regime is going to take them to the cleaners. It will impose intolerable burdens on them. Once again, if we accept the Treasury estimate—which is precisely what the Government's advertisement would have the populace believe—if employers bear the full cost, up to 100,000 jobs will be lost, and there is a very real temptation for, perhaps, the Australian Confederation of Australian Industry and others to challenge this legislation.

Therefore, I would have thought it very important that the Government take advice as to whether simply having the Bill go back to the House of Representatives to have those four amendments removed, and then be passed on to be given royal assent, is sufficient in the circumstances, or whether the Government is leaving itself open to a devastating legal challenge. If there is one way of achieving the ultimate confusion and chaos in the area of superannuation, I would have thought it would be to proceed down the track with this compulsory regime and then find later on that it is all invalid. I specifically ask Senator McMullan whether he has taken legal advice or whether he has sought legal advice—indeed, whether he has sought any formal or informal soundings—as to the status of the legislation, and whether it is likely to be at risk in the courts if we simply do not have it brought back to the Senate as, clearly, the Government is afraid to do.

Speaking briefly to the amendments which have been circulated in my name, I think the first point is self-evident. The reason why a lot of the current problems arose is the unnecessary and indecent haste that the Government pursued. We all know that people were screaming blue murder in the weeks leading up to 1 July and saying that it simply was not possible to put the whole thing in place by that date. Until the Democrats caved in at the last moment, it was looking very dicey. But, of course, at no stage was the Government prepared to contemplate an extension of time; it insisted on 1 July. So there was a guillotine in the House of Representatives and very strict time limits imposed here, and this is simply a clear product of that approach by the Government.

The words `failure to follow the proper processes' refer to what could easily have been done by way of providing in this chamber and in the House of Representatives for an express provision, making it clear that the Government intends the Bill to have a retrospective effect. Again, the only reason that the Government is not prepared to do that, I presume, is that it is terrified that the Democrats will somehow go to water. If there is a better reason, I would like to hear about it. Otherwise, the Government will have a question mark over this legislation.

Thirdly, I will move that the Senate records its unequivocal opposition to the compulsory superannuation regime. I have no doubt at all that in the months leading up to the next Federal election the ordinary workers will become aware that they are the bunnies in this game and that, far from the advertisements being accurate in telling them that somehow the boss is picking up the tab, it will dawn on them that they are picking up the tab.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will certainly become aware of the contrast.

—They will indeed. As Senator McMullan rightly said this morning in not demurring from my proposition that there are very many groups in the community who get a very raw deal under the Government's approach—
—I did not say that.

—I noted that Senator McMullan did not quarrel with the proposition, but I will be very interested to hear how he argues the case. I had a letter yesterday from Iain Ross doing his best to defend the indefensible; in other words, why the Government and the ACTU say that two million women outside the paid work force should not have access to superannuation. I should have thought that the Senator Gileses and the Senator Zakharovs of the world would have been outraged in Caucus. Maybe they have been sworn to secrecy.
—They know the reality.

—They know the reality! The reality is, as the Government would well know, that very many women will be particularly vulnerable in their later years in the event of divorce or widowhood. In those circumstances I should have thought that it is very prudent, if the circumstances allow, if the capacity to pay is there—
—I thought you understood what you were saying. You are shedding crocodile tears.

—Perhaps we can hear the substantive response and why, consistent with what Senator McMullan says about capacity to pay—where there are, for example, husbands with the capacity to pay and who contribute to a fund that vests and preserves immediately in the name of the wife—that would not be a very much better deal than the current arrangement which does not give them any security—
—You want to keep women dependent all their lives, one way or the other.
—No, it is precisely the opposite. If the money is paid into the account—
—Based on a husband who has a substantial income—
—Let me explain.
—No, no!

—The Government does not want me to explain but I will do so anyway. If the husband makes the contribution the money then vests and the woman has the ultimate in independence because there is money in an account in her name which he cannot touch and which guarantees her security in retirement. But the Government does not want that at all. Instead, it wants the wife to be ultimately dependent upon the spouse if he is still around or upon the State if he is not. I should have thought that is a very poor deal.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to spend much more time on part time and casual employees. There are about one and a half million of them—about a quarter of the work force—75 per cent of them are women and, again, they will be taken to the cleaners by award superannuation, and we know what sort of a rotten deal they get because I get correspondence on it every day of the week. Again, I am disappointed that the Government does not seem to realise what it is doing to punish those people.

The final matter of concern is this disgraceful advertising campaign that we are being subjected to. I would be interested in the view of the Democrats on this. Firstly, it proceeds as though the legislation is fully in force, which of course it is not. Secondly, it gives everyone the impression, through the mouth of Betty, that the boss is picking up the tab, when of course he is not because it is the workers' shout. The workers are the ones who are really paying for all this, so I would have thought that they should at least be told that.

As Daryl Dixon and others have been saying in recent times, it is very misleading indeed because it does not give a true picture of the amount that they will have in retirement. Taking Senator McMullan's point this morning, sure, the rates of return over the last five years have not been too flash, but that is not my criticism. My criticism is that the Government is not deducting administrative charges, insurance costs and contributions taxes when it publishes these highly dishonest and misleading documents showing what people will get in their retirement.

The Government would prosecute any life office or superannuation fund that had the temerity to do such a thing. The Government would say, `It is grossly misleading. People ought to know what they are likely to get in retirement. They should not be given these figures in gross; they should be given them in current dollars and perhaps on a net present value basis'. But here we have the Government committing all the cardinal sins, all in the interests of somehow scoring a few cheap shots at the taxpayers' expense.

TALK.START.PARA: —We had to change ours yesterday.

—I can tell Senator McMullan that we certainly have not changed ours. I hope Senator McMullan has read the document because if he has he will see that it is even better, fairer and more affordable than it was before. Therefore, I move:

PARA.TAB: At end of the motion add ", but the Senate:

(a)condemns the Government for its unnecessary and indecent haste in rushing through the Parliament important legislation, which adversely affects the lives of millions of Australians, without allowing time for full and proper debate;
(b)condemns the Government for its failure to follow the proper processes in seeking to achieve retrospective operation of the legislation;

(c)records its unequivocal opposition to the Government's compulsory superannuation regime which will severely punish ordinary Australian workers by requiring them to forgo wage increases and rising living standards in order to disqualify themselves from the age pension; and

(d)condemns the Government for embarking on a very expensive and highly misleading advertising campaign which pretends that the legislation is already in force, wrongly implies that employers are expected to bear the cost of compulsory superannuation and paints a very false and inflated picture of the amounts which are likely to be available to workers upon retirement.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats support the Government motion; they do not support the amendment moved by the Opposition. However, we concur with the view of the Clerk of the Senate that, as the intention of the two Houses was clear, the administrative problem could have been overcome by the correction of the erroneous documentary record and the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill could have proceeded to royal assent as amended by the Senate.

PARA.TAB: As we are not recommitting our decision here this afternoon—we have already had the full debate—I would simply assert that the Democrats' position then and now can in no way be described as caving in or being likely to go to water. Senator Alston knows me better than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they do not.

—I think they do. On the contrary, our position and negotiating has been forceful and determined. So I will resist the temptation to recanvass the issues and go over the same old ground. I believe that we made the right decision in voting to put the compulsory system in place. I have always said it is not perfect and is not our preferred model, but we always have the opportunity in this place to refine and to fine-tune, and that is the point about most major pieces of legislation. That opportunity is not denied to us. This is the beginning, not the end, of the superannuation saga. We will see and debate a great deal more about it. Today our intention should be to facilitate the speedy rectification of this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to this matter today. There are undoubtedly three issues. One of them is the constitutional issue which has been canvassed. I certainly agree with the proposition put forward by Senator Alston.

PARA.TAB: The other issue is whether or not the Government, having found itself in this situation, ought to be rushing ahead with the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill and trying to bring it into existence at this stage. Clearly, it will not operate from 1 July. Without its being recommitted, I do not see that it can possibly operate from that date. In any event, it ought to be very clear to the Government by now that it was very misguided legislation.

There would not be a senator in this place who could not give examples of people having lost their jobs as a consequence of the additional funds that employers are now expected to have to pay as a result of this amendment to the legislation. I certainly can. I know of one example where a group of three lost their jobs. It was not possible for the operation to continue with two. The employer could no longer continue to pay the money that he would have to pay for three employees and he closed the section. So three people lost their jobs.

I would say to the Government that, at this stage even, it should reconsider whether it is appropriate. It is not open for the Government or anyone to say that I am not in favour of superannuation; I am. But, if the Government is putting it into effect at such enormous cost to the community, it needs to think seriously about what it is doing.

The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan)—or somebody else who spoke about this in the debate—said that the employers were bearing the full burden. To an extent, they are, in that they have to provide the funds, but I suggest to you, Mr President, that it is the employees who are bearing the burden when, as a consequence of this, they lose jobs. If that is what the Government wants to see as a reasonable outcome to its legislation, I think it should give very serious thought to what it is doing.

As to the operation of the Government's legislation, I wish to refer to a particular matter that I have had brought to my attention. A constituent of mine, a women—and it is significant that it is a woman who indulges in part time and casual work from time to time, and is not in full time employment with a particular employee—worked for 20 hours per week on a casual-part time basis from January 1991 to May of 1991. She then left because she had reason to do so, or the employment may have been just for a particular period.

She did not know, when she started off in this employment, that her employer was required to pay 3 per cent towards her superannuation. It was really only near the end of her period of employment that she found that out, and received a letter about it. When she had completed her employment, she found out the grisly details of what, in fact, had happened to that money.

The fact is that during the period of time that she had been employed, her employer had paid $165.05 as the 3 per cent superannuation tax that was required to be paid to Canplan Multi-industry Superannuation Plan 330. her number, as a member of that plan, was 36463. What she, in fact, received at the end of it all was $34.69. The actual amount of money that she was to have received was a fraction more than that—$44.05—from which the superannuation company deducted PAYE tax of $9.36. So the cheque she received according to her group certificate was for $34.69.

As I have said, she did not know she was in a superannuation scheme. So, in a sense, she was not really getting anything that she was expecting. But she was incensed to think that this sort of rip-off is being perpetrated by the Government; that there are probably people in schemes like this—people like herself, who go from one scheme to another—who, in fact, are not covered realistically for superannuation at all. It is a superannuation company, registered by the Government, whose operations are clearly approved of by the Government, that is getting all of the money out of the scheme, and women, in particular, who are inclined to this type of

SPEECH.PARA: part time employment, are the ones who are missing out.

PARA.TAB: If she had happened to have gone immediately to another employer whose superannuation was with that same plan, the scheme could have been carried on. If she had not realised that she should take the money out—if she had been sufficiently misguided to think that it was a superannuation scheme and that, perhaps, she should leave her money in it—it would not have taken very long at all for the remaining $44 to have been eroded to absolutely nothing. She might not have known about it, but she certainly would not have got any benefit at all.

A superannuation scheme is something that actually provides benefits for members and where, once money is going into it, there is some chance that there will be superannuation at the end of it. It should be genuine retirement benefit money, not something that comes out from time to time and is virtually worthless. It is the employers who are paying in. It is a tax, as far as they are concerned—a tax they have to pay. There is no reason for employers to spend a great deal of time and effort monitoring what happens and monitoring how much of the money benefits their employees.

It really is an absolute nonsense that the Government has put into effect. Now it comes in here today trying again, from 1 July last, a date long since gone, to add an additional sum which employers have to pay—not to the benefit of employees, as I have proved conclusively by the statements I have given. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a statement which sets out the details of this particular superannuation plan which shows how little the employee got in the end.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: [STATEMENT OMITTED FROM DATABASE - SEE HARD COPY PAGES 34-36]

TALK.START.PARA: —There is another aspect of this matter that really does need to be aired. I ask the Senate to think back to June, if we can think back that far, to the pressure under which we were working at that time. The Parliamentary Secretary, when he first spoke and moved the motion, said that this was not a high point in the history of the Senate. Had he not said that, I may not have made any further comment upon this but, in view of that statement, I think it is important to point out the pressure under which the Clerks of the Senate were working at the time. Certainly, a clerical mistake has been made in a section of that part of the Senate—everybody recognises that—but the one thing that is absolutely certain, is that nobody can attribute fault to the Clerks who were working in conditions which any employer ought be condemned for allowing to operate.

PARA.TAB: The Senate, at that time, was coping with 69 Bills with just under 36 hours of Government Business time in which to deal with them. It was operating under a guillotine with more amendments to those 69 Bills than I could possibly have counted myself. At the time in question, the day these Bills were passed, the Broadcasting Bills were also passed—and anybody who has listened to the Senate or taken the slightest interest in what we were doing would know exactly how detailed, complex and large that package was.

On the day in question, three major packages of Bills reached the third reading—under guillotine, of course. After we had left this place, the Clerks had to stay and incorporate all of those amendments into the documentation which went to the House of Representatives. It is not just a matter of picking a piece of paper off the Clerks' table and sending it across to the House of Representatives showing what we have done. Those amendments have to be incorporated into the legislation, they then all have to be checked to make sure that they are in the right place and they then have to be proof read and eventually transferred to the House of Representatives. In addition, at this time, there were 70 procedural matters to be drafted and prepared for the Senate the next day when we came back again.

I think we were sitting quite absurd hours at that time, and I am talking about the Clerks who finish much later than we do and who start earlier. The fact is that most of the Clerks worked all through the night one night, or so near to all through the night as to make little difference. The fact is that several of them worked from coming in at 8 o'clock on the Wednesday morning until 3 o'clock the following Friday morning, without returning home. That, by my calculations, is 43 hours. There may be certain extreme circumstances in life where one may be required to be up and active for 43 hours, but there can be no justification whatever for the Senate imposing those working conditions on any of its employees.

Presumably, during that time they had an hour's break here and there to have a meal—I certainly hope so—but the circumstances under which the staff of this Parliament, the Clerks of the Senate, were required to operate in that week stand to condemn all of us who are involved in those hours being sat. I shall not comment upon how it was that we came to work past 10.30 p.m. as often as we did at that time. In terms of occupational health and safety, it is absolutely criminal; in terms of just reasonable behaviour from one person to another, it is absolutely outrageous that this should happen.

It is not surprising that a small mistake occurred. Probably the surprising thing is that more mistakes were not made during that time. People were required to work unreasonable hours under pressure. A government which talks about compassion and looking after people needs to stop and think about what it is doing when it treats its own employees in this manner. I am sure that something far more significant would have been done if a union had been involved. However, the clerks of the Senate will not let the Senate down. They tolerate the absurdity of our behaviour because they have a very high regard for the Senate, its role in the parliamentary system and the work that they do.

Having said that this was not a high point in the history of the Senate, let everybody be quite clear that it happened because of the program that the Government was running at the time and the way in which it was forcing legislation through the Senate. As I said, the Senate had 36 hours in which to deal with 69 Bills. It should be remembered that when we go home the clerks still have to do everything that is necessary to transfer the documentation to the other place. That is the reality of what happened.

Perhaps it is a blessing that this happened. The Government has been given an opportunity to behave more sensibly towards the business community of this country, many of whom have gone broke and many of whom are going broke. The passage of this legislation should be deferred so that some people who would otherwise lose their jobs will be given a bit of a chance. The Government should take advantage of what has happened and think about this matter again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to follow Senator Reid, the Opposition Whip. We should all take on board what she said. The last week of Parliament was a farce—an absolute farce. It was a disgrace upon all of us. It was particularly a disgrace upon the Government and upon the Australian Democrats, who supported the guillotine and motions to negative the adjournment.

PARA.TAB: What has to happen in this place before we review procedures? Do we need to have another death in this chamber?

TALK.START.PARA: —Another death!

—Yes. I was here at the time. I can recall that after a number of late nights there was the death of a senator who had been working well and truly into the early hours of the morning after the Senate had adjourned. Senator Knight, a senator in the then Government, also died.
—Ivor Greenwood and John Knight.

—I am not too sure in my mind whether we were actually working late when John Knight died. As one of the longer serving members of this Senate, I think I am entitled to appeal for some sort of sanity and for the procedures of this Parliament to operate in the interests of the people whom we represent.

PARA.TAB: Senator Reid has indicated the number of Bills that were under consideration during the sitting period in question. Let me remind the Senate that on the very day that this incident occurred there were 161 amendments to legislation. In addition, seven of the Bills dealt with that day were subject to the guillotine. We all remember that there was not time for us to consider the propositions that came before us by way of amendment. I believe that there was not time for us to consider in substance the legislation itself. As Senator Reid has said, on that day the Senate was considering three substantial packages of Government legislation, all of which were under the guillotine and all of which required amending. But very few of those amendments were properly considered. We were not given time to consider any of them. It is little wonder then that there was confusion.

I believe it necessary to refer to a letter that was sent to the President of the Senate by the Clerk, and distributed to honourable senators with the approval of the President. That letter, which is dated 2 July 1992, deals very well with the situation. I think it is important for me to refer to that letter so that honourable senators and other people reading the record will see what did in fact occur. I seek leave to incorporate the letter in Hansard.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: 2 July 1992
Senator the Hon. Kerry W. Sibraa
President of the Senate
Mr President
SUPERANNUATION GUARANTEE (ADMINISTRATION) BILL 1992:
ERROR IN RECORDING OF SENATE AMENDMENTS

The schedule of amendments made by the Senate to this bill which was forwarded to the House of Representatives on 24 June 1992 contained 4 amendments which were in fact not agreed to by the Senate. These amendments had been circulated by Senator Alston. Although he indicated during the proceedings on the bill that he did not intend to move the amendments, somewhat ambiguous references to them, which do not appear in Hansard but which are recorded on the video tape of the proceedings, misled responsible officers into believing that the amendments had been put and carried. My attention was distracted from the proceedings during part of his speech. I subsequently queried whether the amendments had in fact been carried but was assured that they had. This error was not detected by the House of Representatives or by departmental officers monitoring the passage of the bill, and the erroneous schedule of amendments was circulated in the House of Representatives when it agreed later that day to the amendments made by the Senate. When the error was detected on Monday last, it was decided by the government that the bill could not proceed to royal assent.

While I very much regret this error, I believe that the view that the bill cannot proceed is mistaken. In accordance with the usual procedures, the House of Representatives passed a resolution the effect of which is to agree to the amendments made by the Senate in the bill. That resolution did not have the effect of endorsing the erroneous schedule. It is the documentary record of the proceedings which is incorrect, not the proceedings in either House, the effect and intention of which are perfectly clear. To say that the bill now cannot pass because of the error in the schedule is to say that the erroneous record of proceedings prevails over the proceedings themselves. It is not correct, as the government's advisers seem to have concluded, that the Houses have not agreed to the bill in the same form. It is clear that the Houses have agreed to the same bill; it is the documentary record of that process which is inaccurate. The record should be amended to reflect the proceedings, rather than the proceedings altered to reflect the record. I put this view when the error was discovered, but it appears that the government's advisers have decided otherwise, mistakenly in my view.

I should also point out that part of the cause of the error was the sense of urgency which is always placed upon the return of bills to the House of Representatives at the end of a period of sittings. The responsible Senate officers, including me, are constantly told at these times that bills which have been amended must be returned to the House of Representatives as quickly as possible. In this atmosphere it is surprising that more errors are not made, particularly with bills which are the subject of complex proceedings in the Senate. From now on I will be personally checking all bills and schedules of amendments returned to the House of Representatives with great care, and the return of the documents will be delayed for as long as is necessary for this to be done, notwithstanding that the House of Representatives is waiting for the documents. I consider that the system which is in place for the processing of bills and amendments is perfectly sound, and what is required to avoid future errors is greater care on the part of the officers involved and, as I have indicated, less regard for claims of extreme urgency.
With your concurrence I would like to send this report to the Speaker, the Treasurer and the Senators responsible for the carriage of the bill.
I also request that this report be presented to the Senate on the next day of sitting.
(Sgd Harry Evans)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Honourable senators will see what the Clerk of the Senate has said about what occurred at that time. The Clerk said:

SPEECH.PARA: The schedule of amendments made by the Senate to this bill which was forwarded to the House of Representatives on 24 June 1992 contained 4 amendments which were in fact not agreed to by the Senate. These amendments had been circulated by Senator Alston. Although indicated during the proceedings on the bill that he did not intend to move the amendments, somewhat ambiguous references to them, which do not appear in Hansard but which are recorded on the video tape of the proceedings, mislead responsible officers into believing that the amendments had been put and carried.
Well after we had drawn stumps on that day, officers of the Senate were listening to the tape and looking at the video to see what in fact did happen. There was confusion. The Clerk went on to say:
My attention was distracted from the proceedings during part of his—
that is, Senator Alston's—

speech. I subsequently queried whether the amendments had in fact been carried but was assured that they had. This error was not detected by the House of Representatives or by departmental officers monitoring the passage of the bill, and the erroneous schedule of amendments was circulated in the House of Representatives when it agreed later that day to the amendments made by the Senate.
Is not that also a reflection on the Government? What were its advisers doing during that time?

PARA.TAB: The Government, of course, takes the attitude that it will decide whether the amendments will be accepted, and its troops in the Senate just vote accordingly. That is presumably what happened. I will come back to that in a moment when I deal with the question of constitutionality.

It is clear from the letter that every attempt was made to ascertain what in fact had happened. What occurred took place under the pressures of the urgency which was demanded of the Senate and of its officers by the Government. It was the Government that was demanding the urgency of this matter. The Government was demanding that the legislation be sent back to the House of Representatives. The blame for this unreasonable demand can be laid at the door of the Government.
We heard what Senator Reid said. As I heard her, she indicated that some officers were here from Wednesday right through until Friday morning.

TALK.START.PARA: —Forty-three hours.

—They were 43 hours in this place, which is a disgrace. The Government, which is supposed to be a government to protect the rights of the workers, ought to hang its head in shame. I say here and now that I think the Democrats ought to reconsider the idea of agreeing to the Government guillotine, reconsider very seriously the idea of negativing the adjournment and, more importantly, reconsider moving the Macklin amendment.

PARA.TAB: Putting all this aside, the net result of the Macklin amendment is that some legislation which is of great importance to the public is given very little debate through the whole Parliament. It is given virtually none in the House of Representatives. What debate did the Broadcasting Services Bill have in the House of Representatives? The Government had to get that legislation in here by a certain date. It was introduced in this chamber, but it had virtually no debate when it got to the other chamber.

What about other legislation that came from the House of Representatives? I took the opportunity of considering this at the time. For example, one of the health Bills had virtually no debate in the House of Representatives. When I say `no debate', I mean no real debate. Maybe half an hour or an hour was given to it. The matter then came to this chamber.

A number of other Bills like that one were rushed through the House of Representatives in order to meet the deadline so that they could be dumped on the table by the Government. When those Bills got here they were the subject of the guillotine in this chamber, thus denying full debate in the Senate. So there is a farcical situation in this Parliament when debate is denied in the House of Representatives because of the Macklin motion, the Government rushes legislation here, and then denies full debate in the Senate through the guillotine. That is an absolute disgrace.

I appeal to those in the Democrats to reconsider this proposal and to consider very carefully whether they move the Macklin motion again. I will oppose it on the next occasion quite deliberately because I believe that ultimately it is a denial of democracy. That was not the intention of Michael Macklin. His intention was to enable the Senate to have Bills here so that we could properly consider them. But that intention is then negatived by the application of the guillotine here. As I said, the net result of that is that Bills do not get a fair hearing in either the House of Representatives or here.

I again remind the Senate that on that Wednesday there were 161 amendments to legislation before this chamber. Given the time that both we and the officers had to spend in this chamber, is it little wonder that there was confusion.

Senator John Herron has just walked into the chamber. He had something to say about the issue of health as a result of the long hours of sitting. I encourage him to continue on that examination to expose the occupational hazards that occur when we are forced by the Government to sit here for long hours to consider measures deemed as urgent by the Government under the guillotine.

Not only were the Clerks confused but also quite obviously we were confused. If someone was to ask me whether those amendments, which were referred to by Senator Alston, had been passed, I would not be able to say. Senator Alston made reference to them. He, the Opposition and the Government knew that the House of Representatives opposed them and that they therefore should not have been included.

This brings me to the constitutional issue. Is the intention of the Parliament not the real issue? We know that one of the aids used by the judiciary in the interpretation of the law is the intention of Parliament. The letter that I have just incorporated indicates what the Clerk thinks about this issue. It indicates that he sees no reason why a simple correction of the record should not be sufficient. I agree with him in that respect, with the proviso—and he probably had this proviso in mind—that if a member of the House of Representatives had bothered to look at the amendments when they came down at that late stage to the House of Representatives and had indicated that he or she had deliberately voted having read and considered the schedule of amendments that had come back from the Senate, then that simple amendment to the records would not then suffice. Clearly, that would not then reflect the intentions of the Parliament.

No such member of the House of Representatives has come forward and said, `Yes, I read the schedule of amendments that came from the Senate and voted accordingly'. I will guarantee that very few, or any, members read the amendments at all. Some decision was made somewhere around the place by the Government that it would agree with them, and that was it. What was wrong with the Government? Even the Government did not read the amendments. If officers of the Government read them, they would have said to the Government, `No, we will not agree with these four amendments'. Everybody realised the situation. I believe that the proposal put by Mr Evans, the Clerk, is reasonable.

We are now faced with a motion to give retrospective effect to legislation. I will not support it. I am prepared to say, `Let the proposal put by the Clerk proceed'. In other words, let there be an amendment to the record which will reflect the intention of the Parliament, both the Senate and the House of Representatives. The Government would then get its measure in place from 1 July 1992. The Government is now proposing to move this amendment and, I believe, thus virtually reopen the whole issue to challenge.

I ask through you, Mr President, that Senator McMullan table in this chamber the advice that the Government got in respect of this matter, the advice referred to in your statement, Mr President, that the Government was given. I would like the Minister to table that advice so that we can have a look at it. It has not been tabled and it should have been. That is the constitutional question that we are now faced with. I seriously believe that the Government is now opening up that measure to a legal challenge, at least as to the date of operation.

Finally, I come to the Opposition's amendment to the motion. Because I am not supporting the motion, I will not be supporting the amendment, although that does not necessarily follow on all occasions, of course. I notice that the amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Senate:

(a)condemns the Government for its unnecessary and indecent haste in rushing through the Parliament important legislation, which adversely affects the lives of millions of Australians, without allowing time for full and proper debate;. . .
It continues:

(c)records its unequivocal opposition to the Government's compulsory superannuation regime which will severely punish ordinary Australian workers by requiring them to forgo wage increases and rising living standards in order to disqualify themselves from the age pension. . .
I am a bit confused as to what all that means, and therefore I am not in a position to say that I support it.

PARA.TAB: If it means that the Opposition is strongly opposed to the amendment that we made to the Industrial Relations Act, then I would agree, because we will regard the day that we agreed to that amendment as a very, very dark day for workers in this country. I did not agree to it; I voted against it. I think I was the only one in the whole of the Parliament, in both the House of Representatives and the Senate, to vote against that measure. I voted against the amendment to the Industrial Relations Act which required the Industrial Relations Commission to have regard to the amounts paid in superannuation when determining national wage cases. We and the workers of this country will rue the day that we ever passed that proposition. It undermines the integrity of the Industrial Relations Commission and builds into the system a situation where workers will increasingly not be able to form or raise a family on one income.

At some stage I would like to debate the issue raised by Senator Alston and adverted to by Senator Reid. One of the things I am very concerned about is that the women who do the most important job of nurturing and raising Australia's future citizens have been discriminated against. They will continue to be discriminated against, unless something is done in respect of superannuation and there is a recognition of their status and the contribution they make to this nation. We all accept the moral and formative contribution that these women make, but I am also talking about their economic contribution. That debate will be for another time, but I hope it is not too long in coming.

It is time that we in this place took stock of ourselves. Do not let us have a repeat of what happened at the end of last session. It is shameful, a disgrace and a denial of true democracy. It is an intolerable burden not only on ourselves, but particularly on the officers of the Senate, the staff of Hansard and also the other auxiliary staff in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment of my colleague Senator Alston. It highlights the fact that we have a tired Government which is running a tired program and which is unable to be in charge of its own legislative program. Quite frankly, the bottom line is that Mr Dawkins should resign. He was in charge of this legislation, but I am told by those who know the situation well that the Government pushed it off to the Parliamentary Secretary, Senator McMullan, because Dawkins does not understand superannuation.

PARA.TAB: The situation was that the legislation was introduced here and sent down to the House of Representatives. A whole galaxy of highly paid advisers and Ministers collectively failed to pick up that there was an error along the way which would make their legislation ineffective, invalid and unable to pass into law.

In the Senate this afternoon we have seen Senator Evans as a man who does not want to be responsible for what happens in his department. He has shown that to be the case in this chamber on three occasions, with Burke, the Marshall Islands and now the Richard Butler affair. But now over in the House of Representatives we have the man who calls himself the Treasurer, pays himself as the Treasurer, and yet who is unable to see his own legislation correctly passed into law.

Clearly, as my other colleagues have pointed out, no blame attaches to the Clerks. The hours that they work and what is required of them have been amply described, particularly by Senator Reid and Senator Harradine. What does deserve to be reiterated is that the Democrats were part and parcel of this farce. They agreed to the guillotine and did a deal with the Government. In that way an outrageous number of Bills were pushed through this place in a ridiculously short period of time when this place is charged with the review and oversight of so many Bills. On this occasion the Democrats deserve to be culpable too.

On this side Opposition members argued very logically and meaningfully that the imposition of this compulsory superannuation tax is a de facto federal payroll tax. Indeed, we said that many, many people would lose their jobs. `Oh, no', said the Government. `Oh, no', agreed the Democrats. One could not help wondering if they said in parenthesis, `And too bad if they do'. On the Saturday after that legislation appeared to pass through the Parliament, I attended a function. I was talking to somebody I know reasonably well who is a small business man and I asked, `How are things?' He said, `Dreadful'. I said, `What is the matter?' He said, `Well, because of the recession that has been foisted upon us, I have just been holding the line. But now that this compulsory superannuation payment has gone through, yesterday I had to sack a part time employee and turn a full time employee into a part time employee'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It had no effect on that person!

—That is exactly what I would expect from a former trade union official who we are never sure speaks for the trade union movement or in his capacity as a Minister. He has no compassion for this man who said, `I know what effect this had on their families'.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. That is an unnecessary and dubious reflection on me. There is no doubt that I have sworn an oath of office to uphold the obligation of a Minister of the Crown and to suggest that I am dictated to or work to some other agenda is offensive. It would be held to be a libel in a normal civil court. In this place it should not be the type of conduct engaged in and I ask, Mr President, that you rule, if Senator Bishop is not of her own volition prepared to withdraw the slur, that the offensive remarks be withdrawn.
—I really think that a personal explanation should have been made, and I take it that you did that, Senator Cook, because I did not hear anything unparliamentary said.

—Since you concluded your remarks with a question mark, Mr President, the part that is unparliamentary in my view is that I do not act according to the oath of my office as a Minister of the Crown. I think that is an unnecessary and unfair reflection upon me. There is no substance for it, but we have become acclimatised, I suppose, to that sort of behaviour being engaged in. It is unfortunate if that behaviour is engaged in, but there is no reason why it should be tolerated and I think the reflection should be withdrawn.
—I listened carefully and I think it was a debating point. Whether it is in good taste or not is up to the person it was a reflection on and I think that really deserves a personal explanation.

—I find it utterly amazing that Senator Cook finds it libellous to call him a member of the trade union movement. There are other people who may, and if I might say further it took us several hours in the last session to get Senator Cook to admit that he was a paid-up member of the BWIU.
—That is also untrue.
—Senator Cook should check the Hansard.
—Order! I think we should return to the debate.

—I will come back later with the correct page of the Hansard so that people can check for themselves. It took several hours for him to admit it to us, but if he is ashamed of being a member of the trade union, that is his affair. We all know that the ALP is the political wing of the trade union movement.
