I was talking about a real hardworking Australian small businessman who was recounting to me the fact that he had had to sack a part time employee and cause a full time employee to become a part time employee because of the compulsory superannuation payment which, if he had had to pay it, would have made him go under. He knows only too well that if he takes on debts he cannot pay when they fall due he is in breach of the law and would make himself liable. That is the effect of that legislation on ordinary struggling Australians.

PARA.TAB: The Government has no care or compassion for those people. If the Government did care, it would accept Senator Reid's invitation today not to pass into law the mess of this legislation and to take the opportunity to withdraw it and give struggling small business in particular an even break.

I would say the same to the Democrats because they are complicitous in this; they are part and parcel of it. We heard early noises from the Democrats when they said, `Oh, no, we are concerned about those people who are going to lose their jobs'. Of course, some sort of deal was then done and they went along with it. We have an opportunity—they have an opportunity just as the Government has—to relieve struggling Australian business men and women of this intolerable burden.

I was listening to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator McMullan, who is not even here—it is his legislation that has got messed up; he has a problem there and he does not even bother to stick around for the debate—in a discussion on the radio the other day with Senator Alston. I heard Senator McMullan say, `The difference between our systems on superannuation is that ours is compulsory and theirs is voluntary'. That is very true. That is an essential difference. Our policy is designed to make it attractive for people to provide for themselves in later life whereas this Government's is designed to penalise business, to regulate it out of existence. The whole of the Fightback package is designed to free it up, to take the burden and the impost of taxation on business off so they can employ more, so there can be more productivity and not the ludicrous concept of productivity that is served by the so-called accord.

The constitutional question has been canvassed and very eloquently dealt with by Senator Alston. The real question is that if we follow the route the Government is following today, simply because it is fearful of recommitting the Bill for a vote, the Government might lose the Democrats or the Democrats might do something which is unpredictable. It is frightened to death of recommitting the matter. If the Government did, it would put the matter beyond doubt. However, it is prepared to go this route, which means that the legislation may be subsequently held to be invalid and that the period from 1 July 1992 to today will be, to put it mildly, despite the protestations of Senator McMullan earlier, a deep grey area.

I find the Government's harsh and intolerable attitude to small business and individual families appalling. It does not care a damn what happens to those people who lose their jobs. There are around 40,000 to 70,000 people who could be affected. People will go towards Christmas without having a job; kids will not be enjoying the Christmas they have been used to. But all of this is irrelevant because we are on an ideological kick here. The Government says, `We must have compulsory superannuation', which will have the effect of a compulsory tax.

In conclusion, I simply say both to the Democrats and the Government that if they take heed of the words of Senator Alston's amendment they will see that they have erred; that the Government was unable to be in charge of its own legislation, with its highly paid galaxy of advisers, and unable to pick it up; and that the way the Government's legislative program is run is just about as good as the way it runs the economy—both downhill and into the ground. I would say to them: here is an opportunity. Why do you not take it and give Australia a break?

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the remarks of my colleagues and Senator Harradine on this particular issue. Senator Bishop concluded her remarks by addressing the nature of the legislative program that the Government had put before this chamber. I want to concentrate particularly on that matter. Given the enormous burden the Government imposed on this chamber between 16 and 25 June when some 61 Bills were declared urgent and forced through this chamber, I suspect the issue is that it is probably not surprising that only one mistake was made. I suspect the real surprise is that not more mistakes were made.

PARA.TAB: I have had the Senate Table Office pull out some figures to see how we can perhaps measure the performance of this Government in relation to the management of its legislative program by comparing it with other governments. At the end of my remarks I propose to seek leave to incorporate this table in Hansard. I have cleared the incorporation of the table with Senator McMullan, who unfortunately is not in the chamber. This table shows that in fact the record of this Government in managing the legislative program is absolutely appalling. On no other occasion since 1970, for example, has any government attempted to put so many Bills through the Parliament, having declared them urgent.

It is interesting to note that between 1970 and 1972, the period of the McMahon Government, two Bills were declared urgent. In the seven years of the Fraser Government, some 57 Bills in all were declared urgent. Contrast those 57 Bills over the seven years of the Fraser Government with the 61 Bills which this Government forced through in one session.

A fair assessment of the table which I will be seeking leave to incorporate in Hansard will show that the management of the Government's program has been particularly bad. It will also show, regrettably, that that management seems to be getting progressively worse. Senator Harradine was quite correct in drawing our attention to the heavy responsibility that the Democrats must take in this. It would be impossible for the Government to pass a motion to declare its Bills urgent and to guillotine these Bills through the Senate, but for the agreement of the Australian Democrats who are prepared to support the Government in its motions to declare Bills urgent. That is a great pity—a number of my colleagues have drawn attention to this—and I want to draw out a couple of the reasons why I think it is a pity.

The Macklin motion, which was designed to encourage the Senate to more carefully review the legislation coming from the House of Representatives, is completely negated by the willingness of the Australian Democrats to agree to pass a motion to declare Bills urgent. The next time that Senator Coulter is asked to act with the Government on such a motion, I urge him to look very carefully at the table which I will be seeking to incorporate in Hansard which shows the progressive decline in the capacity of the Government to manage its program.

I suspect there is something more insidious, however, in the sense that some public servants have come to the very sensible conclusion that, if they can hold Bills back until the last weeks of the session, those Bills can be rushed through the Parliament without any proper debate. It is well worth Senator McMullan and his colleagues looking very carefully at just what their departments are doing. Whereas I may deplore the fact that public servants may be acting in this manner, given the stresses and strains also placed on them, from some perspective at least, they may be regarded as acting in a rational manner in trying to get their Bills through the Parliament with the least possible fuss.

Although I do not believe Senator Coulter has collectively conspired to achieve this goal, the Democrats continuing support, regardless, for the motion by the Government to declare Bills urgent does have this effect. I would ask Senator Coulter to carefully consider that matter the next time the Government seeks his support for such a motion. It is quite clear that, at least in some departments, Bills are being held back because departments know they can be rushed through the House of Representatives, where the Government has the numbers, and they can also be rushed through the Senate. I think that is a great pity. Also, the Ministers of the Government understand that if they can hold Bills back they can, regrettably, rely on the support of the Australian Democrats to agree to an urgency motion so that the Bills can be rushed through the Parliament without proper debate.

Very real issues indeed have been raised by the amendment that my colleague Senator Alston has proposed. They are matters that would not have occurred had the Government not rushed the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992 through the Parliament. We can understand the Government wanting to rush its Bills through the Parliament; I suspect that what many people on this side of the chamber cannot understand is the willingness of the Australian Democrats to agree with the Government to rush this Bill through the Parliament.

I urge Senator Coulter to look very carefully at the table I will be seeking to incorporate in the Hansard. I urge him to consider that his willingness to give a blank cheque to the Government is not serving the Australian community well. It is certainly not serving this chamber well, and I suspect it is not serving the mandate which I think Senator Coulter has defined for his own Party—to make sure that legislation is properly considered in this place. With those few remarks, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which shows the number of Bills which were declared urgent between 1970 and 1992, which has been prepared by the Senate Table Office.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that any other person is rising to attract the call in this debate, therefore, it is appropriate that, on behalf of the Government, some remarks be made in response.

PARA.TAB: In my understanding, during the contribution to this debate by Senator Harradine, a reference was made to an opinion obtained by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) on the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992 and whether that opinion could be made available to the Parliament. I have here a document bearing the title, `In The Matter of Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992', headed, `Opinion' and signed by the Solicitor-General, Mr Gavin Griffith, dated last Thursday, 13 August 1992, which poses a number of questions, deals with a consideration of those questions and, accordingly, answers them. I believe this to be the document referred to by Senator Harradine. I now seek leave of the Senate to have this document incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: IN THE MATTER OF SUPERANNUATION GUARANTEE (ADMINISTRATION) BILL 1992
OPINION

After passage through the House of Representatives the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992 ("the Bill") was amended in the Senate. Due to clerical error (in its root sense of meaning error by a clerk) the signed Schedule of Amendments ("Schedule") annexed to Message 491 24 June 1992 from the President of the Senate to the Speaker included some purported amendments which had not been passed in the Senate. The error was not exposed until after the House of Representatives had agreed to all the purported amendments in the Schedule before assent.

The President has not yet sent a message to the Speaker to correct the error of Message 491. I am instructed that the Clerk of the Senate has expressed a personal view that whilst the error could have been corrected administratively before 1 July without further reference to either House, rectification now requires resolution by the Senate. This is because the commencement Clause 2 reads "This Act commences on 1 July 1992", a date now passed. The suggestion is that the Bill has therefore become a Bill for retrospective legislation, and effectively a new Bill, if brought into force in the form.
I am asked—

PARA.TAB: (1) Is there any legal impediment to the President now transmitting the correct schedule to the House without reference to the Senate?
(2) May the Bill be passed by the House of Representatives with the same amendments passed by the Senate, and then presented for assent under section 58 of the Constitution?
(3) Would such enactment have effect from 1 July 1992?
(4) Was the Clerk correct in his view that the error could have been corrected administratively before 1 July?

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Chapter 20 of the Senate Standing Orders regulates the passage of Bills through the Senate. Under S.O. 131, a Bill which has originated in the House of Representatives and been passed by the Senate with amendments is returned to the House by message from the President with the amendments set out in a schedule certified by the Clerk. However, S.O. 131 prescribes only a parliamentary procedure. It does not reflect any constitutional requirement to pass a law (cf. procedures under section 57 of the Constitution in respect of the enactment of legislation at a joint sitting). The correction or non-correction of Message 491 by further message from the President will not affect the efficacy of the completed passage of the Bill through the Senate. Constitutionally it is not a necessary pre-condition to the House reconsidering the Bill amended by the Senate that the schedule of amendments passed by the Senate be correctly, or even at all, transmitted with message under S.O. 131 from the President to the Speaker. What is required is that the proposed law be passed in the same terms in each House.

2.Where, as here, a Bill originates in the House and is passed by the Senate, the courts will not ordinarily enquire whether the internal procedures of Parliament have been complied with. The High Court has expressed the view that it is for each House to determine whether a law has been passed by each House according to its procedures, and the assent is taken as indicating that the Bill has been passed by each House: see Victoria v. Commonwealth and Connor (PMA Case) (1975) 134 CLR 81, 181 Mason J. At 164, Gibbs J said the courts are not concerned with enforcement of Standing Orders of the two Houses.

3.Although there must be limits to the extent to which the High Court will foreclose consideration of parliamentary processes in constitutional litigation, it is unnecessary to consider issues of judicial review in resolving this matter of parliamentary process. Obviously, each House must rely upon the other to comply with its procedures, and it cannot be a proper working of the relationship for material formally communicated by one to the other to remain uncorrected after error is detected. Message 491 should have been formally corrected by a further message from the President to the Speaker as soon as the mistake was exposed, and no authority from the Senate was required before or after 1 July. The fact that a law proclaimed in the form passed by the Senate after 1 July will contain a commencement date in incorrect tense is irrelevant.

4.Section 58 of the Constitution allows the Governor-General to assent to a proposed law only after it has been "passed by both Houses of the Parliament". The constitutional requirement is that the substantive text be passed in each House. Here different amendments have been passed. Section 58 has not been complied with. It follows that no present version of the proposed law may be presented for assent. There is no scope for a text to be finalised by administrative action to express the supposed will of the Parliament. As the proposed law has not been passed by both Houses it cannot be presented for assent, either in the form passed in the Senate or with the purported amendments agreed to by the House of Representatives.

5.The mechanism to ensure passing of the Bill in compliance with constitutional requirements is a separate issue from correction of the President's advice to the Speaker. The House of Representatives may now agree to the amendments as they were in fact passed by the Senate. It then should send a new message under its Standing Order 247 explaining that its earlier message under that Standing Order was ineffective insofar as it said that the House had agreed to the amendments that were not in fact made by the Senate and stating that it has now agreed to all the amendments made by the Senate. Then the same proposed law will have been agreed to, and so "passed" by both Houses. In that form, the Bill may be presented for assent under section 58. This can be done even if no correcting message is sent by the President of the Senate to the Speaker. No further consideration by the Senate is required. Nonetheless, as a matter of practice between the Houses, it is appropriate for the President to correct message 491 before the House of Representatives considers and agrees to the correct schedule of amendments.

6.Upon assent, the commencement date is a matter of construction: see Worrall v. Commercial Banking Co of Sydney Ltd (1917) 24 CLR 28. The infelicity in the tense of clause 2 will be explained by legislative history. For the avoidance of doubt, this intention for retrospective operation could be expounded and explained in the Minister's speech when the correct amendments are agreed on the further consideration of the Bill in the House of Representatives. In the peculiar circumstances of the passage of this law, a court should find that the Act does have retrospective operation back to the originally intended prospective date of 1 July 1992. This may, in turn, give rise to some other arguments as to whether the purported retrospective operation of the Act back to 1 July is valid, but those arguments could arise even if Clause 2 was amended directly to provide for retrospective operation.
Accordingly, the questions are answered as follows—
1.No. The mistake in message number 491 should have been corrected as soon as it was detected.
2.Yes.
3.The Act should be held to have effect from 1 July 1992.
4.No.
SOLICITOR-GENERAL
13 August 1992

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion before the chamber can be best described as a motion to correct a technical defect that arose in the transmission of advice from this chamber to the House of Representatives. There is no argument, it seems, that what was determined by this chamber and what was later transmitted to the House of Representatives for its deliberation was different and a mistake was made. This debate is about a motion moved by the Government to enable that mistake to be corrected, and corrected in a way in which the appropriate respect for the Standing Orders and the procedures of the Parliament is given.

PARA.TAB: What has occurred in this debate, certainly during the time of my presence on duty in this chamber, has been an effort—under the guise of an amendment to the motion proposed by the Government—to do a couple of things. The first is to redebate the issue in chief—to recanvass the merit of the original legislation, a matter that was debated and determined previously. That has resulted in a number of honourable senators in this place arguing matters that we are familiar with. They argued them before; we hear them again. None of their opinions are surprising. They were not persuasive when they were originally put and they ought not be persuasive now. But in any case, those opinions are beside the point of the matter which is before us.

I say to Senator Bishop that it is quite extraordinary to hold up as proof—in her terms—that this legislation has a deleterious economic effect, that the day after the Senate passed it, a small business person approached her and said, `As a consequence of the passage of this legislation, people have to be laid off'. The Bill had not been proclaimed, no effect was felt by anybody, but by a vote of the Senate there was this conjunction of events. That is a preposterous argument. It is one that defies logic. It cannot be sustained. I only mention it here as an example of the argument being put when merit has been canvassed.

The second category of debate that has occurred has been, in essence, to accuse the Government of poor management of the Parliament and to hold the Government responsible for the mistake that was made. The sub-arguments under this heading are that the Government had offended particularly by having a number of Bills, by majority vote in this chamber, declared urgent and then dealt with at the end of the last session, and that the Government has put forward too many Bills.

Again, when the motion that these Bills be declared urgent was moved, a debate was had in this chamber about the merits of that motion. The question was determined by a majority vote of the chamber, yet we see in this debate a number of the arguments put then being canvassed again. They were canvassed by Senator Kemp, who was the last speaker here and who has just left the chamber. Moreover, this is done in a self-righteous way as if the matter had not been determined, almost in a way which reflects on a vote of the Senate, and in a way that suggests that all innocence resides with the minority party that lost the vote.

I think that it is fair to say that what persuaded this chamber when that vote came before it was the fact that there were a lot of Bills and that the proceedings of this chamber had slowed to a walk. The passage of Bills was delayed. I think that it would also be fair to say that any independent person watching these developments could conclude that a filibuster was under way and that a deliberate slowing of the proceedings was engaged in by talking through everything so that the Government would not get its Bills through, as an Opposition tactic. That debate was held and determined. Whatever were the issues, at least those explanations should be made in view of the re-canvassing of those views.

It is odd to allege that a government is too active, that we put too many Bills forward. We make no apology for being an activist government. But one of the honourable senators in this debate has accused us of having too many Bills. It is true—and I confess that we do work hard—that we have significant change to preside over, but we make no apology for doing those things, and, if the accusation is that we have been working excessively hard, I guess that we as a government stand accused of that and accept the responsibility. But we do not accept responsibility for working sloppily. Working hard and working sloppily are two different things.

In this debate there have also been two sub-debates. One is that the Australian Democrats are culpable. That is really ridiculous. It does not require answer and I do not propose to answer it now. The other debate is that Secretary McMullan and Minister Dawkins are somehow responsible for all of this. I am not going to get into the business of who is responsible or who is to blame; that is not a constructive debate. All of the people responsible have worked hard, under significant pressure, and they are all professionals who deserve the position to which they have been appointed or elected.

But life is not without error and to presume that no-one makes a mistake, no matter how professional, thorough or diligent individuals might be—whether they be appointed or elected—is, of course, to support a fallacy. We all make mistakes. And when we do, the most sensible thing is to remedy it in a professional manner. I do not want to get into the business of who is to blame. It is a useless debate and, in the end, it is an irresponsible debate, too. I do not want there to be any lingering doubt that the Government has some sort of concern about that. Errors do occur and the mark of responsibility is their being corrected properly and quickly. That is why this debate is on now, at the beginning of this session, straight after Question Time and the normal procedures introducing the session.

That brings me to the amendment that has been moved. I think there is little support for it, and so there should be. As I have said, it canvasses the issues again. I want to commend the motion that my colleague Senator McMullan, the Parliamentary Secretary, has put before this chamber. When all of the debate on superannuation in this country is over and when a bit of daylight has been shed on the passage of this legislation, its application and its effect in the community, I think certain conclusions will be revealed as truths. Firstly, superannuation, prior to the advent of our submissions in support of it before the Industrial Relations Commission and our legislative prescription, was something that went to white-collar workers but traditionally not to blue-collar workers, was something that went to people in public employment but not to people in private employment by and large, and was something that went to better paid employees but not to middle and low income employees. Superannuation will now be available to all people. That is a significant social justice measure.

Superannuation payment for all employees, rather than only for those who have a discretionary income enabling them to invest in it or those in some privileged position of employment, is a social right. It is a right in social justice that this Government stands for, and it is in stark contrast to the view of the Opposition: let the measure fall where it may. We think that everyone is entitled to it. It also means that people can retire with superannuation and with dignity, so that they are not just recipients of retirement pensions; they can retire on a better level of income. That is an appropriate measure.

The second thing that can be said is that, if one looks at the ageing of the Australian community, it can be seen that the post-war baby boomers start to become retirees early next century. The ratio of wage and salary earners paying income tax to the number of people in retirement dramatically collapses so that fewer taxpayers support more retirees. The burden of taxation then has to be confronted: does the level of taxation increase to keep the benefits up or does the level of benefits come down? Every prudent government in the world has faced this fact and made provision before the event so that there will not be a problem in terms of meeting what is clearly a cost in the future and has determined that the cost burden must be shared in some way. I think that is a reasonable thing. As I say, all prudent governments in the world have confronted it. It is a big change in the Australian community and it is appropriate now. I think that, when people look back on this, they will see that that was a fair and reasonable measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, you have fewer dependent children.
—That may be so.
—That is so.
—We have fewer dependent children so the population ratio collapses even more.
—The dependency ratio will actually be less.
—I think that goes to support my argument.
—No, the other way around.

—Perhaps we should have that as a side argument. The third thing that I think will be established by the passage of this legislation is that superannuation which is accumulated into funds as aggregate savings will add to the volume of savings in the economy. The rapid take-up of superannuation will mean a direct explosion in the level of savings in the economy. Further, since those funds will be administered by trustees with an obligation to the contributors, I believe that it will also mean a huge pool of potential investment in Australian industry that is Australian owned.

PARA.TAB: While I believe that we ought to encourage foreign investment in this economy, quite clearly, the more Australian ownership and penetration there is of foreign ownership in this economy the better. One of the reasons why there has been less investment, despite the improved profit share going to business as a factor share, is that there has been a tendency—up until 1987, at least—for business to engage in speculative gain rather than real wealth generation. So the profit share has been dissipated in share market trading, artificial increases in share prices, takeovers and so on—and not directed to wealth creation. This legislation will establish a pool of investment funds open to Australian industry.

Those three arguments, despite the difference it seems that I have with the distinguished Leader of the Australian Democrats in regard to one of the arguments, should be enough to defeat this amendment and establish it for what it is—a politically opportunist amendment to a technical motion rectifying a fault, an amendment which seeks to use the expediency of this motion to make what are, in the event, some fairly trite legal points. It is an amendment worthy of defeat and not of support. I commend to the chamber the motion moved by my colleague Senator McMullan.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I have spoken in the debate. During the course of my remarks I canvassed the question of whether the Government had sought or obtained any legal advice. I am grateful to have had the opportunity to see the advice incorporated in Hansard by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook). I wonder whether, with leave, I might canvass one element of that in relation to retrospectivity.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the chamber. The advice of the Solicitor-General, Dr Griffith, in relation to this matter is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: For the avoidance of doubt, this intention for retrospective operation could be expounded and explained in the Minister's speech when the correct amendments are agreed on the further consideration of the Bill in the House of Representatives. In the peculiar circumstances of the passage of this law, a court should find that the Act does have retrospective operation back to the originally intended prospective date of 1 July 1992. This may, in turn, give rise to some other arguments as to whether the purported retrospective operation of the Act back to 1 July is valid, but those arguments could arise even if Clause 2 was amended directly to provide for retrospective operation.
Accordingly, he answers the question `Would such enactment have effect from 1 July 1992?' by saying:
The Act should be held to have effect from that date.

It seems to me that that advice is couched in very careful and uncertain terms. What he is really saying is that, hopefully, it will be held to have effect from 1 July. But it is also very clear, reading between the lines, that he would recommend, if asked, that the normal procedure be followed, and that is that you expressly provide in the Bill that it shall have retrospective effect. I therefore ask whether the Government is prepared to obtain further legal advice on this point; otherwise, as I did say to Senator McMullan, there is a very real prospect that there will be employer groups and others who may wish to challenge the legislation.

PARA.TAB: I am sure that the last thing the Government wants is to find that ultimately the intention was not sufficiently explained in the Bill, which is where it would firstly need to be explained. To avoid all of that, the matter should be clarified at this stage. So I ask Senator Cook whether he is prepared to obtain advice that is in much clearer and more definite terms than that provided by the Solicitor-General.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The short answer to that question put to me by Senator Alston is no. I thank Senator Alston for being concerned, on the Government's behalf, about whether this legislation will survive an appeal if an action is taken against it. I appreciate the worry that Senator Alston has that the legislation that he has opposed may not survive that. He feels that we should take his advice as to his reading of the Solicitor-General's opinion and further seek advice on that point, but I do not think it is necessary. The Government is of the view that the advice that is now in the record supports its approach to this matter. I notice that Senator Alston has interpreted that by using phrases like `if you read between the lines' or `it appears that it is obvious that'—which suggest that Senator Alston is engaging in a subjective interpretation of what he thinks that advice means.
—He says `could' or `should'. That is what I was pointing to.
—Yes, but Senator Alston also said, `If you read between the lines'.
—Yes, obviously, I went on to make another point.

—I do not think the advice offered by a distinguished jurist like the Solicitor-General can be subjected to that type of interpretation—`if you read between the lines'. The Solicitor-General is, after all, the senior law officer of the Commonwealth, handing advice to the Government. He is competent in plain English and expresses his view forthrightly. So I do not take the view that there is somehow a question here that might be engaged in if one were a student of English literature: what is the hidden meaning? One ought to take the plain advice and the plain language and accept the plain word, which is what we do. For that reason, I do not wish on behalf of the Government to accept the offer made on the basis of Senator Alston's concern that we get our legislation right.

—by leave—I wish to make a personal explanation. With great self-discipline, I shall not comment on the matters the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) raised in his speech. However, I heard him suggest that the Opposition had been filibustering and that that had something to do with why the program ran as late as it did. I personally regard that as a gross reflection. That was not the case. It was never suggested at a Whips' meeting that we were filibustering. If the Minister looks at the record of the last session, he will find that there were many days when we did not bring on matters of public importance because we recognised the program that we were faced with. There were some days after Question Time when we took notice of answers, but we did not take up the same amount of time we would have taken had we put down a matter of public importance.

PARA.TAB: It was unfortunate to bring that allegation into a debate in which there were serious matters to discuss. That was not one of the issues that was relevant. As Whip, I view it as a serious matter to suggest that my Party is filibustering and I am sorry that the Minister made that allegation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not make an allegation. I think I said that an impartial observer watching those proceedings could have been of that opinion.

That the amendment (Senator Alston's) be agreed to:

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the hours of meeting of the Senate this day shall be 2 p.m. till 6 p.m. and 7.30 p.m. till 10.30 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —An incident at Parliament House on 12 August 1992, in which a four-wheel drive vehicle was driven through the main entrance of the building, has received a great deal of media attention.

PARA.TAB: As honourable senators may be aware a number of agencies are involved in providing security in the parliamentary precincts. The Speaker and I decided that an expert who was not attached to any of these agencies was required to provide an objective assessment of the incident and the Parliament's capacity to respond. We commissioned Mr Richard Dixon of the security division of Price Waterhouse Urwick to examine the incident and make an immediate interim report to us on the appropriate means to prevent a recurrence of such incidents. Mr Dixon, who is a retired commander of the Australian Federal Police, presented his report yesterday. A copy of the report has been made available to the party leaders and the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) on a confidential basis.

The report finds that the actions of security staff in detaining the driver of the vehicle and evacuating the public from the building were proper and effective. The driver has appeared before the ACT Magistrates Court on four charges relating to the incident and has been remanded in custody pending the receipt of a psychiatric report.
Mr Dixon's report contains recommendations for the installation of temporary barriers at the entrances to the building. As honourable senators will be aware, the barriers are now in place.

There will not be any over-reaction to the incident. The measures the Speaker and I have put in place will not inhibit in any way the public's access to Parliament House. We have been careful to ensure that the balance between open access and effective security is maintained.

The report makes other recommendations in relation to the installation of more permanent barriers, the strengthening of building entrances, the management of security, the powers of attendants and emergency evacuation procedures. The Speaker and I are considering these recommendations at the moment.

In the light of the report, the Speaker and I propose to commission a wider review of the protective security of Parliament House which will include an examination of the risks to the building and its occupants, and the effectiveness of current arrangements in protecting against those risks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: We live in a peaceful and law abiding country. It is often very difficult to recognise the risks that we face from irrational or extreme lawlessness in this country. Looking at our history in the immediate past, we have seen diplomatic staff assassinated, very ugly incidents this year at one of the embassies in Canberra and, going back a bit further, the Hilton Hotel bombing of over a decade ago. It is an act of prudence that you, Mr President, have followed on this occasion to review the security procedures at Parliament House.

PARA.TAB: Within this new Parliament House we have had people in the other place leaping off the balconies onto the floor area of the chamber. Recently we had this quite dramatic incident where someone drove a vehicle through the front through closed doors into the building itself. It is not being too dramatic to imagine that it could have been a terrorist group which could have driven two small vehicles into this place loaded with 500 pounds or half a tonne of high explosive. Had they chosen to do that to make a statement about the Parliament of Australia, they could have driven in through that front door, through the central hallway, through the doors into both chambers simultaneously at Question Time, detonated the load and removed all the senators and all the members in one fell swoop from Australia. Technically, that is not an impossible scenario.

While the possibility of that happening is very remote, it is prudent that you, Mr President, do make an assessment as to what security procedures are in place here. As a member of the New Parliament House Construction Committee for many years, I am aware that security procedures in this building were a matter of some debate, and changes were made with respect to the old Parliament House.

I have to say that for quite some while I have not been satisfied with the security procedures in this building. In a general sense everyone coming into this building, other than a senator or member, has to have an identification card. There are two types of cards that are worn on the lapel: one that requires the visitor to be accompanied at all times and thereby restricted to certain public areas if he or she is not accompanied, and the other a general card. That might be the theory of it, but in practice there are often people walking around the offices of this building in areas where they should not be without any identifying card on them at all.

I happen to work in this building on many occasions after the Senate has risen. I could not count the number of times I have been in my office and, without any knock on the door, total strangers have burst in and said, `Oh, you are there' and then disappeared into the middle of the night. I have no idea who those people are—whether they are security people or people just having a look at what goes on in the building. But that is a very lax procedure in my judgment.

I am also concerned about the non-sitting periods. We do have body-scan X-rays, metal detectors, that people entering the building are supposed to walk through and the same X-ray scanning machines that the Federal Airports Corporation has for hand baggage at all the airports. But it has been my observation that in the non-sitting periods those X-ray screening devices are not used and people come into the building carrying bags and they are never examined.

It would be quite possible for someone to come in with a nefarious intent and to deposit any sort of device within the building on a non-sitting day, timed to detonate or combust days or weeks later. We do not seem to have any defence against that at all. The other element of security is that of theft. People could be taking things out of the building because there does not seem to be any exit check on people leaving the building, particularly in the non-sitting weeks. So I would hope that we have a thorough and objective review of the systems that are in place, Mr President.

A further point of concern is that the Commonwealth Government does have some very well advised or well trained professional people. For example, we have them in ASIO, in the Federal Police and, I would have thought, in the Protective Services. I am interested in why we went to Price Waterhouse or to a group outside the Commonwealth for this advice. I should have thought there was enough advice available within Commonwealth agencies to provide you, Mr President, with the level of expertise and guidance that you needed on this issue, and probably at far less cost to the Parliament than going to a private consultant. Having had some experience of some of the agencies of the Commonwealth, I do not really believe that in this area there are private contractors who can match the resources that the Commonwealth has.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, this question of security is one that I have raised with you and others in Estimates committees over a number of years. I have raised and highlighted examples of where the security has been, quite frankly, inadequate. This was particularly so during the Gulf war, when it came to our attention that it was quite open for anyone to go into the garages under Parliament House where bombs could have been placed. There have been other examples of theft where thousands upon thousands of dollars worth of merchandise have simply walked out of this building. On all occasions, we simply got the answer that, really, our security is quite adequate.

PARA.TAB: I suppose one of the things that made me crosser than most was the party that the now Prime Minister (Mr Keating), then Treasurer, held in the private dining-room, where a Fred Williams painting was greatly harmed by the throwing of food and drink. When I insisted on getting a report from security officers, all they could manage to do was interview 12 people. They could find no culprit. Surprise, surprise, no action was ever taken and, if my memory serves me correctly, it was the Department of the Treasury that paid the bill for the restoration work that took place on the painting and not the then Treasurer, now Prime Minister, himself.

Mr President, I echo the remarks of Senator MacGibbon when he says that he does not understand why you had to go to an outside consultant when we have access to the Protective Service which, as I understand it, is a sort of unlabelled version of the Federal Police. We pay a very heavy cost for the alleged security in this building and I can only say that, on the sorts of questions that I have asked you, Mr President, in Estimates prior to this time, I am really not surprised that we finally had a crisis.

I would like to know the truth or otherwise of the anecdotal story that the man driving the vehicle actually stalled between the two sets of doors and nobody was able to get him out of that vehicle at that time. I would like to know whether that is true or otherwise. Again, Mr President, when we come to the Estimates, I can say to you now we will be looking very much at whether we get value for money with the way the security is presently run.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have just a couple of points as well on security in Parliament House. May I ask you how on earth any vehicle got from the front road to the front doors, in the first instance, without some security measure coming into place? What is happening with perimeter security? I always thought that there was some form of perimeter security to stop such a thing; that only formal cars for formal functions would be able to get up to that location.

PARA.TAB: It was noted by a lady who came into this building at about one o'clock yesterday afternoon with photographic ID—there was no great problem with that—that there was no-one on duty at the side Senate door, and she was able to just waltz straight through the side Senate door without any check or verification. Given the events of last week, I think it is rather sad that something like that should happen less than one week later.

I also ask you what is the status of the new planter boxes—I suppose you would call them—at the side Senate door? They look like outsize coffins. I presume they have been put there for some security purpose. I wonder whether, in fact, that has been approved by such people as the Fire Department. It has always been a source of fascination to me that, given those two very narrow doors on the Senate side, in the event of this building catching fire and there being a stampede of people trying to leave, they would almost have to get into single file to exit in a most orderly fashion while their tails are burning. Mr President, I ask you whether that has been checked from a fire point of view.

Also—not that I wish you to publicly disclose any further measures as to the sensitive nature of the security—are any other obstacles going to be built just for the purpose of stopping cars coming in when, in fact, it is quite clear that someone could have just walked up to the front door the other day and thrown something in, and that not necessarily being from a car?

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to some of the issues that have been raised, as far as Senator MacGibbon is concerned, as a member of the New and Permanent Parliament House Committee—and he knows that I was on it too—he would realise that previous governments downgraded security on the grounds of costs at various times when the issues were brought before the Committee.

PARA.TAB: The issue of identification cards is being addressed at the moment. I would like to point out that the rules on sitting days are the same as for non-sitting days, as far as coming into the building is concerned. That is what I have been advised.

At least two senators raised the fact that we have the APS, the AFP, ASIO and other organisations carrying out security in this building. That is the very reason why the Speaker and I wanted somebody who was not associated with any of the agencies that give us advice on security in this building to do the first report for us—somebody who was at arm's length from the different agencies that give us advice at the moment. The advice that has been given to us is certainly on a temporary basis. It was a rush job, but something had to be done immediately.

The planter boxes which are there were part of that report. There was a genuine concern about some sort of copycat attitude in that somebody might try to do the same thing. The advice was that that was the best thing that could be done on a temporary basis, and those planter boxes will not be there on a permanent basis. However, there is no doubt that the Speaker and I have to ensure that that sort of event does not happen again. As I have said, this is simply temporary, but we will look at a full ranging report on what we can do on a permanent basis to make sure that that type of incident does not happen again.

Senator Bishop and, I think, Senator Knowles asked some questions that I am not able to give answers to at the moment. It is not that I do not want to, but I am not about to point out some of the deficiencies in the system that have been pointed out to us already. As a result of that, the confidential report that has been given to the Presiding Officers has also been given to the party leaders and the relevant Ministers and, hopefully, at some time in the future, we will be able to give more details. I can assure you, Senator Bishop, that during the Estimates committees you will be able to follow that line of questioning.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, there was one question from Senator MacGibbon that you failed to answer. I was going to rise on that issue but, because Senator MacGibbon voiced his concern, I did not. It concerns the check of people coming in and going out through the security walk-through and the area where baggage is to be looked at. Could you explain to us why that does not occur?

—I will get you an answer to that. The situation, as I understand it, is that people trying to come into this building who are not members and senators, whether it is a sitting day or not, have to go through those procedures.
—No, they don't.
—It is something that I will get you an answer to as quickly as possible.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Archer (from 21 citizens), Senator Michael Baume (from 27 citizens), Senator Hill (from 260 citizens) and Senator Short (from 188 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:
Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms
Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:
ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms
produced a tolerant society
Your petitioners therefore request that:

PARA.TAB: Australia should remain a democratic constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia as our Head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Michael Baume (from 42 citizens) and Senator Bishop (from 19 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Quarrying at Exit Cave
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned, noting the Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area Standing Committee concludes that `even under the strictest environmental conditions continuation of quarrying jeopardises the area's World Heritage values', respectfully call upon the Federal Government to take all necessary measures to prevent further quarrying at Exit Cave.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill recognises that Australia has the worse extinction record of native mammals of any country on Earth in recent history and that species extinctions are still occurring at an alarming rate.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should support Commonwealth Threatened Species legislation which uses the full powers given to it by the Australian Constitution and which provides the necessary financial resources to halt the loss of species on this, the oldest continent on earth.

PETITION.TITLE: Smokefree International Flights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned,

(ii)call for the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) of which Australia is a member to set a standard for smokefree international flights; standards set by ICAO must be agreed to by its 162 member nations.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Australian Labor Party should return to its traditional support for the Constitutional Monarchy as represented by Messrs Chifley, Evatt and Hayden and reject support for an Australian Republic being promoted by Mr Hawke and Mr Keating.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Post

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag

We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
We are proud to fly the Australian Flag and will oppose any changes to it.
We support the Constitutional Monarchy and will oppose any moves to turn Australia into a Republic.
We believe in loyalty to the Crown and Nation, pride in the National Anthem and respect for our existing Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: This petition of the undersigned, who are proud citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate,

b.we do support the Australian Flag, and

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.TITLE: United Vietnamese Buddhist Congregation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Federal Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showed that:

During the last 47 years, since the Communists have been taken over the Government in the North Vietnam, and last 17 years in the South, the Buddhist community, which is 85% of the whole population, has been badly discriminated, and strongly suppressed. Its activities have been limited. Its united, elected & structural Congregation has been banned. Its resources have been dispossessed. Many leaders have been killed, convicted or banished.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate make strong representation to the Vietnamese Government, to request them:

(b) stop all of their interference and control, openly or shadowy, to the religious affairs.

(2) urgently and unconditionally release all of the religious leaders, especially the important/senior monks of the UVBC: Most Venerables Thich Huyen Quang, Thich Quang Do, Thich Duc Nhuan, Thich Tue Sy, Thich Tri Sieu, Thich Nguyen Giac. . . .who have been convicted or banished just because of their reputation or their human right activities.

(3) return to the UVBC or to other regional Buddhist communities, and make fully compensation of, all the Buddhist-community-previous-owned institutes, monuments, factories, temples, training monasteries, university, high & primary schools, and all other educational, medical, welfare, charity institutions etc., which have been taken over, misused, destroyed, illegally occupied or forcibly offered to different Government levels since 1945 in North Vietnam or 1975 in South Vietnam.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order No. 78, I give notice that at the conclusion of this statement I shall withdraw Business of the Senate notice of motion No. 2 standing in my name for this day for the disallowance of clause 11 of Public Service Determination No. 27 of 1992, made under the Public Service Act 1992. Mr President, I seek leave to make a short statement about the Committee's concerns with this instrument.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This instrument, upon which I reported on 26 May 1992, is defective because it appears to entrench an anomaly strongly criticised by the Merit Protection and Review Agency. However, following intervention by the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, the Department has reviewed its previous position that the anomaly need not be addressed and has subsequently proposed action which should resolve the present inequity. As usual, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short statement and the Committee's correspondence.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: On 26 May 1992 the Committee reported to the Senate on its concerns with clause 11 of this Determination, which related to an anomaly which deprived certain officers of the Australian Public Service of credit for up to one week's recreation leave. That anomaly was investigated by the Merit Protection and Review Agency, which reported that the position was "clearly . . . inequitable", "obviously anomalous", "unfair and inequitable" and required legislative or other action to mitigate its past and future consequences. However, the present Determination not only did not correct the anomaly but also may have entrenched it. Also, the MPRA advised the Committee that it was not informed that the Determination would be made.

After that report to the Senate the Committee was briefed by a member of the senior management groups of the Department of Industrial Relations and two other members of the Department, who also prepared two papers for the Committee. The result of these discussions was that the Department expressed a preferred option to deal with the problem through direct appropriation during the present budget process, rather than by legislative action. The Committee advised that it would be satisfied if the matter was dealt with in this way.

The outcome of the Committee's scrutiny of this instrument is encouraging. We have not yet received confirmation that the money will be available. However, the position now is that whereas previously the Department informed the MPRA and those affected that the anomaly would not be addressed, following the intervention of the Committee the official stance of the Department is that action should be taken.

The Committee is grateful to the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator the Hon Peter Cook, for his assistance. The Minister instructed the Department to cooperate with the Committee in its investigation and, on being advised that the Committee would be satisfied with particular action, wrote to the Prime Minister requesting this action. This action by the Minister demonstrates a commitment to the principles of the Committee.

The Committee will report again to the Senate when we receive further advice. The Committee still has a notice of motion of disallowance on Public Service Determination 1992/46, which amends substantive provisions of clause 11 of Public Service Determination 1992/27 to correct drafting oversights.
The correspondence of the Committee in this matter is set out below:
Senator the Hon Peter Cook
Minister for Industrial Relations
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to Public Service Determination 1992/27, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 7 May 1992.
I attach a copy of a representation about the Determination from Mr Graham Boucher. The Committee would appreciate your comments on the representation.

On its face, the representation raises serious issues. The copy of the Merit Protection and Review Agency report in respect of this matter stated that the existing position was "clearly. . . inequitable" and that the legislation was "obviously anomalous" and required amendment. The MPRA recommended that in view of the "unfair and inequitable" application of the legislation that Mr Boucher should be compensated and that other action should be taken. It now appears that the Department may have expressly made delegated legislation which fails to implement the thrust of the recommendations. If this is so then the Committee would be disturbed.

The Committee also has several concerns about the instrument itself. Firstly, subclause 11.1 appears to interpret the words of s.68A of the Act in a particular way. We would be grateful for confirmation that this is legally possible. In this context the Explanatory Statement advised the statutory authority for subclause 11.2. Next, the Explanatory Statement does not appear to tell the whole story, if that story is as related by Mr Boucher and the MPRA.

The broader issues raised by this Determination are also serious. Numbers of Public Service Determinations grant discretions to decision makers. In the past the Committee has raised the question of merit review of these discretions. The answer we have received is that merit review is available under the grievance procedures of the Merit Protection (Australian Government Employees) Act 1984. For instance, see our correspondence on Public Service Determinations 1990/11, 1990/12, 1991/37 and 1991/39. A letter to the Committee of 22 July 1991 concerning Public Service Determination 1991/39 stated that the "regulations provide for internal review and for review by the Merit Protection and Review Agency of adverse decisions. . . The regulations are shortly to be amended. . . to ensure that the rights of officers and employees are protected". The Committee accepted these assurances and consequently refrained from raising other discretions. It is disturbing, to say the least, that the Department may apparently ignore a recommendation of the MPRA in this way.

Given the serious nature of this matter we would be grateful if the subdelegate in the Department who made the Determination, and other suitable officers, could brief the Committee at its next meeting at 8.30 am on 28 May 1992 in Senate Committee Room 1S6. The Department should contact the Committee secretary on 277 3066 to confirm this.
The Committee would also appreciate your comments on the above issues.
In order to preserve the options of the Committee I will give a notice of motion of disallowance in respect of the relevant clause of the Determination on the next sitting day.
Yours sincerely
Patricia Giles
Chair
Senator Patricia Giles
Chair
Senate Standing Committee
on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Giles
Thank you for your letter of 7 May 1992 about Public Service Determination 1992/27.
I have asked the Department of Industrial Relations to cooperate fully with the Committee's enquires, and to make the appropriate officers available to brief the Committee on 28 May 1992.

In order to assist consideration of this complex matter, I have also asked the Department to provide the Committee as soon as possible with a paper clarifying the different roles of the Merit Protection and Review Agency in handling various kinds of grievances. The paper will also address the commitments given in the past about merit review discretions, and comment on the representation from Mr Boucher taking account of relevant policy.
I will write to you again when I have had the opportunity to consider the Department's views and the outcome of discussions with the Committee.
Yours fraternally
Peter Cook

PARA.TAB: 18 June 1992

SPEECH.PARA: Senator the Hon Peter Cook
Minister for Industrial Relations
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to your letter of 27 May 1992 on aspects raised by the Committee of Public Service Determination 1992/27.

Officers of your Department have since then assisted the Committee by appearing before it to speak to a paper and, after that meeting, by preparing another paper. The Committee considered that second paper at its meeting of 18 June 1992.

The Department's second paper covered various courses of action available in this matter. Under the heading "Conclusion" the paper advised that "the preferred option" is to deal with this problem by direct appropriation "through the current budget process". This confirms earlier advice in the paper that these arrangements "could be achieved in the 1992/93 budgetary process". The Department also advised, in a covering letter, that the paper would be the basis of a submission to you.

The Committee would be completely satisfied if the matter was dealt with under the Department's preferred option. However, the Committee considers that another appropriate solution would be to amend the parent Act.

The Committee emphasises its view that the present position for relevant officers, characterised by the Merit Protection and Review Agency as unfair and inequitable and the existence of which has been known for almost 20 years by the administering authorities, should be addressed.

The Committee would be grateful for your advice on proposed action on the Department's preferred option. It would be appreciated if this could be received by, say, the end of July, to enable the Committee to finalise its consideration of this matter by the start of the Budget sitting. Given that the preferred option is to operate in the context of the 1992/93 budgetary process we do not suppose that this will cause any difficulties.

The Committee also noted that Public Service Determination 1992/46 replaced the substantive provisions of subclause 11.1 of Public Service Determination 1992/27. Your Department advised that this was because "it was realised that subclause 11.1 did not have the intended effect". In order to preserve the options of the Committee I will give a notice of disallowance on this second Determination during the next sitting week.
Yours sincerely
Patricia Giles
Chair

I have now written to the Prime Minister (with a copy to the Minister for Finance) proposing that this option should be implemented by the government from next financial year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Foreman, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the time for presentation of the report of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on taxes and charges associated with the road transport industry be extended from 11 September 1992 to the end of March 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have a brief statement on the notice of motion that I have given incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

The Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure invited submissions to its inquiry into proposed charges on heavy road vehicles by the end of February 1992. As the closing date for submissions approached it became clear that numerous potential contributors to the inquiry would not be able to meet that timetable. The reason given was that the National Road Transport Commission had called for submissions on the proposed charges and was conducting consultations with interested parties.

As a consequence contributors required extensions of time to prepare submissions to the Committee's inquiry. The Committee continued to received submissions until July and a number of submissions, particularly from Commonwealth sources, are still to be received.

Notwithstanding the late receipt of submissions the Committee was able to commence its program of public hearings and to date has held hearings in Adelaide, Mount Gambier, Melbourne and Perth. It has also inspected heavy vehicle operations at Mount Gambier. Last week the Committee also conducted inspections for 1 1/2 days in remote mining centres in Western Australia.

The remainder of the hearings and inspections program will entail visits to Darwin and Sydney as well as hearings in Canberra. Given the spread of hearings locations and the constraints of the Senate sittings program, Estimates Committee meetings, the need to produce a report on annual reports and some members' commitments on Select Committees, the Committee has concluded that it is necessary to seek an extension of time to complete the program, deliberate on its findings and to produce a report. Under the circumstances the Committee seeks agreement to an extension of time to report by the end of March 1993 and not as initially intended by 11 September 1992.
