I seek leave to make a statement relating to the 1992-93 Budget.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) is delivering in another place his Budget Speech for 1992-93.

SPEECH.PARA: It is my privilege to outline to the Senate the Budget proposals of the Government.
Mr President, this Budget has three fundamental objectives.
The first two are about jobs: jobs now, and more jobs in the years ahead.
When, as is the situation now, there are not enough jobs, it is up to the Government to take action; to do everything in its power to provide jobs for those Australians without employment.
We have already taken initiatives to boost the economy and rebuild and modernise the nation's transport system.
We have vastly expanded opportunities for young Australians.
And tonight, as our first priority, the Treasurer is announcing further measures to boost employment in those communities and regions hardest hit in recent years.
Many of our fellow Australians have, for the first time, found themselves out of work.
For them we cannot simply wait and hope, or engage in some economic experiment.
We must act now, in ways which we know will work.
These employment measures will include projects conceived at the local level, providing real work and, at the same time, enhancing facilities for many deprived communities.
The total cost will be $1.2 billion over two years.

This attack on unemployment is part of our second objective—the implementation of a comprehensive and continuing strategy which is designed to achieve around 800,000 new jobs over the next four years.

Crucial to this strategy is the maintenance of a resolve to create a dynamic and successful trading nation: a nation based on talent, ideas and innovation, with its industry employing skilled workers producing goods and services to sell here and overseas.
This resolve will be fortified by measures announced tonight to entrench an already impressive growth in research and development and in exports.
There are new initiatives in vocational training, and there is increased effort to cut the costs of Government services and improve competition.
Our objective is to have new industries alongside the old, striving to secure a larger slice of the world market.
But this Budget—as its third objective—also confirms this Government as a caring Government, intent on pursuing its program of social reform.
Tonight I announce a major enhancement of Medicare, increased support for the aged and those who care for them, and for the unemployed.
There are new measures to improve access to more secure housing, and there is more assistance for families.
Mr President, as a small nation our future depends on taking advantage of developments abroad.
And in our case we straddle two very different parts of the world.

First there is the industrialised world of Europe and North America. These countries have also been struggling with high levels of unemployment. But they have higher inflation than we have. And many have lower growth prospects.
Australia's inflation rate is around 2 per cent, about half that of Europe.
This year the Government expects the Australian economy to grow by 3 per cent, or around a third faster than Europe.

Australia is also part of Asia. Growth rates and productivity in many Asian countries are impressive. But some have inflation close to 10 per cent. Most have inflation more than double that of Australia.
With a foot in each hemisphere we can benefit from opportunities in both.
We can enjoy higher growth than is forecast for Europe and the USA, with inflation no higher.
Our growth rate will be closer to Asia's, but it will come without Asia's higher inflation.
And as we commit ourselves to best practice at home, and embrace competition abroad, neither hemisphere will constrain our growth.
But these opportunities will not be handed to us on a plate.
We must seize them.
Last year was difficult for many countries. It was particularly difficult for Australia.
Recovery started during the year, but failed to gather strength in the way expected.
We all deeply regret that the growth achieved was not sufficient to prevent rising unemployment.
We all deeply regret the cost of unemployment to individuals, to families and to the community.
But regret, without action, has a hollow ring to it.
Nearly 50 years ago, the Labor Government of John Curtin, in its famous White Paper, committed the Commonwealth to a policy of full employment.
This Government affirms that full employment must and will be our continuing goal.
Tonight the Treasurer is presenting a statement titled Working for the Future which sets out this Government's plans for the years ahead.
The Budget has a firm and unequivocal role to play in boosting economic activity in the short term.

It does so by providing a strong but temporary stimulus, and by ensuring that Australia emerges into sustained growth, with an enhanced economic infrastructure, better able to underpin the opportunities of the 1990s.
Overall, the outlays cost of new and previously announced measures to boost the economy will be around $4 1/2 billion in the next two years.
In addition, we allow the impact of the recession on the Budget to run its course.
As a result, the budget deficit in 1992-93 is estimated to be $13.4 billion.
Nearly ten years ago this Government acted in the 1983 Budget to boost the economy and reduce unemployment.
One and a half million new jobs were created and within four years the Budget recorded a surplus—the first in nearly four decades.
The present recovery will deliver jobs. But the Government is acting now to reduce unemployment more quickly, to ease the pain and burden on Australians and their families.

Tonight I announce the expenditure of a further $742 million this year, and another $467 million next year, to attack unemployment at its roots—in the communities where the despair is deepest, where the pain hurts most.
The package builds on the offer from local government—the sphere of government closest to the community—to move rapidly to expand local employment opportunities.
This package for local government involves job placement, road building and repair, and a new local capital works program, together with the Landcare projects recently announced.
Its centrepiece will be the local capital works program which will inject $345 million into 411 local government councils, where about 70 per cent of all unemployed people live.
The program will involve grants of between $4 million and $20 million for each of 23 regions hardest hit by unemployment. These regions cover 179 local councils.

In addition, some $5 million is to be provided to local government, through their State Associations, to strengthen their capacity to co-ordinate the provision of regional infrastructure and regional economic development.
This measure recognises that local government has a key role to play in the process of national economic recovery and economic adjustment.
There will be $60 million for roads, and $154 million to be spent on government and non-government schools and universities.
$188 million planned for expenditure on urban development and public housing will be brought forward and spent this year and next.
Expenditures on Defence purchases and housing of $87 million will similarly be advanced to this year.
These measures will also be focused in regions with high unemployment.
Labour market and training programs will be expanded, particularly to assist long-term unemployed adults and to improve workforce skills and labour market flexibility.
.Places under the JOBSTART program this year will almost double, to 104,000.
.Work experience and training under the JOBSKILLS program will be available for an additional 12,000 people over the next two years.
.An extra $92 million will be provided over three years for adult training places to help people back into jobs.
.Over the next four years, we will provide English language training to 38,000 job seekers.
In all, we will nearly double expenditure on these programs this year, to $1.1 billion, and assist over 420,000 people.
The combined effects of these measures will see unemployment decline from 11 per cent last June to below 10 per cent twelve months from now, and keep on declining in the years ahead.
Clearly, reducing unemployment is our most pressing objective. But we must also continue our confident resolve to build a more export-oriented nation.
The Australian economy is part way through a momentous period of transition.
We have derived enormous benefits from our abundant natural resources and will continue to do so.
But in a highly competitive world, we must increasingly turn to the even more potent talents of our people.
We are creating new strengths and new skills as we respond to changes in the world around us.
In five years, our manufactured exports have more than doubled, while exports of services have increased by 82 per cent.
This has been an outstanding achievement. Our record on manufactured exports surpasses that of the major developed countries and even the Asian tigers.
There are many impressive examples.

Mitsubishi has centred its world production of the Magna Wagon in Adelaide. Ford is exporting its Capri, and Toyota plans to export 30,000 vehicles a year from its new plant in Victoria. Already, car industry exports exceed $l billion a year.
And Australian firms are exporting office equipment, chemicals, textiles, computers, telecommunication equipment and waste management technology.
There are about one hundred Australian firms exporting medical and scientific equipment.
Exports of services are also booming. Tourism is an important and well known example. But there are others. Australia's universities, schools and colleges earn $1 billion from overseas each year.

Australian engineers and accountants, business consultants and architects are building a valuable offshore client base. And exports of medical services to overseas patients in Australia are growing from a small base.
Currently, around 60 per cent of our exports go to Asia. For some time, Japan has been our largest export market. But Korea is now our third and Singapore our fourth largest market.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is fifth?
—Taiwan, I would expect, Senator. We export more to South-East Asia than we do to the USA.

SPEECH.PARA: But we need to increase our total share of the world market, if our growth is not to be constrained by the subdued international outlook.
This Budget adds to new measures announced in February, to enhance the capacity of our industries to export.
$75 million will be provided over three years from 1993-94 to those established and successful exporters entering new markets.
And a new working capital guarantee facility will support approximately $300 million of new exports for firms short of working capital.
The Government is also to assist further the rural sector which has been badly affected by reduced world prices and severe drought.
Additional funds will be provided for rural adjustment and a National Drought Policy, and improvements will be made to the Income Equalisation Deposits Scheme.
We are reducing the costs facing all exporters, our farmers, miners and manufacturers. And we are working with the States to improve the interstate rail freight and electricity industries.
With the States, we are reviewing their vital water supply industry and their shipping ports, and there is more to come.
We have given the Industry Commission a new role to identify impediments restricting the growth of promising export industries. The Treasurer is announcing the first group of ten references tonight.
Mr President, the capacity of our industries to compete depends on our ability to develop innovative products and more efficient production methods.

We have decided to extend indefinitely the 150 per cent research and development tax concession, so that Australia can continue to grow as one of the world's research and development centres. We have also decided to tighten up the scheme to ensure that research benefiting from tax concessions has an appropriate commercial focus.
And our great scientific institutions, such as CSIRO, will receive $31 million over two years to continue building the research capacity so necessary for the challenge ahead.
Innovation springs from the arts as well as science. The Budget continues support of the film industry and increases support to the performing arts.
While the Government is actively encouraging the development of industry, this will be consistent with the preservation of the Australian and global environment.
We are allocating $107 million over the next four years to industry and environment programs to foster sustainable development and to help address climate change issues.
The Government's initiatives will integrate economic and environmental decision-making.
We will improve the taxation treatment of investment for, and spending on, pollution control.
Our capacity to compete in the world, and to enjoy challenging jobs, depends greatly on the skills of our workforce.

The creation of a new Australian National Training Authority and the injection of $720 million by the Commonwealth will see, in three years, over 100,000 more young Australians involved in vocational training.
And by the year 2000, we will have another 200,000 young Australians aged between 15 and 19 years at school, in college and at university.
To meet these increasing demands, the employment package I am announcing includes $60 million to help the States refurbish up to 600 of their older high schools.
In higher education, the Government will establish the Open Learning Program at a cost of $53 million over the next three years.
The program will draw on the remarkably successful but much smaller pilot project which started this year.

For Australians in remote communities, for those with family or work commitments, and indeed for any Australian who may not have enjoyed access to traditional higher education, this initiative will be a historic milestone in removing barriers to participation.
In short, every Australian with access to a television and a letter box can now have access to a university education.
Existing AUSTUDY arrangements will be improved, and the system of grants will remain intact.
Tertiary AUSTUDY students will have the option to supplement their benefits through a voluntary loans scheme.
Through all the improvements, about 43,000 additional students will be eligible for assistance.
Mr President, the co-operative development of a flexible wages policy is a key element in this Government's economic strategy.
Through its close relationship with the trade union movement, this Government has fundamentally altered Australia's wage setting arrangements.
Workplace bargaining, which links wage increases to skills formation and productivity improvement, will become the primary mechanism for wage adjustments.
Agreements between managers and workers on matters such as hours of work, penalty rates, work practices and wage rates have improved flexibility while protecting basic conditions.
Building on this approach, the Government has proposed an alternative to a National Wage Case.

Our proposal is that minimum award rates be adjusted through supplementary payments, by an amount of $10 a week, and that workplace bargaining be the principal vehicle for wage increases in the future.
This will protect low paid workers while encouraging employers and employees to accelerate productivity gains.
This will occur in a framework of maintaining Australia's inflation rate at or below that of our major trading partners and matching international best practice.
In the 1990s, as in the 1980s, the Accord between the Government and the trade union movement will ensure that we achieve significant improvements to the economy.
This Budget is a budget of action on jobs.
It is a budget of confident resolve to continue the transition to a modern, vibrant economy.
But it remains a budget of care; care for our aged, for the frail, and for the disadvantaged.
In this Budget the Government is building on its proud record of social reform.
The cost of the initiatives to which I now refer have been offset, over this and the forward estimates years, by program savings and by revenue measures.

Important among the changes are the Medicare reforms which the Deputy Prime Minister will announce tonight. They will guarantee that every Australian will have access to the full range of Hospital and Medical Services on a fair basis.
An additional $1.6 billion will be provided over six years for public hospitals, subject to the States and Territories agreeing to the Government's proposals for the strengthening of Medicare.
These proposals ensure that Australians will have hospital services provided on the basis of clinical need and not on the basis of private health cover.
No longer will private patients be able to jump the queue ahead of public patients in equal need of treatment.

A program, costing $71 million over two years, will ensure that waiting times for elective surgery are brought down to acceptable levels. Strategies to achieve this will include, where necessary, buying in services from the private sector.
The Government's reforms will ensure that Medicare can meet the 29 per cent increase in public hospital admissions expected over the next decade.
To fund these substantial improvements in health services, the Medicare levy will increase by 0.15 per cent from 1 July 1993.

Australians on average weekly earnings will pay about 80 cents extra a week in their Medicare levy. For this they will receive the benefits of—and improvements to—one of the best health care services in the world. This achievement is one of which this Government and all Australians can be justly proud.
In February 1991 the Government gave a commitment to provide a real increase in pensions during the life of this Parliament.
I am now announcing an increase in the single rate of pension of $6 a fortnight, and $10 a fortnight for pensioner couples, from late January 1993.
This increase incorporates the adjustment otherwise due in March 1993 and includes an additional amount.
This additional amount will be provided to the older, long-term unemployed, and to most of the unemployed with dependants.

From April 1993, all full and part pensioners and older long-term allowees will be eligible to receive the range of fringe benefits provided by the Commonwealth, including hearing aids and a telephone allowance.
$44 million will be provided for nursing homes over the next four years and a home equity loan scheme will be established for pensioners.
Mr President, the Deputy Prime Minister will also be announcing tonight a new long-term housing strategy.

One of the first steps in the strategy will be to provide an extra $24 million in 1992-93, rising to $40 million in 1995-96, for rental housing managed by community organisations and local government.

$48 million will be provided over three years to help 20,000 lower income earners buy equity in the public housing in which they live. This will also release capital to fund new homes for those in need.
And a new structure of rent assistance, to cost $71 million next year, will benefit 440,000 low-income private renters, including about 300,000 pensioners.
The Government will introduce a package to improve the affordability and efficiency of child care services.

It includes an increase in the existing fee relief ceiling of $4 a week for each child in care. And it will provide for continued operational subsidies to community-based child care centres and family day care services.
These measures will assist 135,000 families and will cost $68 million over the next four years.
In a new initiative, up to $136.50 in family allowance will be available on request as a lump-sum advance to help meet unforeseen expenses.
In 1990, the Government initiated measures to assist people with disabilities to enter the workforce and to participate fully in the community.
Tonight we are announcing further measures at a cost of $68 million over four years which will build on those reforms.
Additional funding of $41 million over four years will be provided for respite services to reduce the burden on carers of frail aged and disabled people.
And the domiciliary nursing care benefit is to be increased to $26 a week from 6 January 1993 and indexed thereafter.

The Budget provides for the policies and programs to assist Aboriginal people which the Prime Minister recently announced. It also provides a total of $19 million over four years for the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation.
Australians living in remote areas are often disadvantaged.

The Government has thus decided to increase the income tax remote area zone rebates by 25 per cent from 1 January 1993. For people in the remotest areas of Australia, the base component will be $235 higher in a full year. Remote Area Allowances will be increased accordingly.
I now turn to revenue measures.
The major revenue initiatives include the increase in the Medicare levy and an increase of $5 a kilogram in tobacco excise.
This increase will raise the price of a packet of 30 cigarettes by up to 20 cents and reinforces our policies to reduce the health costs of smoking. It will raise $80 million this year.

As part of the continuing task of making the tax system fairer, from 1 April 1993, Fringe Benefits Tax will be applied to valuable car parking facilities—mainly in central business districts—that are provided by employers to their employees.
Also, the tax benefits of limited partnerships will be restricted by taxing them on the same basis as companies.
The Budget has been framed with a realistic appreciation of the difficulties before us.
While net borrowing by the public sector is expected to be the same as last year, the Budget deficit will represent an estimated 3.3 per cent of gross domestic product.
The Government will eliminate the deficit as soon as possible. We shall introduce our announced personal income tax cuts. And the budget deficit will fall as economic recovery strengthens.
Outlays will fall over the period to 1995-96. But in the absence of new measures, revenues are also likely to decline.

If the fiscal position nearer to the time is not stronger than is now projected, the Government will consider and implement a number of tax changes to maintain the revenue structure. These changes—referred to in the Budget Statements—would allow for the 1995-96 deficit to be between 1/2 per cent and 1 per cent of gross domestic product.
Australia will grow more quickly this year than last. Australia is once again on the move.
Output is forecast to increase by $22 billion in 1992-93, creating around 160,000 jobs.
Recovery this year will continue to be aided by growth in private consumption, in housing and in public sector investment.
And business investment in plant and equipment, which is crucial to long-term job growth, is expected to turn around during 1992-93, making a modest contribution to the recovery.
Low inflation will continue to be the top priority of monetary policy.
Low inflation will take pressure off interest rates and thereby keep low the cost of borrowing to firms and families.
Low inflation will fortify our competitive position and so spur economic and employment growth.

The current account deficit is forecast to widen to 3 3/4 per cent of gross domestic product, in part owing to investment growth. This is below the levels experienced in earlier years, due in no small part to our impressive export performance.
Over the past decade, this Government has progressively reformed the Australian economy.
We are working to see our manufacturing and service sectors emulate the great record of our mining and rural industries by becoming dynamic and outward looking.
This Government also saw that our education system had to be reformed: from the school system through to universities.
With that reform, young Australians can acquire the skills necessary for the challenging jobs of the future.
The Government has reformed the capacity of the public sector to support the process of economic and social transition.
Much has already been achieved.
Australia, our companies and all working men and women are now better able to seize the opportunities offered by a changing world.
We need only the resolve to seize those opportunities.
This Budget shows that resolve.
But that resolve must continue to be matched by our care for those in the community who will not immediately benefit from those economic opportunities.
This Budget demonstrates that care.
And while Australia is better placed for future growth as the world economy recovers, we are determined to take action to provide jobs, by using all the means at our disposal.
This Budget takes that action.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief explanation as to why.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The matter of public importance proposed by me on behalf of the coalition today reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to present clear and objective forecasts and estimates in its 1992 Budget, free from political interference and manipulation.

I think it is quite clear from the wording of that MPI that the words were framed in anticipation of the Budget and that it would be a relevant debate prior to the Budget being introduced. Because of the delays in our procedures today, we had not reached the MPI by the time the Budget was introduced. It is inappropriate, therefore, now to proceed with the MPI in its existing wording. That is the reason why I have sought leave to withdraw the matter for discussion.

PARA.TAB: In doing so, I wish to make a couple of points. The first one is that the main reason for the delay today in our proceedings in the Senate is the Government's incompetence in its handling of the matters pertaining to the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992. Had that been handled with the competence that one would have expected in this place, those delays would not have occurred.

The second point I want to make is that the withdrawal of the MPI in no way reflects any backing away from the coalition's concern about the Government's political interference in and manipulation of economic forecasts and estimates. It is a customary practice now. It has been a highlight of this Government's performance in the last few Budgets and economic statements, notably the One Nation statement of February this year, that there has been very serious interference and involvement by the officers—particularly of the office of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and office of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins)—in the formulation of economic forecasts and estimates. It is a matter of great concern.

We will be examining the Budget delivered tonight very carefully indeed to see whether that iniquitous practice has been pursued on this occasion. The Budget that we have seen produced tonight is a Budget full of `spend now, pay later' elements and the figures in the Budget depend very importantly on the parameters that have been put down as underpinning the Budget and the economic climate. It is those parameters that we have always expressed concern about, particularly in recent years. They are the parameters that have caused great difficulty and great concern. They are the subject of political manipulation and interference. The debate we were going to have today will take place, but in an updated form in the context of the consideration of the Budget.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the resolution of the Senate of 7 November 1991, on behalf of the President I table the report of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs entitled A National Drought Policy—Appropriate Government responses to the recommendations of the Drought Policy Review Task Force, final report, which was presented to the President on 21 July 1992. In accordance with the terms of the resolution, the President has authorised the printing and circulation of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: On 22 July 1992, the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs presented to the President a final report on its inquiry into a national drought policy and, in particular, appropriate Government responses to the recommendations of the 1990 report of the Drought Policy Review Task Force.

PARA.TAB: The Committee commenced this inquiry in January this year, when many areas in Australia were in drought. Although recognising the importance of receiving evidence from governments and other organisations, the Committee wanted to listen to the views of those most affected by drought, that is, ordinary farmers and their families in rural Australia, and to draw on their current experience of drought. Over 170 witnesses appeared before the Committee at 17 public hearings, most of which were convened in rural and regional centres across Australia.

The Committee's report, as its title suggests, focuses on measures which should be taken by the Commonwealth Government to encourage a self-reliant, risk management approach to drought by primary producers. The Committee reiterated the view expressed in its interim report that a national drought policy should encourage a self-reliant approach to drought. The policy should also ensure adequate maintenance and protection of livestock and other resources, facilitate the early recovery of agricultural and rural industries from drought and minimise the loss of valuable international markets.

Accordingly, the Committee considered that appropriate financial incentives must be provided to farmers to store funds, fodder and water. Financial reserves, or what was described in evidence as a `haystack of funds', provide a sound basis for drought proofing. At the same time, the Committee recognised that these financial incentives must not be open to abuse.

In its report, the Committee makes precise and practical recommendations about specific improvements to the income equalisation deposit scheme in order to make it more effective and attractive to farmers; the extension of full tax deductibility in the same year for expenditure on drought proofing measures, such as structures to conserve or convey water; and the introduction of tax credits for expenditure on drought proofing measures. It is not much good to give tax assistance to people who are making a loss. It is necessary, over a period of years, to give them an opportunity by providing them with tax credits.

Although endorsing a self-reliant approach to drought, the Committee considered that there are limits to the capacity of farmers to cope with severe drought. Invariably, as drought worsens, self-reliance will diminish and, even with sound management and planning, it may be difficult for a primary producer to withstand the effects of the most severe drought. In some cases it would be impossible. The Committee's report provides detail about the difficulties in defining `severe drought' and appropriate mechanisms to trigger additional assistance in times of severe drought.

Nevertheless, the Committee came to the view that the Commonwealth Government has a responsibility to provide additional assistance in severe drought. It is also in the interest of the Commonwealth Government to do so. It is in the national interest for the Commonwealth Government to protect and maintain Australia's agricultural base and productive capacity and, in particular, its breeding herd and flock. Once lost, it is almost impossible to regain.

As Chairman of the Committee, I welcome the recent announcement by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) that the Commonwealth will provide new extreme drought assistance of $14m to New South Wales and Queensland. Both these States have large regions which have been affected by severe drought for up to three years. They are still being affected by severe drought.

The Committee received considerable evidence about the rural adjustment scheme as a delivery mechanism for Commonwealth assistance during drought. The Committee's report identifies several problem areas, including additional debt burdens and eligibility criteria. As Chairman of the Committee, I welcome the recent announcement by the Minister that the Commonwealth and States have agreed to major reform of the scheme.

This is the first major inquiry and report by the newly established Rural and Regional Committee. During the inquiry, the Committee adopted various procedures that allowed—and encouraged—as many people as possible to have a say. For example, in Cobar, New South Wales, 12 people came from the audience to tell the Committee, some in a very moving way, about the disastrous effects of drought on their farms, themselves and their community. Members of the Committee also visited several properties and had informal talks with farmers. This approach to the inquiry allowed the members of the Committee to gain a genuine understanding of the concerns of rural people. I trust—I certainly shall be working towards this—that the Committee continues this approach in its future inquiries. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, Senator Burns, in commending this report on a national drought policy to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), the Government and the Australian people. The amount of work and effort the Committee put into this inquiry will serve both the Government and the community well. I thank those who worked so hard on the secretariat. It was not an easy inquiry. We had to travel all over Australia in a very short period. We looked at 89 submissions and heard 175 witnesses at 17 public hearings in nearly every part of Australia.

PARA.TAB: As the Chairman said a moment ago, we actually went out to where it was really happening. We went out and talked to the people who have been really hurt by drought to see what was happening to the livestock in those areas, to see what was happening to the country, to see the degradation of the land, because of severe drought. We met with people who were still resolved to have a go, to produce things for the future of Australia. They did not want to lie down and give things away. It was a great eye-opener for all of us on the Committee. It was a happy Committee. We all took on board the evidence that was given and really tried to work out what was going to be best in the long run.

We all know that Australia is a dry continent, but having been a farmer all my life, I did not think it could be as dry as it was in some of the places we went. For example, the situation in Cobar in the western division, which I had visited on other occasions, was absolutely horrific; that at Esperance was not good at all, with people having to battle for survival. We saw the same thing in parts of southern Queensland.

The Committee reached the view that drought in Australia is a naturally occurring phenomenon. Therefore, it does not really matter whether drought comes within the natural disaster relief arrangements or whatever. It is important that in times of severe drought the Commonwealth Government has to play a part. That was a belief shared by all members of the Committee.

Severe drought was taken out of the natural disaster relief arrangements some years ago, and I know that a lot of people who would like to see it put back in. At the beginning of the inquiry I wanted to see severe drought back in the natural disaster relief arrangements. I cannot say that I would not argue in favour of its being back there, but it does not really matter where it is, as long as the Commonwealth Government takes responsibility when severe drought gets beyond the capabilities of an individual and indeed of the State. One of our most sincere recommendations is that the Commonwealth has to play a part, and I believe and hope that that will happen.

Over the past few years there has always been an argument between the Commonwealth Government and State governments as to whether a severe drought has existed and what will trigger help and assistance from the Commonwealth Government, which has the biggest coffers when it comes to ensuring that the breeding herd and the breeding flock are retained for the future. If we lose those herds and flocks in severe drought, obviously we cannot come out of those conditions as quickly as we would like.

Referring to the Budget tonight, I make the point that this Government came into power on the breaking of the drought in 1983. A good and properly thought out drought policy by the Fraser-Anthony Government had allowed the rural industries to get back on their feet very quickly. Peter Nixon, the Minister at the time, made sure that the national herd and the national flock was retained. As soon as the 1982-83 drought broke, the whole of the economy was able to blossom again because we had breeding herds and breeding flocks that enabled people to start producing for the wealth of Australia.

As I said earlier, it does not matter what is in place as long as everyone takes a responsibility. When we brought down this report I made numerous comments, some of which the Chairman has already covered. Wherever we went, we found that although the drought was severe all farmers wanted to become self-sufficient. But they cannot become self-sufficient overnight; it will require many years of saving up money and fodder reserves and building up a bank of money to enable farmers to get through severe droughts.

For example, we recommended that the income equalisation deposit scheme should be made much more effective so that when people deposit money into the scheme in a good year it is totally deductible from their income in that year and tax is not paid on it. When people have money invested with the Government until they need it—that is, when the next drought starts—they should get interest on it at the short term bond rate. When they withdraw their money out of that scheme to use during a severe drought, they should be able to pay tax on it at the marginal tax rate that applies in that year.

At the moment the IED scheme is working in such a way that, having regard to withholding tax and the other problems existing with income equalisation deposits, when a farmer withdraws money in the year that he needs it he has to pay a whopping tax on it. That is not helping him or her; nor is it giving him or her the incentive to put that money away. It is very good to see the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) sitting opposite, since he is the person who is tied up with the finances of this Government, listening to some of the recommendations we have made. I made recommendations on this to him when he was an assistant Minister. I hope now that from his review of the scheme, taking into account what we have found out in this inquiry, we will get a decent income equalisation deposit scheme. I can assure him that if the Government does not give it to us in the next few months we will definitely give it to the farmers when we return to government at the next election, whether it be in December or in May of next year. Returning to the report, there has to be time for people to put the money away.

Another area that has already been canvassed is when somebody does not make money. How can they put money away? Obviously, we thought very hard on this issue as well. We believe that the introduction of a tax credit scheme relating directly to expenditure on drought proofing is another and different way in which people could save for drought. But there has to be time for transitional arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry to interrupt, but have you seen the income equalisation deposit changes in the Budget? There are some you will like there.
—As the Parliamentary Secretary knows, we did not have much time to look at the Budget Papers because they were not distributed in the chamber.
—I am merely drawing it to your attention.

—That is good. I hope they will be as good as they should be. If they have been mucked around with and made only half as good as they should be, they will not achieve what is necessary for people to have that bit of carrot to save—
—What about the weather?

—If Senator McMullan is talking of the Budget, that is a cracker. Here we have the Budget Overview and Economic Outlook: 1992-93, page 29, Treasury, average farm product—estimated obviously—1992-93, 7 1/4 per cent. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Better weather conditions boost farm product.

I would love to think that weather forecasting could be as good as this Budget has tried to lead us to believe. If the Government has had such a airy-fairy look at IEDs as that document shows, I doubt whether the Government's IED scheme will be what Australian farmers need to get us going.

PARA.TAB: However, there have to be transitional times to enable people to prepare themselves. No government can abandon primary producers—and that is exactly what Senator Burns said earlier when he moved for the tabling of this report. Everyone has to be responsible in the drought survival process. The farmers have to be responsible in their own way; but then the Government, when the drought becomes very, very severe, has to play its part.

As I said earlier, basically there was always a problem between State and Federal Ministers concerning the implications and motivations which made the Federal Government give support at a time of drought. Opposition senators have come up with what we call the `trigger mechanism' to activate the Commonwealth's involvement in severe drought. We say that that could include an application from the shire concerned; the use of objective measurements using soil moisture readings; and an overriding subjective assessment by a tripartite drought committee involving the cooperation of Federal and State governments and primary producers. I sincerely believe that that would be a way of taking severe drought from the political area and making sure that the committee always acted in the best interests of both the producer and the State and Federal governments concerned.

Another area of concern is the rural adjustment scheme. We found that in most places people were not happy with the way drought aid was being given and that it was not being received in the proper way. Although we acknowledged that that scheme is the principal source of drought assistance at the moment, we highlighted several problems with it.

Basically, transitional arrangements must be in place to enable people to put money aside; they have to have time to prepare. That will require the Government to have a little bit of foresight in giving those incentives to people to actually help themselves prepare. In the meantime, I believe that the Government will have to do more than the $14m allocated for Queensland and the western division of New South Wales as that will be only a drop in the ocean or a speck of sand in the desert. It will be only a little bit of help when, basically, it is a little bit too late.

The New South Wales Government has already provided $20m by way of assistance in that State through transaction-based subsidies and other measures. That is one of the arguments I have with the Federal Minister in presenting this drought report. He has suggested that the transaction-based support should be taken away. If we want to retain our herd, if we want to do the right thing by animal welfare, if we want to do the right thing by the environment, I believe it is essential that people get the stock off the farm and are able to bring it back after a drought in a way that actually helps their land, helps the animal welfare aspects of the stock and retains the breeding herd. I must say, to be fair, that Minister Casey in Queensland has actually said that he is not going to phase out the transaction-based subsidies for at least another 10 years because he believes that they are very important for the areas that I have just mentioned.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I will read to the chamber a couple of little extracts from people who are suffering from drought. Sitting here in this hallowed atmosphere on Budget night and actually having listened earlier to a Budget that is not going to do Australia any good, that is a throwaway Budget, that is actually a Bankcard Budget which does not address itself to Australia's major problems and issues, we should think of some of the people who have been suffering drought for quite some time. I quote from an article about Wyandra, which is 90 kilometres south on the Warrego, where Phil and Donna Lewis at Max Creek station tell a familiar story of battling along with reserves falling.

This article, which was written nearly a year ago, states that it would be catastrophic if the drought drags on deep into 1992. Some of these people have been suffering drought for three years and I think we should just spare a thought for them at this time. The article reads:

At Max Creek, which covers an area of 10,100ha, there was some rain in February, calving and weaning is finished, 150 cows and calves are on agistment or on the stock reserve down the road, along with 1,200 young ewes. "But we're doing a battle," Phil says, "It's starting to get serious."
And there is the chill thought of foreclosures in the district.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose it is very easy for people who live in the cities and towns, especially around the eastern seaboard, not to understand some of the problems associated with those people who are out there.

PARA.TAB: Another recent article talked about a station owner out at Cobar, Ian Murphy, who is also a spokesmen for the Western Action Movement. It highlighted the plight facing farmers in that drought area. I can understand his concern and worry. Mr Murphy said that, with overseas aid running at a record level—$1,600m—the offer by the Federal Government of $14 million is, as I said earlier, only a speck of sand in the desert out in those areas at the moment. He said that there is a national catastrophe and that the Federal Government should be playing a part. He actually lost a great deal of his sheep and his cattle. He has to get going again and it is going to take time to do it. At the moment he still has equity in his property; he is battling hard against it. I think we should spare a thought for people like Ian Murphy.

I heard a bit of a `humph' from the other side earlier tonight when I said that 70 per cent of New South Wales is still in drought. It is. If anyone thinks that drought out in that area can be broken with a couple of inches of rain—

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially when the crop has not been planted.

—There are no crops out in some of those areas. Out in the western division a couple of inches is not going to get the feed growing; it is not going to buy the sheep or cattle to get the farmers going; and it is not going to get the productivity going.

PARA.TAB: The problem is that the wool clip has gone back and the commodity prices are down. They have a horrific problem out in that area. With regard to what Senator Panizza said concerning cropping, the average broad acre farmer is going to make a loss this year of at least $29,000.

Despite all that, agriculture will make a contribution of something like $14 billion to Australia's export earnings, with a gross value of farm production of some $20 billion. So I think that the Federal Government definitely owes a little bit to the farmers who are producing that export income to maintain the standard of living of all of us, as I have said in this place many times before. Farming directly employs some 400,000 Australians, and two million people rely on farming to earn their living.

That is another reason why no government can walk away from farmers in a severe drought or in a severe downturn situation. As I said earlier, commodity prices are down, especially wool. A gentleman told me tonight that he was offered 360c a kilo for his wool clip the other day. For that price it is not even worth producing because he would be running at a loss when the shearing costs and all the other problems are taken into account.
There are many other areas of our report that need special attention. One of them is climate prediction.

TALK.START.PARA: —We'll cover that.

—That is okay. Senator Calvert will cover it better than I will. But he will cover it for the second time. That will be good because the Government will then hear it twice and it might take a little bit more notice of it. This Federal Government has just made big cutbacks in climate prediction. That is why I would like Senator Calvert to keep reiterating this point because I believe that a lot of work should be done in this area.

PARA.TAB: I know that Senator West from the Government side of the chamber is very interested in rural counselling. More rural counsellors are being used. They are highly necessary if we are to make sure that people are helped to find their way through problems.

The report also deals with kangaroo management, which I am sure Senator Calvert will talk more about later on. It also refers to feral animals. We should take into account rabbits and goats—not only the goats on Senator West's side of the chamber; there are a lot of feral goats out in the western division. I notice that the Government Whip, Senator Jones, is laughing. He has a sense of humour anyway.

Another measure that is very necessary is species conservation during times of severe drought. Land management is very important and a great deal of attention should be paid to it. I know that my colleagues Senator Bjelke-Petersen, Senator Panizza, Senator Crane and Senator Calvert will play a part in discussing the drought committee's report.

In conclusion, I would like to thank again members of the secretariat for their help and assistance during this inquiry. I believe that they made it much easier for all of us to handle the amount of travelling that we had to do. They were also of great assistance in enabling us to visit and listen to people. Neil Bessell, Peter Short, Claire Shepherd and Chris Migus should all be thanked for what they did.

At the end of every public meeting of the Committee anybody was allowed to make a verbal submission for five minutes. The Chairman of the Committee should be thanked for allowing this to happen. I believe that this was a great breakthrough for a Senate committee. We were able to go out to the coalface and listen to what people had to say about how they felt we, as the law-makers of this country, should be handling the problems caused by the drought. I commend to the Senate the Committee's report, which is entitled A National Drought Policy—Appropriate Government responses to the recommendations of the Drought Policy Review Task Force.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to commence my remarks by also adding my thanks to the secretariat of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs. It has to be one of the most impressive secretariats in this Parliament. Although working under extreme time constraints, we managed to produce an interim report in less than three weeks in time for it to be made available to all of the Ministers who were to attend the January-February meeting of the Australian Agricultural Council. We owe a great deal of thanks and gratitude to the secretariat for carrying out that task. The secretariat also managed to produce and present the final report, which is before us tonight, to the Ministers prior to their meeting last month in Mackay. It is no mean feat to be able to respond in a very short time, to write a significant report and to make it available to the key players who are going to be debating this issue.

PARA.TAB: Senator Brownhill mentioned that I might be interested in counselling. I certainly am. I would like to highlight the fact that this Government has increased very significantly the amount of money that has gone to rural counselling services. There has been a large increase. I say thank you very much for that because this is a very important issue. There is a flow on from that. There is a need to support the professionals who provide the counselling. Madam Acting Deputy President, you would be aware of the importance of peer review and support. There is a need to work on one's counselling skills. It is important that we make sure that those services are available for counsellors. That is being worked upon. I notice that this aspect is mentioned in some of the recommendations and Government moves.

I think some of the State governments have to look to see whether they are also providing adequate counselling and support services for rural communities. I suspect that often rural counsellors in a number of areas are called upon to do counselling on non-financial-type issues. As those of us who have had an involvement in counselling know, it is easier for people to present with a physical, tangible problem than to look at some of the issues that they are experiencing within themselves.

I think it is very important to ensure that the States provide adequate counselling services out in the communities to ensure that the rural financial counsellors can do what they are trained to do. There should be adequate back-up and support for those people who require extra counselling, be it in the psychological or mental health area. We must have an adequate number of psychologists, social workers and mental health nurses out in the communities. The States have to look to such a provision of services in the rural areas. This is something the States have not done terribly well. It is even worse when drought and low commodity prices combine to present a handicap.

Senator Brownhill also mentioned feral animals, to which I would add native animals. We hear a great deal of debate amongst some of the green movement to the effect `Let's not endanger our kangaroos'. I can tell the Senate that the great western red and the great western grey are not in any danger of becoming extinct. These animals are in plague proportions. That needs to be recognised by people when we are talking about what the kangaroo cull will be.

Last year I did a trip from Dubbo to Bourke. We arrived in Bourke an hour later than we had planned. From Byrock to Bourke the kangaroos were almost shoulder to shoulder on both sides of the road, and I do not exaggerate. These large animals certainly are benefiting from the permanent water supplies we have provided to them, but they are also being affected by the drought and are dying. They are having a major impact upon the smaller native marsupials; they are destroying the low shrub and low cover that these animals require.

It is very important that we do not get carried away or distracted by some groups who want to save all of the native animals but not look at the particular balances that are so important in these areas. When we are looking at feral animals, we also have to look at the impact that white civilisation has made upon our country by the introduction of horses, goats, pigs, rabbits, camels, and cats. In my travels around western New South Wales, I have met all of those in their feral form, with the exception of buffalo and horses. I certainly have seen camels, goats, pigs and every other sort of feral animal. In Cobar a woman had employed rabbit trappers who in three months had destroyed around 30,000 pairs of rabbits on her property. Those rabbits were horrendous for her income source and also very bad for the land that she was trying to save and support.

We received evidence that South Australia never has droughts. I have been to the Eyre Peninsula a couple of times and I am not sure that it is ever suffering anything but a drought; it is a very dry area of the country. At a State level there is no special drought assistance, and therefore, the State has no need to declare droughts. That is one problem that we will have to address.

We also have the problem of the variation that occurs between the various organisations and groups that are responsible for drought declaration within the various States in the country. We saw a very graphic example of that after our trip to western New South Wales and Queensland in January-February, prior to the rains there. A line was drawn at the New South Wales border. The pastoral protection boards that are based on Moree, Walgett and Bourke were all drought declared, as was the western division.

At the Queensland border there was a semicircle that left out areas on the Bulloo and the Paroo at Culgoa that were not drought declared. We were looking at a straight line, one side of which was drought declared and the other was not. Obviously droughts do not affect areas in straight lines, and that is one thing that we looked at very carefully in our report when talking about severe drought.

There is a need to differentiate between drought and severe drought. There has to be objective assessment as to what is a severe drought and in which areas. There has to be some commonality of ideas and criteria so that we are not left with the crazy situation that we witnessed in southern Queensland where a doughnut-shaped section was not drought declared even though it was as dry as other areas. We looked over the dog fence and we could not tell the difference between conditions on one side of the fence and those on the other. One area had been drought declared and one had not because different criteria were used and different organisations and ways of assessing drought were involved. That is one area that we really have to look at very carefully to ensure that people are not being disadvantaged.

Senator Brownhill talked about 70 per cent of New South Wales being in drought. There is a need in New South Wales to differentiate between areas in severe drought, and that really is the case in the western lands division. Some have had fluky rainfalls but have not had the follow-up rain that is so essential. The people there are suffering and facing some very serious and even critical problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are other areas where people can't get a crop in.

—Some people have been able to get crops on certain types of soil and not on other soils. But Senator Brownhill has forgotten that in the One Nation package we provided assistance to enable people to access money which they could use to put in their crops. As has been said before, if people cannot get their crop in, they cannot get their cash flow going. If they cannot get their cash flow going, the banks certainly will not be interested.

PARA.TAB: It is important to remember that at the last Australian Agricultural Ministers conference, a national drought policy was decided upon. The Government has approved funding of $166.46m in 1992-93 under the rural adjustment scheme. An amount of $14m in this financial year is for extreme drought assistance for New South Wales and Queensland. It is important to note that that is for the extreme drought areas, such as the western division.

The Government will also provide $15.1m, including $13m of new funds, over four years for land care, drought education and training and drought communication and research. It is important to remember that these are things that have been announced tonight in this Budget. So the Government is already responding to our report.

The Government will improve the income equalisation deposit scheme and incorporate a farm management bond. The new drought policy is based on self-reliance, risk management, whole farm planning and recognition of drought as a natural feature of the Australian climate. Important components are the improved equalisation deposit scheme and new farm bond management, which will encourage farmers to build up financial reserves to draw on during times of hardship caused by drought and other factors.

Key changes include a reduction in the withholding tax rate and an increase in the maximum amount of deposits. The investment component will be increased under the farm management bond. Research and development will be increased to encourage drought preparedness and research in areas such as climate prediction; risk assessment and farm management strategies; pest and weed control and the provision of information; education and training to assist farmers and their advisers to improve their skills; and the communication of appropriate management strategies for drought within the farming community.

The rural assistance scheme funding includes interest subsidies to facilitate more effective management of farm businesses and to enhance farm productivity and farm adjustment. Interest subsidies for drought support can be on existing debt or new commercial finance used for carry-on purposes, restocking, fodder purchases, and living expenses. These details are being finalised and will be announced shortly, but that is the outline of what this Government is doing.

To say that this Government has done, and is doing, nothing on the issue of severe drought and has no national drought policy is, I think, a total furphy. It is important that people recognise that this Government has done a lot. We have to do some of the things with State governments, and that is not always easy because they seem to want to have their own agendas and go off and do their own thing. But they have to realise that drought crosses all boundaries, knows no State borders and has to be treated as a national issue. I thank everybody who has been involved with the Committee hearings and the drought report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that I would be speaking after the other members of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, but at your invitation, Madam Acting Deputy President, I will speak now. I am not a member of that Committee, but I do not think I have to be part of a committee to speak about drought in Australia. I am comfortable with speaking about drought this evening, knowing that Western Australia is having one of its best seasons ever. But no matter how many good seasons I have experienced or will experience in the rest of my life, I will never forget that drought is always looking over my shoulder.

PARA.TAB: I have looked at the recommendations of this Committee and I will go through them and comment on them one by one. The first recommendation states that:

SPEECH.PARA: The Rural Adjustment Scheme (RAS) form the basis for Commonwealth involvement in providing assistance under a national drought policy.

I thought that had always been the case. To my knowledge, the rural adjustment scheme is the basis of providing carry-on finance or whatever is needed. That has always been its purpose. I have been a critic of the rural adjustment scheme in the past 10 years. I have only ever heard complaints about it from the Western Australian side. Although the funds have been provided by this Government together with matching funds from the Government of Western Australia, distributing them has always been a problem. RAFCOR is responsible for investigating the applications and distributing the funds in Western Australia. But every year my office receives complaints from people who are involved in the industry that the finance does not get out in time.

PARA.TAB: I have said time and time again in this place that it is useless receiving finance to plant a crop one month after the prime seeding time. In Western Australia, the prime seeding time is between 1 May—if there is suitable rain—and about 8 June. It varies a bit in different areas, but that is the prime time. But time and time again the allocations from RAFCOR have come through one month after that. After all, when one is in the crop game one tries to have everything ready, especially the goods one buys for the crop. The main one is fertiliser. It is always a very good idea to have it in hand at the beginning of the year when it is a bit cheaper and then one will not be held up in getting it onto the place by February.

When the farmers who rely on that sort of finance do not get the finance okayed until the middle of May, they need another week or so to get the item onto the property. The same happens with chemicals. It is no good being able to afford to buy the chemicals in July which are needed by farmers in May if they are cropping. I have said time and time again that RAFCOR—which is the name Western Australia gives to its scheme—and the schemes used by the other States for distributing the rural adjustment scheme funds are too inefficient and slow. Obviously, they are not in the best position to work out whether a farm is viable and it is worth putting more money into it to carry on. It is pointless to come to that decision either past the prime time or at the prime time, because time is wasted otherwise. Hopefully, one day this will sink in.

I have always advocated that the local bank manager, or whoever normally deals with these people, is in a far better position to see whether someone is viable or not and worthy of receiving further carry-on funds. If it is kept local, the banks know the farmers personally and their working and farming habits. The local banks know all these sorts of things and it is better that they deal with the finance rather than organisations which are far removed from these farming areas. I do not know why they carry on in this way.

The next recommendation refers to transaction-based subsidies or rebates being discontinued. I have no worries whatsoever about supporting that recommendation, because I believe that is not the way to go about things. Certainly, I would not recommend that any subsidies or rebates of that kind be brought in because they only lead to inefficiencies.

The next recommendation made by the Committee is that structural improvements for the storage of grain, hay or fodder should be allowable as an immediate tax deduction in the year in which the expenditure is incurred. That is a very important recommendation which should be taken up by the Government. Those sorts of measures were around during the Fraser and Menzies years and in between those years. If I remember rightly, deductions for water conservation and fodder conservation were more than 100 per cent.

One of the main reasons why I believe this expenditure should be allowable as a tax deduction in the year of income is that generally, when there is a build up of stored fodder, including hay, oats, barley, lupins, or anything like that, this is the year of a good crop and plentiful supply. When a farmer has an above average season he carries out conservation that year for possible droughts that may show up in the next one, two, three, four or five years. To begin with, the funds would be available in those years of high production and high income. High profit under this Government seems to be a non-event these days, but when the cash is avail

SPEECH.PARA: the availability of better earthmoving machines, have commenced a program of storing water. Under the Fraser Government, a full deduction of 100 per cent was allowed for dam sinking—in other words, building earthen tanks—in the first year of income. There was a big expansion. With storage to a depth of about 8 or 9 metres, and a climate with 13 to 18 inches of rainfall, there is natural evaporation of about 3 metres a year, if I have it right. Even if a lot of water in those dams or earth tanks is used, it should last for three years under normal circumstances. In those three years suitable rainfall can be expected to refill the dams. It has been my experience that, except in an extreme drought, the bottom of a dam built to a depth of 8 metres will not be seen for many years. I believe this is a recommendation that the Government should look at for the conservation of water and also for conveying water—in other words, piping it from one place to another. Of course, windmills also take water from underground and put it into tanks. It is a good recommendation.

PARA.TAB: The next recommendation is that the income equalisation deposit scheme should be reviewed. Back in the late 1960s or early 1970s, if I remember correctly, Doug Anthony, the Leader of the National Party at the time—if he is not remembered for anything else; I am sure he will be remembered for other things—

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course he will.

—I am sure he will, but if he is remembered for anything it will be the IED scheme. He carried out the research and put the scheme into place during the time of a Liberal government. I believe that certainly played a major part in the conservation of cash on the farm. Water and fodder can be conserved, but along with that cash has also to be conserved.

PARA.TAB: The IED scheme was a very simple one. In a better year with a cash flow, a farmer would put a certain amount away and that amount would not be counted as income in that year. Any amount withdrawn during drier years when income was not so great would be counted as income. The farmer could withdraw the money and pay tax at whatever the nominal rate was for that year. In other words, that farmer would be taxed on his income plus any withdrawal made during that year. If I remember correctly, the figures from that time got up to $15m, $16m, $18m or $20m. There was a limit on the amount a farmer could deposit, but I believe it was a moderate limit and the farmers of Australia used the scheme.

Then along came the Hawke Government in 1983. My friend Senator Walsh, who lives not that far from me in Western Australia, about 100 kilometres away, at the time decided in his wisdom that it was a rort. I could never see what sort of a rort it was, but he thought that the effective interest rate for farmers with money in the scheme, with these deductions, would be higher than for anyone else from some other calling in life who saved money. So for some reason of his own or because of the ideology of the rest of the Government, which was as far left as honourable senators see on this front bench, he wanted to get rid of the scheme.

To make sure the numbers of farmers depositing into the scheme started reducing, the Government dropped the interest rate by one per cent every year until it got down to zero. I know that, in time, the farmers withdrew the money—maybe because they were having tougher times, but I suppose also because no interest at all was being accumulated. I know some farmers who still have money in the scheme and have left it there gaining no interest at all rather than kowtow to the Government's tactics and withdraw it.

After that, in 1982, there was a big drought in the eastern States. Unfortunately, that was when Malcolm Fraser called the election. As Senator Button keeps telling us, when the Australian Labor Party took over government, there was a high unemployment rate—but that was only caused by the eastern States drought. It was normal rate for the time. The drought very kindly broke for the Labor Party in March of the next year when it got into government.

After those droughts, I think by 1987 when I first came here, the Government reintroduced some sort of IED. The Government tried to make it work, but unfortunately got it all wrong and no big amounts of cash have ever been deposited, even though there were the wool boom years of 1986 to 1989 and good wheat years at about the same time. The deposits have never built up again because of the rather punitive measures that were in place.

The savings of farmers at that time were knocked down very much. The flush years would have been a good time to have such a scheme. Unfortunately, the scheme was not there and the farmers paid their income out in tax. The recession has now bitten. Because of the recession we had to have, caused by the then Treasurer and now Prime Minister (Mr Keating), people in most parts of the bush are again in a very bad situation.

The Committee recommends the review of the income equalisation deposit scheme. But the point is that we have it well covered in Fightback, and we will be the ones who will be putting it into action in government next year. The next recommendation is in regard to the desirability of rural bond schemes being reviewed. I believe certainly something should be done there.

The next recommendation is that there should be appropriate Commonwealth support for rural counselling. I believe that should be available, but that rural counselling should be split into two areas. It is all very well to have a rural financial counsellor, but one cannot expect that person to counsel on other matters. I will not comment on the counselling of families by psychologists or that sort of person or the counselling that is available with government assistance. Where I believe rural counselling has failed miserably is in regard to financial matters.

I have been a farmer most of my life, and I would say that the day that I need a financial adviser or a farm adviser will be the day that I get out of farming. I presume there is a place in society for farm advisers. But who are the farm advisers and rural counsellors paid by the Government to advise farmers who are in strife? We see farmers who have gone broke themselves. How often do we see it? Time and time again. I believe in learning from others, and in taking notice of what others are doing to see whether I can improve my way, but I will not listen to someone who has gone down the tube through mismanagement, over-capitalisation and the other sorts of things that may put people down the tube. Yet here we have these people employed to do just that.

A farmer who has gone broke, who has been driven off or whatever, has to get a job and has to earn a living. But for God's sake, if I can use that term, he should be put in a job where he has proved to be successful. Rural counselling by someone who has gone down the tube I cannot support. But this is happening, and I believe if we are to do something in rural counselling we should put in good financial experts rather than someone who has fallen in.

The next recommendation is that a sustainable management strategy for kangaroos should be developed. Senator West spent quite a bit of time on this one. I was under the belief that droughts, as well as having a negative effect on crops and the output from animals such as sheep and cattle, also controlled pests to a certain extent. But I agree with Senator West that in extreme circumstances kangaroos, because they are able to withstand such conditions a bit longer than the stock, can get into plague proportions.

I would like to comment here that the green movement, the environmentalist movement in Australia, has put Australia in that position. For 200 years Australia had sensible control of feral animals, but in the last 15-odd years, or maybe even less than that, that seems to have gone out the window. Now we cannot deal with this or we cannot trap that or we cannot shoot that and protect our own properties.

There are A-class reserves, national parks, that are set up alongside the rural community, but one can do nothing with feral animals that come out of those places. Madam Acting Deputy President, I will give you a good example. Getting out into the pastoral areas, a station near my home was bought out by the State Government and turned into a reserve of some sort. Prior to becoming a reserve, it was a sheep station. Everyone who ever owned the station always had to control the dingoes. They did that by baiting and trapping them. As the station is now a reserve, one cannot bait the dingoes, so they come out into the more built-up areas and attack sheep and cattle. No-one is allowed to do anything about that unless they see the dingo and go out and chase it; if they lose sight of it, they cannot do anything more about it. What utter stupidity! Senator Crichton-Browne knows the area I am referring to very well—around Koolyanobbing in Western Australia.

To add insult to injury, that station had a dam and used waterholes when it was running sheep. If those dogs could get something to eat and they had water, they would stay there. The dozers are now going around filling in the dams; one will not be able to catch water and the dingoes will need to go out further into agricultural areas to look for water, which will create a bigger problem. This is a worry. I certainly hope the Government in the short time it has left in office will do something about the last recommendation.

I refer to a matter which is not mentioned in the report. I have always believed that for any industry, especially the rural industry, to be able to survive in the long term one must have outside investments; in other words, one must spread one's investments. That is always good advice, whether one is a farmer, a share trader or whatever. Under this Government's policies, that has never been encouraged; in fact, it has been discouraged.

Business people, whether they be farmers or small business people, have been taxed out of existence through primary tax, government levies, fuel levies and land tax—at least there is no land tax on rural properties in Western Australia. There has not been any ability in the past 10 years to invest off-property. I can remember some of the rural counsellors who, for some reason, cropped up in the late 1970s. If a farmer was getting down in his cash flow, the first thing they told him to do was sell any real estate off-farm. That was the most stupid financial advice I have ever heard in my life, yet it was given time and time again. If I ever reached the situation where I needed a farming adviser, I would get out of farming immediately. That is the sort of wrong advice that farmers and others have been given in the past 15-odd years.

If the Government is to do something, the best thing it can do is to get out of the way of business. The Fightback package contains such measures. The best thing a government can do is get out of the way and let people farm, mine, operate transport, et cetera, so that they can build themselves up. Taxation measures should be looked at for innovative industries that can go up and down, such as mining. Farmers could then set up a base of off-farm investment.

In the 1960s I used to take part in many debates on off-farm investment compared with on-farm investment. The most frequent debating partner I had on that issue was my father, as we held different views. We held mostly similar views, but on a few issues we held dissimilar views. The farmers who went the way I referred to have been well rewarded. They have been able to keep their farms in hard times free of debt.

In conclusion, because my time is running out, I commend the Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs for its report and recommendations. However, it is all very well for the Committee to report and make recommendations, but the next thing that needs to be done is for the Government—in the time it has left—to take the recommendations and act and not put the report on the shelf and forget about it as it gathers dust.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly a pleasure for me, as a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Regional and Rural Affairs, to comment on the report entitled A National Drought Policy. This is the first report which the newly founded Committee has brought down.
