Honourable senators may remember that most of the members of this Committee were formerly members of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare which had, I believe, the honourable distinction of being the longest serving select committee in this place—something like eight years dealing with animal welfare matters. We realised that if we were to continue there was a need to broaden the scope of the Committee. Thanks to the leadership of Senator Burns and other Government members who agreed with both the Democrat members of the Committee and ourselves that it was about time that we had a committee which represented the very important primary industry portfolio, this Committee was established.

PARA.TAB: Even though primary industry is not the sexy subject it might have been a few years ago when Australia was riding on the sheep's back, nevertheless, it is still a very important industry and we still need the wool industry to pay the interest on our huge overseas debt. In fact, I think most of our wool income goes on that debt these days.

As I said, the report is the first one brought down by the Rural and Regional Affairs Committee. As previous speakers have said, we are very lucky to have such a very good secretariat, particularly our secretary, Neil Bessell. Whilst the report is not very long, it certainly gets to the nub of the problems. I am very proud of the fact that this report has a bit of feeling about it. In fact, in the report there is a foreword with a couple of photographs. I was going to comment to Senator West, although she is not here now, that there are a couple of very good photos of her in her elegant straw hat to keep the sun off. However, the photos show members of the Committee talking to members of the farming community at a place called Grass Patch in Western Australia which was experiencing a drought. My colleague Senator Crane was responsible for taking us to look at a drought in Western Australia. It was not much different from any other drought that I have seen because it had the same effect on farmers as does any drought around Australia.

I must say that the people we spoke to throughout our investigation of this matter were very pleased to see that the senators about whom they hear in Canberra had taken the time to get out of Canberra to look at what was really going on. We had to ask ourselves why this report came about: what was the motivation behind it. The motivation behind it was, of course, that the drought policy review task force brought down its recommendations in 1990 and as a committee we felt that there was no better way to test out a task force recommendation than to actually go and see how in practice these particular recommendations could be accommodated.

At the time that the Rural and Regional Affairs Committee was established, we had probably one of the worst droughts, coupled with a recession, that this country had seen for the previous 60 years. I hazard a guess that parts of the western division of New South Wales and south-west Queensland had probably not seen a drought like it for 60 years either. As a farmer who has gone through droughts—even in Tasmania we do have droughts—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not very many, though.

—Yes, but I can tell Senator Bjelke-Petersen that when we do have a drought it probably affects us more than it does those who are used to having dry spells because, in a lot of cases, we are not prepared for it.
—You have very cold droughts in Tasmania.

—Fair enough. Actually, in 1980 we had 11 inches of rain and in 1981 we had 10 inches. It was pretty similar to the type of territory in which Senator Collins lives. Senator Bell would probably remember that, too.

PARA.TAB: As I said, the reason for establishing this Committee was to put a human face on what has become something that Australian farmers have lived with ever since settlement of this country. It was heart-rending to see some farmers, particularly out in the western district, out the back of Bourke, which was one place I had always wanted to visit. So I have actually been to the back of Bourke.

It was interesting to listen to the experiences of people who have been there for four generations. One could actually feel their frustration and their sorrow at not being able to do anything about their stock. All farmers have a certain amount of feeling for their stock—some more than others—but I remember that one particular farmer had a huge property with a very low stocking capacity. He had 150,000 sheep and he guessed that he might have 10,000 left if he were lucky. He was not going to look for them because they were so weak that they would probably fall over and die, if they had not already died. To see a proud man like that speaking to us with tears in his eyes certainly brought home to me the personal effect that this terrible drought has had.

If the drought were not bad enough, the decline in wool prices, the recession and high interest rates—all those things that have never happened before at the same time—have really knocked the stuffing out of our rural communities. I was looking at some figures today and saw, for instance, that as of August this year the average broad acre farmer—that is one who grows wool and wheat—will make a loss this year on average of $29,100. That is pretty tragic stuff when it is coupled with the effect on small businesses. That would include a lot of people in rural areas. The number of bankruptcies for the financial year 1991-92 was about 17,857. Things are pretty tough out there. Whilst the farmers are suffering, we found that all those other people in rural towns were also suffering as a result of what was happening in the bush.

Looking back on some personal recollections, as I said earlier, I always remember that Senator West's hat was continually blowing off. I also remember the tragic story of one particular woman at Cobar who worked as a nurse as well as running her own farm. She had lost most of her stock and retained some of her breeding herd. It was estimated that in that particular area alone there were about 150,000 dead sheep because of the drought. I must commend the secretariat, as the cover of the report itself says it all; it shows just a desert with a whole heap of woody weeds.

A person from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy showed me some photos from a dry spell in Bourke a couple of years earlier of rabbits eating other rabbits to survive. That was all that was left for them to eat. They were eating themselves. It shows how drought creates problems, even for feral animals. To see rabbits feeding off dead rabbits to survive shows how desperate the situation was.

On the positive side, I was quite proud that every area our Committee—which some of us called Burns's drought-breakers—visited, apart from the western division of New South Wales, received reasonably substantial rain within two to four weeks after we left the place, and some areas even received it while we were there. I remember that Tasmania was having some sort of drought, and it rained the next day. I think we put our expertise to practical use. I know from Senator Crane that Western Australia received some useful rain a few weeks after we had been there.

I said earlier that all droughts were the same, but I will have to change my comments on that somewhat. In Senator Crane's area of south Western Australia—which is very light, sandy country around Jerdacuttup and Ravensthorpe—I was very concerned, as were all members of the Committee, that the dry weather was having a tremendous effect on soil degradation. There was plenty of evidence that the fragile, light and sandy country that had been cleared there not all that long ago was under a fair amount of threat from wind erosion. That is one of the side effects of drought that we cannot put a price on.

Although we made most of our visits earlier this year, I have been travelling around on other committees. Last Thursday I was in the home State of Senator Bjelke-Petersen. The Joint Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works was approving a new tax office. Around Australia it seems to be the only growth industry. There are new tax office buildings going up everywhere. It will create 400 jobs in Brisbane, so I think it will be good for the local economy. The day I was there I got out of bed and I thought I would go for a walk. I looked out and I thought, `Goodness me, this can't be Brisbane. There's a fog rolling across the city'. Then I thought, `It's not fog; it must be smog'. I realised afterwards that it was dust blowing from the drought areas of western New South Wales and south-west Queensland. It brought back to me the horrific things that we saw during our investigation into this particular problem.

Most of the areas we visited were almost like Bondi Beach. In fact, when we went out in the western division of New South Wales, my first impression was, `Why don't we give it back to the animals because that is all it is good for'. We were told that in a good year something like $1 billion of wool is produced in that area. That is a fair amount of money even in today's terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a lot of money.

—It is a lot of money in today's terms. Even with the shonky accounting of the Government in the Budget tonight, it is still a lot of money. It is needed to keep this country going. As I said earlier, it is a thriving community. I reckon the people who work out there not only need assistance, they also need a medal to stay there. But they do stay there, and they love it. We talked to people who were making more money getting rid of kangaroos than they were from sheep farming. Since we left the place, one of the chaps we spoke to has walked off his farm. The only thing left on it is his son who goes out shooting the kangaroos. I think he is keeping up the payments on the farm by doing that.

PARA.TAB: One of the things that was touched on tonight and that I found rather interesting was the evidence given to us by Mr Barry Hunt, the Chief Research Scientist with the CSIRO Division of Atmospheric Research in Melbourne and by Dr Gauntlet, the Acting Director of the Bureau of Meteorology in Melbourne. Ten or so years ago, when the farmers on the east coast of Australia started hearing about the El Nino effect, we thought it was something like UFOs—a bit of speculation without much fact behind it. But it has come to light from investigations that there is an El Nino effect. It does occur at regular periods. It can be forecast, as has been shown by the evidence given to us.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does El Nino mean?

—I will tell you in a minute. Of all the facts that came out of the evidence we received—some 89 submissions and some 175 witnesses at some 79 public hearings—the El Nino effect is one of the most important. With the work that is being done on atmospheric research, at present it can be predicted a year ahead, with 50 per cent accuracy, whether there will be a dry spell or a drought, particularly the El Nino effect. We know how it starts now; it starts north of Australia, moves down through the Pacific and creates all these problems.So I was most disturbed to hear in our evidence that the Government is considering withdrawing funding for this research—something like $600,000 a year. I have not had a chance to peruse the entire Budget yet, but I have heard from Senator McMullan tonight that there is some good news in it about IEDs. I hope that there is also some good news in it of continuing funding for this research.

PARA.TAB: When I was in the United Kingdom recently on a Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conference, I had an opportunity to talk to some members of African countries who were experiencing the tremendously severe drought that is still occurring in Africa. They asked me what our country was doing about helping them. I made some inquiries and found that our Government is being reasonably generous and that over $4m has already been given in cash aid. The citizens of Australia have also been very generous in donating through various organisations. Even so, Africa is experiencing a tremendous drought.

After hearing this, I had a lot of pleasure in telling the friends that I had met in Zambia, Zimbabwe and Kenya that the research that was being carried out in Australia, with its new computer modelling, has the ability—it was demonstrated to us in very logical terms—to forecast the same El Nino effect in regard to the east coast of Africa. So if we continue this research, and if the computer modelling is allowed to continue over the next few years, there is every chance that in three or four years time we will be 75 per cent accurate in predicting drought, not only on the east coast of Australia but also on the east coast of Africa. What better form of aid could we give to our African neighbours than to allow them to predict droughts and to drought-proof themselves to a certain extent for the dry spells as they came along?

That was one of the key recommendations of the Committee and one of the key issues that came through the whole report—that the farmers want to drought-proof themselves; they want to be self-reliant. But, of course, every now and again we get these conditions which snowball and we end up with the situation that we have in some areas of Australia where assistance is needed. I am pleased to see that the Government has given some sort of aid—$14m.

Senator Panizza has just told me that El Nino means `the baby'. I just hope that the baby is not thrown out with the bath water when research is being done on El Nino, as we certainly need that research to continue.

I am pleased to see that most of the things that we identified have also been worked on by the New South Wales Government and I note that Mr Fahey, the new Premier of New South Wales, is increasing rural transport subsidies from $3m to $5m, which will be of great assistance to farmers.

One of the other things that I noticed in this press report—it was touched on earlier tonight—was rural counselling. Senator West took a particular interest in this. It is certainly not a very enjoyable job that these rural counsellors have. We spoke to quite a few of them. In fact, a lot of them needed counselling themselves after a certain amount of time because they were getting worn down by the tales of degradation and of the sorrow and bad luck that people are experiencing. The rural counsellor out in the area that I believe is the worst affected, the area out near Bourke, is dealing with 70 people with a combined debt of $30m. One can just imagine the problems they must have. One has to ask oneself whether they will ever get out of that debt and survive; I do not think a lot of them will.

I just hope that in the Budget Papers tonight there might be a bit of help. I have already heard that there is very little assistance, if any, or any hope for small business, the private sector of our community. If that runs through the Budget, as I think it does, the farmers cannot hold out much hope. The drought that we looked at and reported on is the worst for 12 years in the Bourke area, with stock losses up to 90 per cent.

Another area that has not been touched on tonight but which I was impressed by—it does not necessarily follow that this happens in every State—was the role that local government plays in some areas, particularly New South Wales, in sharing the burden of a natural disaster such as drought. I was pleased to hear about some of the things that the shire councils in the western division of New South Wales are doing; for instance, rate relief for land-holders, provision of work on shire projects, hiring equipment from farmers to give them a better cash flow, allowing grazing on public land and maintaining those very important stock routes and public watering facilities that are needed during drought.

Most important—this has already been touched on tonight—is the participation in programs to reduce pests and feral animals. In these dry times we had evidence that some farms are overstocked by feral animals or kangaroos before even one head of sheep, cattle or anything else is put on them. This shows the effect that native animals such as kangaroos and feral animals such as wild horses, rabbits and the like are having on what is already a critical situation.

The Committee made a lot of recommendations. I just hope that the Government takes some note of them. The task force handed down its recommendations in 1990. This report comes in 1992. I do not know whether we will be looking at it again in 1994 or some such time to see what has happened. But I can assure you, Mr Acting Deputy President—the Chairman of the Committee has already made this point—that we will be reviewing this to see what is happening. Unless we do, this report will be like a lot of other reports in this place that just end up gathering dust on a shelf.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak tonight to the Government responses to the recommendations of the drought policy review task force. Although I was not a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, I have certainly listened with a great deal of interest to what some of the members of the Committee have told us about the trips that they have had and the investigations that they have carried out into drought. It is something that I believe all members of the Senate should be most interested in. The beginning of the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout the inquiry, the Committee was impressed with the fortitude and resilience of the farming community. Time and again, the Committee was told by members of this important section of the Australian community that they do not want handouts, they want to be self-reliant but must be given the opportunity to prepare for drought.

Senator Calvert said that he was looking at the photographs in this report. I was quite interested to see a couple of photographs in the report; I think it helps to make it interesting for those of us who were not there and to let us know of the tremendous amount of work that the Committee has put into this report to make it something that we are all able to read and take part in. Page 1 of the report says:

The Task Force recognised that drought is a natural and recurring condition and therefore is a normal commercial risk that should be included in the management decisions of Australian rural enterprises. Consequently, managing for drought is about managing for the risks involved in undertaking a farm business, given the vagaries of climate and the prospects of variable seasonal conditions.

I have a son who lives on a property on the McKenzie River in central Queensland. He has been there for about 10 years and he has had two terrible droughts. It cost an enormous amount of money to buy enough fodder to make sure that his cattle did not die. Because he is on the McKenzie River, he has also had two terrible floods. I have yet to decide which is worse—the droughts or the floods. The floods bring down weeds from further up and they whisk cattle away. In one case the poor bulls were so big and heavy they could not swim and they all went down. Quite a lot of the stock were taken away and ended up miles and miles down the river.

PARA.TAB: It is very difficult to manage for drought; we just never know when it is coming. It is certainly a very expensive business to have enough fodder to keep cattle going. I just hope that before long there will be some rain in his part of Queensland because a tremendous amount of Queensland is suffering from drought at present.

The Committee sought this reference from the Senate because it was concerned that, although some of the recommendations of the 1990 report of the drought policy review task force had been implemented, in two years most of them had not been acted upon. In the past two years, when very few of the recommendations were applied, many areas in Australia have been, or have become, gripped with drought. That is what Senator Calvert and Senator Brownhill were speaking to the Senate about earlier. Only today the front page of Brisbane's Courier-Mail noted:

SPEECH.PARA: Drought gripping Queensland is set to strip hundreds of millions of dollars from the State's battered rural economy as sheep die by the thousands, weakened cattle flood onto the market and crops fail.

I saw a very sad picture in our paper a few days ago of a man in Charleville who was trying to keep his sheep alive by bulldozing down some of the brigalow scrub around the place. He would work in Charleville during the week and go out at the weekend to try to keep his remaining 2,000 sheep alive so that when the drought breaks, which we hope will be soon, he will at least be able to have some stock on his property.

PARA.TAB: The report notes further that the drought is spreading from the west and north into the State's top wheat country. Summer rains largely failed through the centre of the State and now, at the end of winter, there has been very little useful rain. The report notes in the foreword:

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout the inquiry, the Committee was impressed with the fortitude and resilience of the farming community. Time and again, the Committee was told by members of this important section of the Australian community—
as I said earlier—
that they do not want handouts.

That is what the farming community is like. It is very self-reliant and very anxious to do the best it can with what it has. It certainly has not been given the chance to prepare for what is now referred to as a natural and recurring condition. I often wonder when the Government will stop sitting on its hands and start doing something useful to help the drought-stricken Queensland primary producer.

PARA.TAB: I did note that the Senate Committee report also recommends that financial assistance be provided to farmers experiencing severe drought. It also has recognised that there is an essential role for the Commonwealth to play in relieving farmers from this severe drought. One point that was brought out by a number of members of the Committee is the fact that $14m has been made available by the Government for drought assistance. But there are lots of people everywhere around Australia in the drought areas, not only in Queensland but in New South Wales and so many other parts of Australia. It is very difficult to make $14m go around to the areas that really need it.
There is no doubt that we need the Government to stand behind our primary producers and to accept the fact that they have a major role to play in the prosperity and financial recovery of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—That is right. If this Government lacks that resolve then it does not deserve to represent anybody, let alone the farmers and their families who contribute so much to Australia's real wealth. Senator Boswell told me that in the Budget tonight farmers have not got anything that will help them very much at all. In fact, he said they will be going the other way, down the drain. I certainly believe that our rural people, particularly in good seasons, play a vital and important role in our export earnings; there is no doubt about that.

PARA.TAB: What gives the drought crisis we face special importance is the fact that it comes on top of a rural crisis. Increased costs by the Government, depressed commodity prices, high interest rates, and the collapse of the wool floor price scheme have already set farmers and farming families reeling. Even before the drought started they were in a bad financial position. That is why it is not possible for them always to prepare for drought, as the report says they should. That is why there are so many families throughout the bush already facing financial ruin.

Health care workers in remote Australia are also discovering for the first time in postwar memory actual poverty and actual near starvation. Furthermore, as a result of this current Government's policies, young rural Australians already have reduced opportunities for education, health services, cultural experience and future employment. I brought to the Senate this morning a notice of motion regarding that matter. The Government's failure to address this situation will lead to long-term disadvantages for rural Australians who are being denied their right to full education at both secondary and tertiary levels. Mr Acting Deputy President, you would know just how important it is for young people to have the opportunity for tertiary education.

To tell honourable senators just how bad the drought situation is in my own State of Queensland, I will read from a report published in our Courier-Mail just today. It seemed to me to be very appropriate, with the emergence of this drought report and the measures the Government, we hope, will continue to implement for people in drought situations, that this article should be in our paper today. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: More than one-quarter of Queensland is gripped by drought with a horror spring season set to batter the state economy.
Rural income will be stripped by hundreds of millions of dollars as sheep die by the thousands, weakened cattle flood onto the market and crops fail.
The drought focus has been on the extensive western and northern areas but is spreading through some of the state's best cropping country.

The queue for drought declarations is lengthening daily at the Primary Industries Department natural disaster section. . . there were now 9500 properties officially drought declared from the western Queensland border at Goondiwindi to Atherton in far north Queensland.

Several shires were expected next month to join the 21 shires already declared drought stricken. . . large areas of central and western Queensland and the far north were failing rapidly with property owners facing stock water shortages.
`There has been insufficient water to fill dams in many regions—

Regrettably, this Government did away with any tax concessions for farmers who wanted to build dams. That, I believe, is one of the problems that is confronting people facing droughts at the present time. We used to be able to get tax concessions for making dams and provision for water on our properties, but that was all taken away, and that has not helped in any situation at all. The Courier-Mail further notes that the Department had received:
. . . reports from Bollon and Charleville districts of 30 to 40 per cent flock losses. . . For many people it is just not a viable proposition to buy feed.'
In addition:
. . . freight costs to move stock would be more than the sheep were worth in many cases.
There had been a huge exodus of cattle from the worst affected areas, particularly the north. Movements of 25,000 head a week were putting pressure on already shaky markets.
The article continues, stating that rainfalls:
. . . for the 16 months to the end of June were the lowest since 1946 at Blackall and Tambo.
Charleville was the driest since records were instigated 47 years ago.

It is no wonder that poor man was having so much trouble keeping some feed up to the 2,000 sheep that were left on his property. Mr Acting Deputy President, if you could have seen the photograph in the paper, you would have realised just how bad it really was—and he had already lost 8,000 sheep; he had been unable to save them. So it is very bad indeed out in the west.

PARA.TAB: The Labor Party talks loudly about social justice, but rural people apparently are not part of the social justice program. Its economic policies have already been ruinous to anyone trying to contribute to the productivity of the nation. Those of us who inhabit this nation are all Australians. But I tell honourable senators that we are two nations in terms of financial opportunity: those who are fortunate enough to live in metropolitan Australia, and those discriminated against by living in rural or remote Australia.

I believe that, regrettably, this Government has helped to create these two nations. It has done nothing to try to bridge the rift. Indeed, its policies have contributed to a disturbing widening of the gulf between these two sections of our nation. So often we find that its neglect effectively punishes those who for a variety of reasons choose not to live in the cities and the big rural towns. I regret to say that to be a non-metropolitan Australian under this Government is to be second class, a member of the B team, a reserve grade Australian.

In the last few years I have made quite a number of speeches on each of these subjects as they have become more and more critical to our national financial welfare. They also involve the disintegration of a lifestyle and society which have served Australia well in the past. If we fail any—I reiterate the word `any'—of our rural industries now, we will continue to see the disintegration of rural Australian society as many of us have known.

It has been very distressing to note that the profound shift in Australia's export earnings from farm products to other economic sectors has left primary producers with shrinking incomes. These changes mean that we simply cannot afford to sit back and wait for the farm sector to be virtually depopulated, which is starting to happen all over Australia. It is not only happening in south Burnett, where I come from, but also in many other rural areas.

The Government cannot claim that the crisis and the drought in rural Australia has only just hit. It has been warned continuously for years. The evidence to show just what is happening outside our major cities has been around for quite some time. It is in the interests of everyone to control the process, to ameliorate its worst effects and to approach the whole issue with a balance of sympathy and energy.

The Minister must seriously consider the recommendations for the introduction of special drought loans and tax credits for expenditure directly related to drought proofing a specific farm. There certainly is a need to recommend the reinstatement of natural disaster relief arrangements in the case of severe droughts. It is disappointing that the Committee did not decide to recommend this to the Government, but I suppose it is not always easy to bring in everything that one thinks is necessary.

It is important that a government looks after the interests of non-metropolitan as well as metropolitan Australia and brings them together in a single nation where fairness and equity prevail. I congratulate the members of the Committee on the tremendous work that they have done in presenting this report. I certainly look forward to the Government acting on many of the recommendations that the Committee has submitted.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, I also rise to speak on the final report entitled A National Drought Policy—Appropriate Government responses to the recommendations of the Drought Policy Review Task Force. I will begin by reiterating some of the comments made by other members of the Committee. I thank the secretariat for the tremendous work it did. I am sure it also enjoyed it, particularly when we visited places such as Bourke, Dubbo and the south coast of Western Australia. I think the secretariat did a tremendous job not only in the preparation of this report and the organisation of the Committee but also in the interim report which was put out at very short notice.

PARA.TAB: I also wish to acknowledge the very fair way Senator Burns chaired the various meetings. The process which we developed this year with this inquiry was mentioned earlier tonight. The people who attended were invited to make a short statement of three to five minutes from the floor. I suggested this course because in other inquiries one often heard pearls of wisdom over a cup of coffee; they would never be recorded. I was very pleased that that course was followed.

When one looks at records and figures of the Australian economy, it is very apparent that when the bush is doing well the community is also doing well. That is a fact. For instance, in 1982-83 we found that when the recovery occurred in the farming and grazing sector it flowed right through the economy. It is very important that, when we consider such things as the national drought policy, we look at the overall impact on the economy.

This report is a report that should never have happened. It should not have been necessary for us to present such a report. This report came about because of a number of events. When we were considering the Committee's interim report we talked about the report of the task force which came down in May 1990, which is now well over two years ago. That report has virtually sat gathering dust.

I just want to take the Senate back a little further. In 1986-87 I sat on a national drought committee which brought down a report for then Minister Kerin. The Department and the Minister did not like that report. So that one was put on the shelf and allowed to gather dust. The next drought policy review task force brought down a report which, while not identical, was very similar to the report that was brought down in 1987.

As part of a national drought policy there is a need, first of all, for consistency between States. There is a need to identify the responsibilities of the States, the Commonwealth and local government. It has been very clear for a long time that there has been much inconsistency in the policies of the various States and the way in which they are treated by the Commonwealth.

There have also been inconsistencies in the way in which drought has been determined in the various regions. For example, we found that drought is a regular feature in certain areas. Yet we also found that significantly harder criteria for the purposes of drought declaration applied to other regions which are significantly drier. I think it is very important that there be consistency across the full range of drought policy.

In the time that is available to me I would like to look at some of the specific recommendations that have come out of the report of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs. There are two things that we can say are significantly different, or on which much more emphasis has been placed, when we compare our report with the report of the drought policy review task force. The first is that we put much more emphasis on the importance of tax credits as a means of achieving self-reliance, and I will say a little more about that later.

Secondly, we recommended that in times of severe drought there is a role for the Commonwealth to play. Transaction levies are part of the role that the Commonwealth should play in protecting the national herd and the sheep flock. Transaction levies should be administered in such a way that they assist in preserving the breeding flock in the national interest and returning the breeding flock to the property of origin. There is no doubt that under the previous arrangements there was some rorting of the system in some States. It is not difficult to overcome that problem. I believe that we addressed that aspect.

I was very pleased to see that the Committee reached a unanimous position on its recommendations in respect of a national drought policy. I have to say I did not expect that that would be the case when I attended the last meeting. But we came to similar conclusions as we worked through the various recommendations and we were able to reach a unanimous position.

As far as a national drought policy is concerned, consistent with previous reports it was agreed that emphasis should be placed on self-reliance. It is important that transitional arrangements be put in place to allow a change from previous drought policies. It is unreasonable for farmers affected by drought, as it is for people in any industry, not to be given time to adjust to new circumstances brought about by a policy switch put in place virtually overnight. We put some emphasis on the importance of transitional arrangements.

I have noted what other speakers have said here tonight on a number of matters. I particularly wish to comment on Senator Bjelke-Petersen's comments that she was disappointed that we did not move back to having drought included in the natural disaster relief arrangements. I do not think whether or not it is in there is important, provided we have a comprehensive, proper national drought policy. I have no doubt that it can work within natural disaster relief arrangements, but it can also work outside the natural disaster relief arrangements.

There is one significant difference between drought and other disasters such as flood, cyclone or fire. They are events that generally occur very quickly. They are over and done with and they fit neatly into a financial year. Under the previous natural disaster relief arrangements, if a drought started a couple of months before the end of the financial year, people had to commence 1 July on a new financial trigger, even though they had been suffering a drought for a couple of months. A drought creeps up, whereas these other events often occur overnight and usually last no longer than a day or two or a week. I think it is important that, whether the drought policy be in or out, it be recognised that it is quite different in the way it creeps up on us.

I want to comment in particular on the rural adjustment scheme and evidence that was given to us regarding it. I am very concerned about the rural adjustment scheme. I think it, unfortunately, has failed Australian agriculture. I am particularly concerned that it is now being asked to be all things to all people. Concern was expressed to us during the hearings about the fact that drought has come under the rural adjustment scheme. Concern was also expressed that the social security arrangements for farmers have come under the rural adjustment scheme. The problem is that the Rural Adjustment Authority does not have the expertise to handle these matters.

From my previous experiences on the drought consultative committee in Western Australia, I believe that when drought was handled by a different arrangement, separate from the Rural Adjustment Authority, it did not get mixed up and confused with the various parts A, B and C of the rural adjustment scheme. The problem with the Rural Adjustment Authority, which is subject to review, is that when people go before it, if it happens to point what I call the big finger C—that is, part C—they should run 100 miles, because as soon as it does that, that is the finish. It is virtually saying, `You are out of farming and there will be no assistance'.

As soon as that happens, banks, stock firms, financiers, suppliers and everybody else walks away. My advice to people in agriculture, whether farming or pastoral, is that when the rural adjustment authorities, no matter in which State they are, start signifying that they are a candidate for part C, they should get out of the door as quickly as they can run, because that is the death knell. It will determine by the stroke of a pen whether people are viable or non-viable. In my view, one is never non-viable until one gives up. It should not be determined by somebody with a stroke of a pen, depending on the particular situation.

I know my time is drawing to an end and I would like to continue these remarks at another time. I must comment on a couple of other aspects, particularly the tax arrangements regarding tax credits, which is a recommendation that we put before the Government. Tax credits have a significant advantage over the current arrangements, in that they are much fairer and more equitable. When a particular operation has a problem with drought and tries to get into self-reliance, very seldom is it paying much tax so taxation arrangements, in terms of depreciation, are of little value. It would be far more equitable and fair if the Government were to put in place a system of tax credits, as recommended by the Committee, to the tune of 75 per cent of the highest marginal tax rate, whatever that might be. I recommend to the Minister for Primary Industries that he pursue our recommendation.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m, I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Death of Lord Cheshire and Mr Colin McCaskill

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I place on the record my personal regret at the passing of two great men, one an Australian and one an Englishman. Both people have done great things for this country and for humanity. They both gave great service for and in the name of charity.

PARA.TAB: Group Captain Leonard Cheshire, VC, DSO, DFC and, more recently, Lord Cheshire—a peerage received in recognition of his many and great charitable works—was an extraordinary gentleman by any judgment. As Britain's most decorated World War II aviator, he was a veteran of more than a 100 bombing raids on Europe and leader of the famous 617 Squadron, which developed a method of low level marking.

For many men, a successful wartime career would be enough, but not for Leonard Cheshire. After the war, he established the Cheshire Homes, which has 270 homes in 50 countries for the sick and disabled. The Ryder Cheshire Foundation is known worldwide for its work among displaced persons and their descendants. The Ryder connection came from his wife, Baroness Ryder. It was originally in this connection that he made several visits to Australia.

I had the honour to meet Lord Cheshire when he visited Australia on his latest charitable work—that of establishing the world disaster fund. His aim was to raise a dollar for every person in the world killed during World War II to establish a permanent fund which would be available to assist when natural disaster struck anywhere in the world. He was actively and enthusiastically supported by many people in his work in Australia. Among them was the Reverend John Fincher from Quirindi, which is my home town. It was through the enthusiasm of John Fincher that I first became involved in this fund, about which I have spoken in the Senate on several occasions. All honourable senators will know that Senator Reid is on a committee involved in it in Canberra.

The world owes a great debt to Lord Cheshire, and we give praise to his life and his many great works. I heard only tonight from my brother-in-law, who is here visiting me, that he actually played very good tennis with him at Orange at one time.

The second man to whom I wish to pay tribute is Colin McCaskill, a name which for decades has been synonymous with the RSPCA. In fact, Colin McCaskill was the RSPCA. As Executive Director for many years, Colin took the organisation from a small home for lost dogs to a $1m-plus enterprise, encompassing a much wider charter and bringing the work of the RSPCA to the notice of the community.

Colin McCaskill never missed an opportunity to raise the plight of animals subjected to man's inhumanity. Indeed, it was his dedication and sheer hard work that brought in so many legacies and donations that enabled the RSPCA to expand its services and to broaden its message to the point where today it is the peer authority on animal welfare in this country.

For many years, Colin, ably assisted by his wife Pat, who ran RSPCA volunteer shops, and his daughter, Marie, who acted as the PR director, was the voice of animal welfare, not only in New South Wales but throughout Australia. He was also the foundation secretary of the RSPCA Australia.

Colin retired from the position of New South Wales Executive Director after 20 years of very active service. However, his interest and involvement did not cease there. He continued to be an RSPCA councillor and an active and respected member of the New South Wales Animal Welfare Advisory Council, the Animals in Research Panel and the ethics committees of Macquarie University and the University of New South Wales. Animal welfare in Australia has much to thank Colin McCaskill for. I place on record my personal thanks for all the assistance Colin gave me over the years and express my condolences to Mrs McCaskill and Marie. Two great people in the world have left us in the last few weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with considerable sadness that I wish to pay tribute to the life and work of Dr Robert Hill, who died here in Canberra on 25 July at the age of just 38 years. In his short but brilliant career he represented many of the attributes that this country needs so badly. He had great talent and he pursued it relentlessly. He knew the value of education and research and encouraged it endlessly amongst his colleagues and his students. He appreciated more than anything that he was Australian, and although he had many international opportunities to follow his many scientific skills, he chose to stay in Canberra and spent his time with the ANU. The whole of Australia will be the loser by his death.

PARA.TAB: Dr Hill's dedication to excellence was a great example to everyone in so many ways. He wanted Australia to be a top research country and worked very hard to spread his efforts amongst his colleagues, members of parliament and business interests. He gave a lot and he expected a lot. When Anutech put on an exhibition in Parliament House last year it was Dr Hill who did much of the preparation and presentation. He accepted that if he could not get the parliamentarians to science, then he would bring science to them.

He was always keen to do anything he could to advance the cause of education, science and research in Australia generally. With his ability, dedication and leadership capacities, everyone who knew him was expecting him to be a leader in our community for many years to come; but regrettably that was not to be. The sudden death of Dr Robert Hill is a national tragedy as well as a great personal loss to his wife, Dr Sally Rigden, and daughters Ashley and Carolyn. I trust this great scientist will be remembered for the contribution he has made and the example he has set Australians at large.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight marks the seventeenth major economic statement by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, and his cohorts since 1983. When considering tonight's Budget it is probably interesting to look at what Mr Keating said in some of these previous 17 major economic statements. I refer honourable senators to the 1983-84 Budget in which Mr Keating said, `There will be considerable improvement in the coming year'. In that year foreign debt rose from $23 billion to $29 billion. In the 1984-85 Budget Mr Keating said, `The Government's policies are now on track'.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I seek your ruling as to whether the rule against anticipation applies in this respect. My understanding is that the Budget is a matter that is before the Parliament in a whole variety of contexts and is on the Notice Paper. Under those circumstances, Senator Macdonald is essentially out of order in using the adjournment to begin a Budget debate which we have not yet started. I seek your ruling on that matter because otherwise the adjournment debate could be filled up for nights ahead with Budget discussion.
—On the point of order, Mr Deputy President, I am not going to refer at all to tonight's Budget. I am not going to refer to it except in the context in which I have referred to it so far.
—As long as the honourable senator does not refer to tonight's Budget, he will be in order.

—It is interesting to note how sensitive the Labor Party is when its past inefficiencies and misstatements are brought to the attention of the Australian public. As I said, in the 1984-85 Budget Mr Keating said, `The Government's policies are now on track'. In that year the foreign debt rose to $51 billion. In the 1985-86 Budget, Mr Keating said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have produced a new strategy for the coming year—it will be very successful financially.
In that year the foreign debt rose to $76 billion. In the 1986-87 Budget Mr Keating said, `My plan for this year is a more robust economy'. In that year the foreign debt rose to $86 billion.

PARA.TAB: In the 1987-88 Budget Mr Keating said:

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I can report that Australia is winning.
In that year another 8,504 Australian businesses went bankrupt. He said further in that Budget:
We have turned the corner and the big gaps in the trade accounts have begun to close. . . This is an achievement of historic proportions.
Further, he said:
The Government's policy response has been innovative, strong and most of all, right.
Further, he said:
. . . our economic strategy is now bearing fruit.
He then said that this Budget:
. . . stands as a monument to the competence and compassion of this Government.
In that year, Mr Deputy President, the foreign debt rose to $96 billion.

PARA.TAB: In the 1988-89 Budget Mr Keating said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we are well on the way back to prosperity.
He then said:
This is the one which brings home the bacon.
In that year he also said:
Our foreign debt has begun to fall.
In fact, in that year the foreign debt rose to $117 billion and 7,435 more businesses went bankrupt.

PARA.TAB: In the 1989-90 Budget the Treasurer said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a budget without gimmicks—without resort to quick fixes. It is a budget which puts the nation's interests first.
In that year the foreign debt rose to $129 billion and another 8,552 Australian businesses went bankrupt. In the 1989 Budget Speech the Treasurer said:
As a result of the government's economic policies, Australia will emerge from the recent high level of spending without a recession, and with its economic and social structure improving.
In that year the unemployment rate rose from 6 per cent to 7.3 per cent and another 122,600 Australians joined the dole queue.

PARA.TAB: In the 1990-91 Budget the Treasurer said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a budget that will keep us in the right financial shape as we enter the 1990s. It will give us a very solid foundation for whatever we as a nation have the courage to undertake.
In that year the foreign debt rose to $137 billion. He further said:
These are the Rolls Royce of Budget documents in the OECD. That's the most comprehensive, quality set of budget documents in the OECD area.
In that same year 13,091 businesses went bankrupt. Further, the Treasurer said:
This year our financial situation will markedly improve—without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession.
In that year the unemployment rate rose from 7.3 per cent to 9.8 per cent and another 225,100 of our fellow Australians joined the dole queue. In the 1991 industry statement it was stated:
The package announced today deals with our underlying structural problems. . .
In that year we were in the depths of the worst recession that this country had seen in 60 years.

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating's replacements during his leadership campaign were no more successful in the Treasury position than he was. In the 1991 Budget Mr Kerin said:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is set for recovery in 1991-92.
He further said:
. . . economic recovery is on the way.

In that year the foreign debt rose to $148 billion and 16,803 Australian businesses went bankrupt. The unemployment rate climbed to 11.1 per cent and another 117,400 Australians have since joined the dole queue. In September 1991 Ralph Willis promised:
. . . in the course of 1992 it is reasonable to expect that we could be back to employment growth in the order of nearly 200,000 jobs.
But by the end of July, only 31,300 more persons had work whilst in the same period another 65,500 lost their jobs.

PARA.TAB: In the 1992 One Nation statement Mr Keating said:

SPEECH.PARA: This statement is the largest single package of constructive measures and approaches that I've been associated with.
Further, he said:
We have the essentials for a strong recovery. The measures I have announced tonight will harness them.

But since that One Nation statement 51,800 more Australians have lost their jobs; 3,886 Australian businesses have become bankrupt; the foreign debt has continued to rise beyond $148 billion; unemployment has continued to rise—it is now 11 per cent—and some 2 million of our fellow Australians are either unemployed or underemployed.

PARA.TAB: The Government should have listened to Senator Peter Walsh. Even the dumped ex-Minister for Finance said some time ago that Labor had `stuffed Australia's economy', and he warned the Government earlier this year that the One Nation statement was based on rubbery figures. This is Senator Peter Walsh, the ALP senator, warning the Government that the One Nation statement was based on rubbery figures. He was asked whether the growth estimate of 4.5 per cent in the One Nation statement was realistic, and in the April 1992 edition of the Australian Left Review he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I doubt that it should be taken seriously.

They are Senator Peter Walsh's words. The coalition said that the One Nation statement was a sham and that it was based on dodgy figures. Senator Peter Walsh also said that about the dodgy figures. This has been shown to be true.

PARA.TAB: Tonight's Budget statement was the seventeenth major economic statement by the Labor Party since 1983. In that period, unemployment has risen from 691,000 to around 2 million unemployed and underemployed fellow Australians. Foreign debt has blown out from $23 billion to around $150 billion. I am sure that the Australian public will have no faith in the Prime Minister's seventeenth major economic statement, given his record of dismal failure in the previous years.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 27 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Royal Commission into Productivity in the Building Industry in New South Wales:

(1) Was evidence given to the Commission that the Master Builders' Association (MBA), with the knowledge of the NSW Building Services Corporation, diverted millions of dollars provided by both Commonwealth and NSW Governments for the express purpose of funding an MBA apprentice training scheme.
(2) Was the MBA scheme initiated in 1977 as a `non-profit' scheme.
(3) Was evidence given to the Commission that the MBA scheme was, in fact, profitable for the MBA.
(4) Will an investigation be conducted under the Trade Practices Act or any other relevant legislation, into whether the MBA's actions constitute an offence.

(5) Was evidence given to the Commission that the MBA had been a party to secret commissions relating to tenders over the past 10 years; if so, will this evidence be investigated to decide if appropriate criminal proceedings should be issued.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am advised that evidence was given that the MBA scheme was generating large surpluses which were used for the general purposes of the MBA. I am advised that no evidence was given that the Commonwealth provided monies to the MBA for the express purpose of funding an MBA apprentice training scheme.
(2) I am advised that the scheme was promoted by the MBA as a non-profit scheme.
(3) I am advised that evidence was given to the Royal Commission that surplus funds, generated by the MBA scheme, were treated as profit by the MBA.
(4) I am advised that matters arising from the Royal Commission are under investigation by relevant Commonwealth agencies.

(5) I am advised that evidence was given to the Royal Commission that the MBA had received secret payments from successful tenderers. Also, I am advised that evidence was given that MBA officers arranged and were present at meetings of tenderers during which agreements were made that the successful tenderer would make payments to unsuccessful tenderers. Further, I am advised that evidence was given that the MBA sought to collect unsuccessful tenderer fees from the successful tenderer on behalf of its members and that the MBA may have set-off in its accounts monies owed by a successful tenderer to an unsuccessful tenderer both of whom had MBA accounts. I am advised that matters arising from the Royal Commission are under investigation by the relevant Commonwealth agencies.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 14 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Attorney-General's reply to Question on Notice No. 1143 (Senate Hansard, 17 October 1991, p 2354)

(1) Once an area of Australia has been inscribed on the World Heritage List, what procedures are lawfully open to allow the boundaries of that area to be: (a) increased; or (b) decreased, whether to a minor or major degree.
(2) What procedure was followed by Australia so that Stage 3 of Kakadu National Park, as now proclaimed, was nominated for World Heritage Listing.

(3) What is the legal status of the Operational Guidelines issued under the World Heritage Convention, in particular: (a) has the Australian Government formally acceded to, or ratified the guidelines; if so, by what means and on what date(s); and (b) by means of what Commonwealth statute do the Operational Guidelines apply in Australia.
(4) Under what international law is the World Heritage Committee appointed or selected.
(5) Who are the members of the World Heritage Committee.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: I am advised as follows:

(1) Paragraph 56 of the Operational Guidelines adopted by the World Heritage Committee sets out the procedures for increasing an area already inscribed on the World Heritage List. An extension to a property is treated as a new nomination, unless the boundary change is, in the opinion of the World Heritage Bureau, a simple modification. Neither the Operational Guidelines nor the Convention specify procedures with respect to reduction of areas on the World Heritage List. As indicated in my answer to Question on Notice No. 1143, there is provision in the Operational Guidelines for removing a property altogether from the World Heritage List in two circumstances. The first is where the property has deteriorated to the extent that it has lost the characteristics which led to its inclusion on the World Heritage List. The second is where the property was under threat at the time of its nomination to the List and the necessary corrective measures to remove the threat have not been taken within the time allowed. A removal can take place if approved by a majority of two thirds of the World Heritage Committee.
(2) Australia re-nominated the entire Kakadu National Park in order to include Stage 3 of the Park on the World Heritage List. This is consistent with paragraph 56 of the Operational Guidelines.

(3) The Operational Guidelines for the Implementation of the World Heritage Convention are adopted by the World Heritage Committee established under the World Heritage Convention. Articles 11.5 and 21.1 of the Convention require the World Heritage Committee to define the criteria on the basis of which a property may be included on the World Heritage List and the procedure for the grant of international assistance under the Convention. In fulfilment of these requirements, the Committee has adopted the Operational Guidelines for Implementation of the World Heritage Convention. Under Article 13.8 of the Convention, the Operational Guidelines are adopted by a majority of two-thirds of its members present and voting. There are 21 State members of the World Heritage Committee.

The Operational Guidelines are not binding on Australia. Nevertheless, as a matter of international law, they are evidence of the subsequent practice of the Parties in implementation of the World Heritage Convention and are able to be taken into account in the interpretation of it. There is no provision under the World Heritage Convention for Australia to formally accede to or ratify the Guidelines. Nor has Australia done so. Furthermore, there is no need for a Commonwealth Statute to apply the Operational Guidelines in Australia. The Operational Guidelines affect the Australian process of nominating properties to the World Heritage List. That process is carried out under the Executive power of the Commonwealth.

The Operational Guidelines were relied upon by Mason CJ and Brennan J of the High Court in Richardson v. Forestry Commission (1988) 164 CLR 261 at 295 and the basis for the Guidelines was referred to in the case stated to the High Court in Queensland v. the Commonwealth (1988) 167 CLR 232 at 234. Perhaps the best statement of the purpose of the Guidelines is that set out in paragraph 4 of the current Guidelines. This provides:

ANSWER.PARA: "the operational guidelines which are set out below have been prepared for the purpose of informing States Parties to the Convention of the principles which guide the work of the Committee in establishing the World Heritage List and the List of World Heritage in Danger and in granting international assistance under the World Heritage Fund. These guidelines also provide details on other questions, mainly of a procedural nature, which relate to the implementation of the Convention."

PARA.TAB: (4) The World Heritage Committee is appointed pursuant to Article 8 of the World Heritage Convention. Under that Article, it is a Committee of 21 Members which is elected by States Parties to the Convention meeting in General Assembly during the ordinary session of the General Conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation.

(5) The current members of the World Heritage Committee are: Brazil, Bulgaria, Canada, Colombia, Cuba, France, Greece, India, Indonesia, Italy, Mexico, Oman, Pakistan, Peru, Senegal, Syria, Tanzania, Thailand, Tunisia, USA, Yemen.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 29 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What criteria does the department apply in deciding whether an applicant for inclusion on lists of approved suppliers under its IT panel period contracts must, as a precondition for such listings, furnish: (a) directors' guarantees; and/or (b) bank or other financial guarantees.

(2) In the case of the PE40 panel selection process and the PE50 panel selection process: (a) how many tenderers were asked to furnish directors' and/or other financial guarantees: and (b) how many such tenderers were Australian-owned business entities and overseas companies.

(3) Has the department declined to give PE50 approved supplier status to any IT suppliers because, in its view, they would be unlikely to achieve significant sales volume under that contract; if so: (a) what is the minimum threshold sales level and what are the criteria and processes observed by DAS in deciding whether to deny approved supplier status on such grounds, (b) what steps did the department take to make such preconditions clear to tenderers prior to preparation and submission of tenders, (c) how many tenders have been excluded on such grounds, (d) how many such excluded tenders were Australian owned businesses and overseas owned companies, and (e) did the department consult the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce (DITAC) in relation to the implications for the development of indigenous IT industry of its exclusion of PE50 tenders of Australian owned companies or in relation to directors and/or financial guarantees sought from such tenderers; if not, why not; if so, was DITAC of the view that the treatment proposed was consistent with the Government's IT industry development policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Criteria (a) to determine if a director's guarantee is required, the Department first considers the availability of alternative forms of security: corporate guarantee from a parent company or other financial guarantee. If none of these are available then a director's guarantee is considered if it is likely to contribute to the effectiveness of the contract.

(b) To determine if a bank or financial guarantee is required, the Department assesses a supplier's net worth (ie. extent to which liabilities exceed assets) and the working capital (ie. current assets against current liabilities). Net worth carries the most weight in determining the company's position.
(2) (a) The Department did not seek directors' and or other financial guarantees for PE40, but sought financial guarantees from 45 tenderers for PE50.
(b) Of those who tendered and were asked for guarantees 16 were Australian owned business entities and 29 were overseas owned companies.
(3) Yes, some tenderers were refused a place on PE50 because they were unlikely to achieve significant sales volume.

(a) No minimum threshold levels were used. Assessment was based on relative demand within the product ranges. For example, dollar value for sales of PC's would not be compared with sales of communications equipment because of the general difference in the unit values of the two classes of products; a successful supplier of communications equipment may sell less in value than a PC supplier whose product is considered not to be in demand.

(b) The RFT, when circulated both in draft form and in its final form, stated that product demand under PE40, the previous contract, would be taken into account as would the representative range and number of products offered for PE50. Specifically, the evaluation methodology stated that high user demand for the company' s products under the PE40 contract would be considered.
(c) There were six companies excluded from PE50 on the grounds of low demand under PE40.
(d) Four of the companies excluded were Australian owned and the remaining two were overseas owned.

(e) There was no need to consult DITAC as the selection of suppliers was carried out within the framework of the government's Australian and New Zealand (ANZ) supplies policy. This policy does not discriminate on the basis of ownership of a supplier.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 29 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to Questions on Notice Nos 1479 (Senate Hansard 19 December 1991, W5194) and 1480 (Senate Hansard 25 February 1992, W125), relating to so-called "common user contracts":
(1) Under what provision of the law of contract can an offeree unilaterally vary the terms of an offeror's offer without voiding negotiations.

(2) Did the department state, in a letter of 24 October 1991 to companies then "on contract" for direct marketing services, etc. that "Clause 45 of the Contract will be amended" to vary the hours of operation; if so, how did the department's letter vary its contractual relationship with those who had earlier made "standing offers" on some different basis.

(3) Has the department required those "on contract" for direct marketing services, etc. to vary the hours of operation as stated in the letter of 24 October 1991; if so, has the department accepted any liability to compensate those "on contract" for additional costs incurred beyond what they warranted to incur at the time they made their standing offers.

(4) What law of the Commonwealth, now in force, gives authority for the Commonwealth Purchasing Manual Chapter 13, Section 13 to permit or require the department to review all orders placed against particular common-use contracts to determine whether certain changes in "contracts" should be made and, further, what law of the Commonwealth, now in force, permits the department to proceed to make any changes which may have been identified.
(5) Is the Commonwealth Purchasing Manual being superseded; if so, what is the formal process of supersession of parts and what are the consequences, in legal terms.

(6) Are those parts of the Commonwealth Purchasing Manual which have not been superseded delegated legislation; if so, what is the source of the delegation; if not, are the remaining parts of the manual no more than a useful reference in those subjects not yet covered by guidance material in the Commonwealth Procurement Circulars.
(7) How does a member of the public find out what laws and procedures relating to common use contracts are in force.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) As stated in my reply to the honourable senator's earlier question regarding "common user contracts" (No. 1479), the "contracts" to which he refers are not contracts in the strict legal sense. They are continuing offers by suppliers to supply goods or services at the price agreed and on specified terms and conditions if they are ordered by the Commonwealth.
The terms of common use suppliers' continuing offers are not varied unilaterally by the Commonwealth. Variations must be agreed between the parties.

(2) The Department included in a letter of 24 October 1991 advice of its intention to vary the hours of operation to bring the arrangement into line with industry practice. The letter of 24 October did not in itself vary or attempt to vary unilaterally the terms of the suppliers' continuing offers. It sought agreement of the suppliers to the proposed variation. Following suppliers' agreement to the proposal, variations were effected by formal notice of amendment.

(3) Agreement of those already "on contract" to the proposed variation had to be given before the arrangements could be varied. With the exception of one company, all suppliers have agreed to the variation. Suppliers had the opportunity to amend prices based on the varied hours in accordance with the conditions of their contracts. The Commonwealth was not liable to pay "compensation".
(4) The aspects of Commonwealth Purchasing Manual Chapter 13, Section 13 to which the honourable senator refers are matters of procedure, not matters of law.

Under the Administrative Arrangements Orders the Department of Administrative Services has a responsibility for "coordination of purchasing policy and civil purchasing". The Department issued the Commonwealth Purchasing Manual in 1984 as a source of advice and guidance for Commonwealth purchasing agencies. A Government Decision in December 1988 confirmed my Department's role as the central coordinating agency for purchasing policy and civil purchasing and expressly included control over purchasing of common use supplies as part of this role.

(5) The Commonwealth Purchasing Manual is progressively being superseded by Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines, issued by my authority, and other guidance material issued by the Department of Administrative Services. Finance Regulation 42 provides that the Minister for Administrative Services may issue guidelines about the procurement of supplies and persons performing duties in relation to the procurement of supplies are required to have regard to these guidelines. Withdrawal of redundant parts of the Manual is notified to agencies by Commonwealth Procurement Circulars. There are no consequences in legal terms resulting from the withdrawal of parts of the Commonwealth Purchasing Manual.

(6) Those parts of the Commonwealth Purchasing Manual which have not been withdrawn are not delegated legislation. They continue as a source of reference material and information on matters about which revised guidance has not been issued.

(7) Information about common use contracts for general purpose goods and services is available in a booklet titled "An Introduction to Common Use Contracting" available free of charge from the Australian Office for Better Buying. Information about common use contracts for computer equipment and services is contained in the "Information Technology Buyers' Handbook" which may be purchased from the Australian Government Publishing Service's bookshops in each capital city at a cost of $14.95.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 5 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to question on notice No 870 (Senate Hansard, 4 March 1992, W749) regarding self-drive motor vehicles:
(1) What rules and regulations apply to Public Servants using self-drive motor vehicles in Canberra, including charges raised.
(2) How many vehicles are on average used for this purpose: (a) Monday to Friday; and (b) at weekends, and what justification is there for public servants using self-drive vehicles.

(3) What part of the Department of Administrative Services fleet is based in Canberra, and how many of those vehicles are used on average: (a) by public servants; (b) by Ministers; and (c) by other parliamentary representatives.

(4) What charges are raised, against whom are those charges raised, and what is the hourly, daily and weekly rate of such charges when self-drive cars are being used: (a) by Ministers; and (b) by Public Servants.
(5) Why did it take nine months to provide the answer to my previous question on notice in relation to this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Senior Executive Service (SES) officers or equivalents are entitled to privately plated vehicles and limited private use of those vehicles. The vehicles are also for official use. Guidelines on the use of these vehicles are issued by the Department of Industrial Relations (DIR).

Commonwealth Z-plated vehicles are for official use which can extend to home garaging. Officers of the Senior Grades (A to C) and other officers may home garage Z-plated vehicles on a regular or casual basis, if approved by the agency head or delegate and deemed to be in the Commonwealth's interest.

Unauthorised passengers (a passenger whose carriage is not in the interest of the Commonwealth) must not be carried in a Commonwealth Z-plated vehicle. There are also rules on the general use of Commonwealth vehicles which cover care, maintenance, garaging and accidents etc.

The SES are obliged to make an annual after tax contribution of $500 (for a 4 cylinder vehicle) or $700 (for a 6 cylinder vehicle) towards costs. Officers of the Senior Officer Grades who home garage vehicles have a benefit value of $500 in terms of the guidelines on reimbursement of work related expenses issued by DIR. Those officers who are called on to use vehicles for official purposes on weekends and at night, including while travelling to other cities and to and from work make no payment for the use of the vehicle. Charges for the hire of the vehicles are met by the client agencies.

2 (a & b) Around 1,450 private plated self-drive vehicles are allocated to SES officers and equivalents. Those vehicles are available for private and official use throughout the week. All SES officers and equivalents are entitled to such vehicles.

Around 1,430 Z-plated self-drive vehicles are hired to client agencies. These agencies make individual decisions on the extent to which Z-plated vehicles are home garaged. The deciding factor is whether home garaging is deemed to be in the Commonwealth's interest. The details of usage of these vehicles during the week, including whether or not they are home garaged are not known to DAS.
(3) Around 2,890 vehicles comprise the Department of Administrative Services self-drive fleet in the ACT.

(a) Around 2,840 of the vehicles are used by public servants, including 430 short term hire vehicles which are predominantly used by public servants but are also available to Ministers and other Parliamentary representatives, etc.
(b) Eight self-drive vehicles are allocated to Ministers.
(c) Five self-drive vehicles are allocated to other Parliamentary representatives (Senators and Members who are not Ministers).

4 (a & b) DAS FLEET establishes charges to recover all costs from its clients. These charges are made against the Minister's department or client agency. The same rates of charge apply to both Ministers and public servants; the charge is deterrnined by the service type and the type of vehicle.

For example it would currently cost a Commonwealth department $100 per week for a fully fuelled and maintained Ford Laser GL or $125 per week for a Holden Commodore Executive sedan. Where there is a private use component, DAS FLEET would provide these vehicles registered, comprehensively insured and maintained but without fuel. The rates per week under this arrangement would be $111 for the Laser and $127 for the Commodore. For short term hires the corresponding prices are $41 and $52 daily (a day being the shortest hire period available).
5. The Senator's previous question required input from a number of areas of the Department. However, it should have been processed much more expeditiously and the Department apologises for the delay.
