TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 19 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the symptoms of exposure to the main sprays used in cotton growing in Australia.
(2) How many people involved in cotton growing have sought medical attention with any of these symptoms during the last year for which data are available.

(3) What statutory obligations require those responsible for the application of chemical sprays in respect of the cotton industry, such as pilots and managers of cotton plantations, to ensure that those who may be affected by sprays, such as cotton workers and residents, are aware of the symptoms of exposure to these chemicals.
(4) What statutory obligations are in place to ensure that waterways are not in any way contaminated by chemical sprays used in agriculture and pest and weed control.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) There are approximately 20 different insecticidal chemicals, 18 herbicides and 6 defoliants/ conditioners which may be used on cotton. Without individual chemicals being identified it is not possible to list specific symptoms of exposure. However, of the 20 different insecticidal chemicals which may be used on cotton, these can be grouped structurally into four main types viz organophosphates, synthetic pyrethroids, carbamates and non-persistent organochlorines.
The general symptoms of poisoning by each of these groups are:

organophosphates—headache, fatigue, giddiness, salivation, sweating, blurred vision and pin point pupils, chest tightness, nausea, abdominal cramps and diarrhoea. When absorbed they inactivate cholinesterase enzymes in the body and may lead to muscular spasms.
synthetic pyrethroids—nasal irritation and sneezing may occur. Facial numbness is reported in some individuals.

carbamates—symptoms are very similar to those associated with organophosphates but enzyme activity recovery is comparatively rapid non-persistent organochlorines—restlessness, increased excitability and localised muscular twitching.
Many of these symptoms can also occur in non chemical exposure situations.

(2) The Commonwealth does not keep records that would enable figures to be determined as to the number of people involved in cotton growing who exhibited these symptoms and sought medical attention during the last year. Enquiries to the National Injury Surveillance Unit of the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services indicate that this type of data would be unlikely to be collected by their Injury Surveillance Information System and a search of that system showed nil incidence resulting from `injury' and `poisoning' or other exposure to chemical agents on cotton farms.

In New South Wales, the Moree District Hospital Agricultural Health Unit conducted a survey of Accidental Exposure to Pesticides (LJ Clarke and C Leatherman) published as Occasional Paper 89/1. The survey covered the period May 1983 to April 1988 and involved doctor's surgeries, hospital inpatient records and the NSW Department of Industrial Relations, Division of Occupational Health. The Study was undertaken to identify the degree to which accidental exposure with commonly used pesticides causes acute and chronic toxicity in the population of North-West New South Wales. Over the five year period 47 exposures were reported from doctor's surgeries of which 12 were hospitalised and 11 confirmed by pathology. Of the 47 exposures, 41 were occupational, 4 non-occupational and 2 not stated. Two of the non-occupational exposures were attributed to spray drift and 2 to childhood poisoning. Three fatalities are recorded but no details are provided.

A study by Queensland Health into community exposure in the Emerald district to insecticides during the 1990/91 cotton growing season concluded that spraying has not posed a threat to public health in that district. The report `Community Exposure to Insecticides in Emerald During the 1990-1991 Cotton Growing Season' provides a detailed account of the study undertaken.

(3) Statutory obligations concerning responsibility for application of chemical sprays rests with the appropriate State governments. In New South Wales agricultural pilots are licensed under the Pesticides Act and in Queensland under the Agricultural Chemicals Distribution Control Act 1966. Both these States also licence contractors who own and operate aircraft for aerial application purposes. Licensing is based on obtaining an Agricultural Pilots Rating by examination conducted by the Civil Aviation Authority and subsequent examination at State level based on the publication "Aerial Agriculture—Chemical Rating Manual". Agricultural pilots are required to have a sound knowledge of chemical safety including the identification of the common symptoms of pesticide poisoning and emergency treatment procedures.

Employers have a general responsibility under occupational health and safety legislation to provide a safe workplace. The anticipated adoption by the States of uniform national Workplace Hazardous Substances Regulations proposed by Worksafe Australia will strengthen these requirements. In Queensland, the Workplace Health and Safety Act 1989 sets out strict provisions concerning workplace health and safety.

(4) In New South Wales there is a strict requirement under the Pesticides Act 1976, that a person must follow the directions on the pesticide label including those directed at protection of the environment while in Queensland the Poisons Regulations 1973 govern the use and disposal of pesticides.

The Clean Waters Act, administered by the NSW Environment Protection Authority, makes it an offence to discharge a pollutant, including a pesticide, into natural waterways and provides for substantial penalties.
In Queensland, the Clean Waters Act and the Water Resources Act place statutory obligations on chemical applicators and make it an offence to discharge contaminated water from cotton farms.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 28 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Have Australian veterans of the 1945-1975 era been afforded the recognition for their war service, and their participation in warlike and often hazardous operations, which has been given to the veterans of World War II, 1939-1945, and their peers of the post 1975 era.

(2) Does the Minister support official recognition by Australia, by way of a special Defence Force medal, of veterans who served this country in the Occupation Force in Japan, those who took part in the campaigns in Korea, Malaya, and Malayan Peninsula, Borneo and Vietnam, those participants in the HMAS VOYAGER disaster, including casualties, survivors and rescuers, in the United Nations peacekeeping forces pre-1975, in nuclear tests and in the Berlin Airlift.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Australian veterans of the post World War II era have been eligible to be awarded campaign medals provided that their service met the qualifying conditions similar to those that applied to World War II.
(2) Australian veterans who participated in warlike activities such as Korea, Borneo, Malaya, the Malayan Peninsula and Vietnam have been afforded recognition of their service.

The Government of the day was aware of the conditions experienced by the British Occupation Force in the former hostile territories of Japan but decided that because the service was not operational it did not warrant recognition with an award.
Australians could qualify for two Service Medals during the Korean War, the Korea Medal and the United Nations Medal Clasp Korea.
Service in the Malayan and Borneo conflicts attracted a General Service Medal (1962) with Clasp Malay Peninsula and/or Clasp Borneo.
Service in the Vietnam War attracted the Vietnam Medal and the Vietnamese Campaign Medal.
Apart from campaign medals, Australians were also eligible to have their service recognised with individual decorations for gallantry and distinguished service.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 28 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What will be the economic impact of the new $4 toll each way for trucks and heavy transport using the new F4 Motorway in western Sydney.
(2) Will the $4 toll be a detrimental cost impost or a positive benefit to industry and business in western Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: There does not seem to be a simple clear-cut answer to the Honourable Senator's question. The Commonwealth Government has not undertaken any studies of the economic impact of the $4 toll for trucks and heavy vehicles using the new F4 Motorway in Western Sydney, nor has it undertaken studies on the effect of the toll on industry and business in western Sydney. The Motorway is essentially a State responsibility.

However some things can be said about the new Motorway and its toll. There is a growing trend around the world for the private provision of public infrastructure. Given the budgetary constraints facing many governments, this trend means that citizens are often able to enjoy the benefits of increased and improved infrastructure earlier than they otherwise would.

As with any new infrastructure project, there will be costs as well as benefits to those affected by the Motorway. Drivers will need to decide whether to continue using the Great Western Highway, with its many traffic lights and difficulties, or to use the Motorway, pay the toll (I understand $1.50 for cars and $4 for trucks) and gain the benefits of large reductions in travel times and improved fuel efficiency from faster, steadier travel. Whichever decision drivers make, the end result will be a reduction in congestion and improved travel times, for those using the Motorway and for those using the Highway.

Of course, any extra impost is a burden on industry. However it is important to realise that drivers and businesses will not be made worse off by having this choice of route: they can continue to use the present Highway and other roads, or choose to obtain the benefits of the Motorway at a price.

There are potentially other benefits which will arise. Any development which can reduce the travel times to the western suburbs is likely to result in more economic activity in the area, with the land likely to become of higher value.

I notice that my colleague Mr Carr has said that if he gains office in New South Wales, he will be acting to drop the toll on the F4 as well as a number of other tollways. Obviously this will make the Motorway even more attractive to people who live and work in the area.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Local Government: Goods and Services Tax

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Local Government, upon notice, on 27 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to preliminary census data for 1991, released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, showing a 15 per cent population growth rate for Queensland and, in particular, an average growth of 42 per cent for the three councils in the Fairfax electorate, in view of the Opposition's proposed 15 per cent Goods and Services Tax on council services and five per cent cut in road grants, what effect would this have on the future of local government in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Local Government has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Opposition Policy Statement includes a provision that Local Government will be zero rated, ie not subject to GST. However, council services likely to involve "significant distortions of competition" with the private sector will not be zero rated or exempt. GST will have to be collected for such services.

The definition of what constitutes council services liable for GST has yet to be clarified. For example, using the European Community Directive on Competition—the model cited by the Opposition as the guide for determining GST rating—local garbage services, water and sewerage, the supply of electricity and the use of swimming pools and car parks may be subject to GST.

The implementation of GST will impose extra administrative costs on councils. These costs are likely to be higher where there is a mixture of zero rated and non-zero rated services to be accounted for.
The 5% cut is to Financial Assistance Grants and not to road grants. The 5% cut is likely to particularly affect rural councils which are more dependent on grants than large, urban councils.

Local Government will be significantly affected by the Opposition's Fightback proposals. The extent and cost of the affects will not be known until the precise details of the proposals are made available.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 27 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to a report prepared by the Food Policy Alliance of a two year study into Australia's imported food inspection program:
(1) Is the study correct in its finding that there are only the equivalent of seven full-time inspectors to monitor the safety standards of food imported annually worth around $2 billion.

(2) Is the Food Policy Alliance correct in saying there is a need for 100 full-time inspectors by the end of 1992 and that the costs of extra inspectors could be paid for by inspection charges to importers.

(3) Are these and other concerns raised by the Alliance in the study being taken into consideration by the Government in its plans for reform of the Australian Quarantine Inspection into a self-funding agency on 1 July 1993.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The claim in the report published by the Food Policy Alliance that only the equivalent of seven full time inspectors are responsible for monitoring imported foods is misleading. There are seven inspectors employed by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) to carry out point of entry checks on a number of foods deemed to be of particular risk by the National Food Authority (NFA). It is estimated that these risk categorised foods comprise about 10% of all food imports. All other imported foods are subject to point of sale checks by the State and Municipal health authorities. Arrangements exist for action to be taken by AQIS and NFA where significant instances of non-compliance with Australia's food safety requirement are reported by the States.

(2) The Minister for Resources has advised that he does not accept the claim by the Food Policy Alliance that 100 full time inspectors are required to ensure an adequate level of surveillance of imported foods by AQIS at the point of entry. It is true that under the Government's fee for service policy, the costs of any additional inspectors would be recoverable from importers.

(3) The concerns raised by the Alliance and other groups concerned about the safety of imported foods are being taken into consideration by Government in a review of existing arrangements presently being undertaken. Any proposed changes will be consistent with the Government's plans to reform AQIS into a self funding agency on 1 July, 1993.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 27 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to concern by Australian plant quarantine authorities about action being taken in the United States which may result in the banning of the fumigant methyl bromide:
(1) Is this fumigant widely used by quarantine authorities throughout the world as a means of controlling a range of pests in imported products.
(2) Is it correct that there is no operational alternative treatment and the banning of methyl bromide could lead to severe disruption in international trade in plants and plant products.
(3) Have doubts been raised on the results of the US Environmental Protection Agency tests.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Methyl bromide is used by quarantine services in many countries to disinfest imported produce. It is a very useful fumigant which is lethal to a wide range of organisms and has a number of properties, such as, short exposure period, low toxicity to plants and relative ease of application, which make it an effective quarantine treatment.

(2) An immediate ban on the use of methyl bromide as a quarantine treatment would cause a severe disruption to international trade in plants and plant products. Some alternative treatments are available but they do not cover the full range for which methyl bromide is currently used.

(3) The issues related to a ban on methyl bromide are now being actively debated by groups in the United States and internationally within the Open Ended Working Group to the Parties of the Montreal Protocol of the United National Environmental Program. The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service is concerned at the consequences of a proposed ban on methyl bromide in the USA by the Environmental Protection Agency. Similar concerns have been expressed by the US Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service which has called for a comprehensive review of the scientific data which led to the proposal to ban methyl bromide on the grounds that it is an ozone depletant.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 27 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: What were the total numbers of telephone directories produced in the last twelve month period for which figures are available for: (a) each area code where white and yellow pages are published in separate books; and (b) each area code where white and yellow pages are published in the same book.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question, based on information provided by AOTC, is as follows:
asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 28 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the `advantages in terms of transit and crew accommodation costs' claimed in answer to Question No. 1866 (Senate Hansard, 29 April 1992, p.1859) for conducting maintenance and repair of major warships at Garden Island by the Australian Defence Industries (ADI) rather than in Williamstown by Australian Marine Engineering Consolidated Ltd (AMECON).
(2) Does the Minister accept that the following considerations favour AMECON over ADI for future major warship repair and maintenance:

(a) the entire fleet met in future consists of warships built by AMECON, namely the ANZ Meko frigates, the FFGs, and the `stretched' version of the ANZ frigates with which the DDGs and possibly the first four FFGs are planned to be replaced; and
(b) it is in the national interest for Australia's only major warship builder to maximise its viability.

(3) Has a cost/benefit analysis been conducted to determine the relative merits of granting future repair and maintenance contracts with ADI and AMECON as AMECON-built warships are phased into service; if so, what were the detailed results.
(4) What ammunitioning/de-ammunitioning facility or facilities could support repair and maintenance by AMECON; if none, at what sites could such a facility be located.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) When RAN ships are "home ported" it means that they would expect to spend the time when they are not actually at sea in the harbour of that home port. This allows the families of married personnel to reside in the same location and enable non-duty personnel to go home to their family domicile on completion of the day's work.

Service accommodation is therefore centred around the traditional home ports of Sydney for the majority of the Fleet, and Darwin or Cairns for the smaller patrol boat type vessels. More recently Rockingham/Perth in West Australia has become a significant home port as elements of the Fleet are home ported in the west under the Two Ocean Basing concept.

When a ship enters a period of extended maintenance then it will be unable to proceed to sea for lengthy periods. If the period of time alongside for maintenance, repair or overhaul away from the home-port extends beyond the normal entitlement for removal of the family, that is, approximately six months, then there will be a cost differential related to the requirement to:
(a) provide travel home to the family for the serviceman after a specified period if a removal entitlement is not established; or
(b) move the family and eventually the family effects, to the new location once an entitlement is established; and
(c) provide alternate accommodation for personnel required to move ashore as on-board accommodation becomes inhabitable due to reduction of domestic facilities such as water, meals etc.
Further costs associated with living out allowances where service accommodation is not available either for married or single personnel must be factored into the cost differential.
By conducting the maintenance activity in the ship's home-port, costs associated with family entitlements for removals/travel etc are negated.

In the case of the single sailors sufficient service accommodation exists in the Sydney area to absorb much of this requirement. With single personnel making up a large proportion of the ship's company this cost will be quite significant away from established service support and facilities. It may mean purchase, albeit on a temporary basis, of sites such as motels to absorb this need.

(2) It is in the national interest for Australia to maintain a naval ship building and repair industry which is efficient by world standards. This is best achieved by commercial competition under open tendering rather than by favouring any particular company.

There is no doubt that the experience gained by AMECON in constructing the last two FFGs and the ANZAC ships will assist the company in bidding competitively for major repair and maintenance work for these ships.

(3) No cost/benefit analysis has yet been conducted on the merits of either company in regard to future repair and maintenance contracts. This will be part of the review process when tenders are let for the repair activity.

(4) Ammunitioning/de-ammunitioning is normally conducted in Sydney harbour but at a specialised site away from the existing repair facility. The ammunitioning/de-ammunitioning activity is stringently controlled by Australian and international regulations and requires special handling equipment especially for missiles.

It would be possible to land ammunition at Point Wilson in Melbourne but this would necessitate the special handling equipment being transported to that site since it is not normally held on location. This would be an added cost.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 28 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Were any of the chemicals used in defoliant programs during the Vietnam War brought back to Australia after Australia ceased to be involved in those hostilities; if so:
(a) What were these chemicals; and
(b) What quantities of each of these chemicals were repatriated.
(2) Were any chemicals distributed to any State Government departments for disposal or use; if so:
(a) Which State Government departments; and
(b) What chemicals; and
(c) In what quantities.
(3) If any of these chemicals were disposed of:
(a) Where were they disposed;
(b) By whom were they disposed; and
(c) By what method were they disposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.
(a) As far as can be ascertained, the chemicals were Hyvan and Reglone.
(b) Hyvan—2,800 pounds, Reglone—2,115 gallons.

(2) An extensive search was conducted but no Departmental records on the subject were found. It is therefore not known whether chemicals were distributed to any State Government departments for disposal or use.

(3) It is believed that unused stocks of chemicals were returned to Australia and disposed of by use or sale, if serviceable, and by destruction, if unserviceable. Generally, serviceable herbicides were disposed of through the then Department of Supply in accordance with normal procedures at the time. Unserviceable stocks were disposed of by letting a contract for their removal and destruction. As no Departmental records on the subject were found, the precise details of (a) where they were disposed, (b) by whom were they disposed, and (c) by what method were they disposed, is not known.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice on 2 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: What funding by ATSIC exists for TAFE courses for Aboriginal women.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question.

PARA.TAB: ATSIC does not directly fund TAFE courses for Aboriginal women. However ATSIC does have a women's initiatives program which aims to improve the status of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women. Through the program, funds are available to community based Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women's groups to provide them with the opportunity to design and manage their own projects, to improve their access to all services and to encourage their greater participation in the decision-making process. This may involve Aboriginal community based groups participating in TAFE courses.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 1 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the extent and nature of Australia's military and defence association with Thailand, including military aid, defence equipment, military transfers and defence cooperation.
(2) What are the legal foundations for such associations.
(3) What was the monetary cost to Australia of this association for 1990-91 and what is the forecast of such cost for 1991-92.

(4) In light of the recent civil unrest, does the Australian Government intend to alter the nature of the military training which it provides to personnel of the Thailand defence forces so that a greater emphasis is given to the observance of human rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Australia does not provide military "aid" to Thailand. Australia and Thailand undertake a range of cooperative defence activities which are funded bilaterally, or are supported by Australia with Defence Cooperation funding. These activities emphasise practical cooperation that is of mutual benefit, and develops personal and professional relationships that are a valuable element in the bilateral relationship. Areas of priority include the exchange of expertise, information and experience, through combined exercising and the provision of training in Australia in a wide range of technical and military disciplines.

Defence Cooperation with Thailand has moved away from equipment based projects to personnel based activities. The only equipment provided to Thailand under Defence Cooperation arrangements in recent years was a Dart Target Range System for training in basic infantry skills, installed in mid 1991.

Australia has approved the sale of some defence equipment to Thailand commercially. In the past financial year approvals granted for defence exports to Thailand comprised commercial encryptors, sporting firearms, some minor aircraft parts, and an aircraft engine owned by the Royal Thai Air Force, which had been brought to Australia for repair and maintenance.
(2) These associations are conducted in the context of the Commonwealth's Constitutional responsibilities for foreign affairs and defence.

(3) Expenditure from Division 232, Defence Cooperation, was $4.350 million in financial year 1990-91, and $3.985 was provided for Additional Estimates in 1991-92. The Australian component of activities such as ship and aircraft visits and combined exercises are funded from the relevant Service.

(4) No. The training offered to overseas personnel is generally on routine Australian Defence Force courses involving Australian trainees. All Australian Defence Force training programs are based on doctrinal principles consistent with Australian compliance with the 1949 Geneva Convention and the Protocols additional to the 1949 Geneva Convention.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 2 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: Is it regarded as acceptable for political satire to appear on a white board in the cafeteria in the High Court building: if so, does that acceptability still prevail if, as was the case on 30 May 1992, one of the persons depicted in the satire is currently involved in a High Court action?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Under the provisions of the High Court of Australia Act 1979 the High Court is responsible for the administration of its own affairs and has power to do all things necessary or convenient to be done in relation to, among other things, the control and management of its land and premises.
I have been informed by the Clerk of the High Court that the Court does not permit the display of political or controversial material in the public areas of its building.

I have been informed that the cafeteria management has been directed by the Clerk of the High Court to remove, and has removed, a drawing on the white board in the Cafeteria, which was not regarded by the Court's administration to be acceptable.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 2 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: Was the exterior cleaning of the southern side of the High Court building carried out on 30 May 1992; if so, (a) did the surface water at the entrance to the building result from this cleaning; (b) was it the responsibility of the cleaning contractor or the High Court, or both, to warn visitors of the slippery conditions due to the surface water; and (c) why were no warning signs present.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Under the provisions of the High Court of Australia Act 1979 the High Court is responsible for the administration of its own affairs and has power to do all things necessary or convenient to be done in relation to, among other things, the control and management of its land and premises.

I have been informed by the Clerk of the High Court that the glass areas on the southern face of the building were cleaned by employees of City Group Pty Ltd, contractors to the High Court's administration, on Saturday 30 May 1992 and:

(a) to the knowledge of the Court staff on duty that day there was no surface water in the vicinity of the entrance to the building; water spillage was confined to occasional droplets from the cleaning tools of the workmen;
(b) under the terms of the cleaning contract, responsibility for warning members of the public of any inherent dangers caused by the workmen lies with the contractor; and
(c) the working area was designated by yellow cones but no specific warning signs were present.

The Clerk of the High Court has advised me that, in future, contractors working in and around the High Court building will be informed that they should display appropriate warning signs when work is being carried out in public areas.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 2 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the name of the private firm commissioned by the Department to produce the World Environment Day information kit for schools and where is it based.
(2) What are the components of its business.
(3) Do any of its principals have connections with Greenpeace or other similar group.
(4) How did this firm come to the notice of the Department.
(5) What procedures were followed in choosing this firm.
(6) Has it previously been commissioned by your Department: if so what are the details.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Social Change Media based at 6A Nelson Street, Annandale NSW.
(2) Social Change Media undertake public education and related consultancy activities.

(3) Membership of a conservation organisation was not something that the Department would take into account, or on which it would require information, during selection of a consultant for the World Environment Day project.

(4) At a World Environment Day planning meeting held in September 1991, suggestions for possible consultants were sought from State and Territory Environment agencies. Social Change Media was brought to the attention of the Department through this process.

(5) The procedure involved a process whereby twenty nine organisations were asked to submit proposals for a concept for a schools kit on 14 August 1991. Closing date was 30 August 1991. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 1 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What cultural programs are offered by the Department for implementation in overseas countries.
(2) How are cultural programs promoted overseas.
(3) What is the total departmental expenditure on cultural programs overseas, both capital and recurrent costs.
(4) What methods of co-ordination are applied to maximise the availability of cultural programs on an equitable basis relevant to the size of each individual diplomatic post.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department of Employment, Education and Training cooperates with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in the promotion of cultural activities overseas with an educational component. In the case of Japan, cooperation is being carried out through an education subcommittee of the Australia-Japan Mixed Cultural Commission; in the case of Korea, a similar arrangement will obtain with the first meeting being held in November 1992.

Overall cooperation on the projection of Australia overseas is carried out through the Australia Abroad Council. The Department is represented on the Council by its Secretary and has a policy input into activities relating to education.
(2) Promotion of these activities is carried out by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Australia Abroad Council.

(3) DEET contributed $25,000 to the organisation of an educational seminar as part of a major promotion in Korea under the auspices of the Australia Abroad Council. In most cases DEET's contribution to activities abroad is of a policy rather than financial nature.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 2 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (With reference to a ruling by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) that genetically engineered foods are not inherently more dangerous than other products and do not need pre-marketing tests.)
(1) Does the FDA advise Australian Government authorities on such rulings and the basis on which such decisions are made?
(2) Have concerns been raised both in Australia and overseas, about fears that the FDA is giving too much testing control on genetically-made foods to biotechnical firms?
(3) What progress has been made in developing legislation to set up a genetic manipulation release authority?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's questions is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) In Australia, the National Food Authority (NFA) is responsible for advising the government on food safety issues. The NFA is currently developing guidelines for foods produced using genetic manipulation. The Authority is aware of overseas policy developments in genetic manipulation—not only in the US, but also in other countries such as the UK.

(2) I am aware that in the United States the recent statement by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has aroused some public debate. In Australia, the US decision received some media publicity (eg: Financial Review, 27 May; The Age, 28 May; Lateline, 16 June). As I understand it, the US approach is to place on food producers legal obligation to ensure that the foods they offer consumers are safe and in compliance with applicable legal requirements, including a requirement to demonstrate to the FDA the safety of any new chemical additive. In the FDA's opinion, its existing pre and post-market evaluation powers, as well as the prospect of tort liability, are sufficient in ensuring food safety, including for products which may be the result of genetic modifications.

(3) The adequacy of the current non-statutory approach to the regulation of genetic manipulation has been the subject of a recent inquiry by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. The Committee's Report, entitled Genetic Manipulation: The Threat or the Glory was tabled in Parliament on 26 March 1992. It makes 48 recommendations concerning a range of issues relevant to regulating genetic manipulation. The report is now under close examination by officers within my Department and other Commonwealth Departments and agencies which have an interest in the regulation of biotechnology. Discussions are also taking place between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories. The issues raised by the report are complex and wide ranging and require thorough examination. I expect, however, to be able to respond to the report on behalf of the Government in the near future.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 2 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Although Television Program Standard 10 has established in law that from 4 p.m to 7.30 p.m children should be able to view television unsupervised by adults, has the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal allowed M and AO shorts and current affairs to drift back to 5 p.m.
(2) Will the Minister require the Tribunal to invoke the law and sanctions currently existing in order to reverse this trend.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Television Program Standards are only established in law in the sense that compliance with them is a condition of the licence.

Under the standards, the period 4 p.m to 7.30 p.m is G time, which means that only programs classified G can be shown. That is, programs which are suitable for viewing by children without parental supervision.
The M classification does not apply to television in that it is a cinema and video classification only.
All programs must be classified before transmission, including news and current affairs, so that the content is appropriate for the classification.
AO programs cannot be shown in G time. There is no evidence before the Tribunal that licensees are showing AO classified programs in G time.
Promotions for AO programs cannot be shown between 4 pm and 6 pm on weekdays. However, promotions for AO programs can be shown in G programs if the promotion itself is modified.
News and current affairs, provided they are appropriate to G time, can be shown in that time.
(2) The power to determine or amend a program standard is a substantive power of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.
The Tribunal is currently conducting a review of the classification standards and may, as a result of this review, decide to exercise its power to change the standard.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 4 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Compared to the overall ANZ content achieved in Project DESINE to 31 August 1989 which was 25.3 percent, what is the current content.
(2) Has the ANZ contractual arrangement of 53 percent with a maximum variation of 5 percent changed in any way; if so, how, why and when.

(3) With reference to an answer given on 28 September 1989 to pre-hearing question 36 of Estimates Committee D, taken on notice, that DAS was then investigating the Techway ANZ content level (a) when was the investigation completed; and (b) what was the outcome of the investigation.
(4) Has the content which was assessed on likely buying patterns at the time of source selection of 23.8 percent changed; If so, how.
(5) What is the current value of orders placed on individual DESINE subcontractors as per question 155 taken on notice at Estimates Committee D on 10 October 1989.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The overall ANZ content achieved in Project DESINE to 31 May 1992 was 24 percent.

(2) The intent of the contractual requirement to maintain the level of ANZ content was and is to ensure that local manufacturing industry continues to participate in the supply of equipment under the contract. The contractual arrangement of 53 percent ANZ content related only to the microcomputers originally supplied by MICA, an IBM subcontractor. The MICA operation proved incapable of coping with the volume and quality required by Defence, and was taken over by Techway and re-located to that company's factory at Penrith in mid 1989. Audits conducted by DAS in late 1989 and early 1990 established the ANZ content of the products supplied by Techway at levels relevant to the Penrith operation. These were included in the contract with effect from April 1990.

(3) The formula used by DAS to quantify the ANZ level is sensitive to a number of variables. For example, as the number of units produced increases, the amount of research and development and capital amortization costs included in the selling price of each unit typically reduces. This, together with any reductions in the cost of components and sub-assemblies, can reduce the measured ANZ content figure even though the actual level of local manufacturing industry participation may be unchanged.

The audit completed by DAS in early 1990 showed that at the then scale of operation and then applicable factor costs, the formula would derive a weighted average ANZ content for Techway products of 30 percent. Accordingly, the contract authority accepted that level of ANZ content for Techway's products.
(4) The overall content actually achieved to the end of May 1992 was 24 percent. There is no reason to expect that this trend will change significantly during the remaining period of the contract.
(5) The value of orders placed on the various DESINE suppliers is set out in the following table.

ANSWER.PARA: ORDERS PLACED WITH DESINE CONTRACT SUPPLIERS FROM MARCH 1989 TO MAY 1992

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 4 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the Administrative Review Council (ARC) report Rule Making by Commonwealth Agencies, which deals with the issue of deregulated (sic) legislation indicate the need for such legislation to be brought under proper control by the Parliament and point out an increase in `backdoor' legislation figures, including disallowable instruments.

(2) Will the Government move to limit or stop this unconstitutional law-making by bureaucrats by implementing the ARC recommendation that regulations which come into this category are subject to proper parliamentary scrutiny, effective publicity and sunset clauses.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Report by the Administrative Review Council, Rule Making By Commonwealth Agencies, recommends that section 46A and Part XII of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 and the Statutory Rules Publication Act 1903 should be replaced by a new Act to prescribe procedures for the making publication and supervision of delegated legislative instruments. I am aware of concerns about the growth in the number and variety of delegated legislative instruments and endorse the need to institute proper procedures governing these instruments to ensure effective parliamentary scrutiny.

(2) I know of no basis on which the present practices for the making of delegated legislation would be held to be unconstitutional as suggested by the honourable senator, and I note that the ARC Report suggests only that those practices are undesirable because they do not provide appropriate avenues for public consultation, parliamentary scrutiny and public accessibility to the body of Commonwealth legislative instruments. I have asked my Department to undertake wide ranging consultations with Commonwealth agencies so that proposals can be prepared to implement the Report to ensure there is proper parliamentary scrutiny, effective publicity and sunset provisions. This will include the formulation of a comprehensive definition of delegated legislation to ensure that all instruments that are legislative in character would be subject to the new regime and cannot avoid the proper parliamentary scrutiny process.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 4 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Which of the specific human rights listed in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights are claimable by the people of Australia in 1992.
(2) Can any of the specific human rights listed in the ICCPR be legally claimed now by the people of Australia in their dealings with their respective State Governments and Local Governments.

(3) Was Mr Ellenbogen of Glenbrook in NSW eligible to receive legal aid from the Commonwealth Government to run his case in the Industrial Relations Commission of NSW, a case which was initiated by two special Ministerial References, by the NSW Minister for Industrial Relations and Employment, given that the NSW Legal Aid Commission does not provide Legal Aid in employment disputes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1)&(2) As a matter of international law, Australia has obligations under the ICCPR to the other Parties to the ICCPR. Australia's ratification of the ICCPR does not create rights in individuals which can be claimed or enforced in domestic courts and tribunals. The ICCPR is implemented domestically in Australia by a wide range of legislative and administrative measures appropriate to the various obligations. These are detailed in Australia's periodic reports to the United Nations Human Rights Committee which monitors the implementation of the ICCPR. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has functions under the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 in respect of the ICCPR, including the function of investigating any Commonwealth Act or practice which may be inconsistent with the rights recognised in the ICCPR as it applies in relation to Australia, that is, taking account of Australia's reservations to Articles 10, 14, and 20 of the ICCPR.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 3 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the fact that the annual cost of osteoporosis to the health budget is between $200 million and $500 million a year, and to the answer given on 31 March 1992 (Senate Hansard, p.1385) to my question without notice asked on 26 March 1992 on the subject:
(1) Does the Government accept the irrefutable evidence that low bone mineral content is a good predictor of increased risk of fracture in that loss of bone density is stopped by oestrogen.

(2) Does the Government recognise the great consensus among those of the medical profession who specialise in osteoporosis that oestrogen stops loss of calcium and collagen and protects against osteoporosis.
(3) What are the detailed reasons why the Federal Government persists in its refusal to extend Medicare benefits to menopausal women for densitometry as a preventative health measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) A major and comprehensive United Kingdom review of the published research literature on `Screening for Osteoporosis to Prevent Fractures' was released in January 1992 (Effective Health Care, No. 1, Centre for Health Economics, University of York).
The review concluded that bone density measurements are poor at identifying which women will go on to have a fracture in later life.
The review's findings endorse the 1986 and 1989 recommendations of the National Health Technology Advisory Panel (NHTAP) concerning the use of bone mineral assessment in screening for osteoporosis.

(2) Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT), based on oestrogen alone or combined with progesterone, has been shown to retard, stop or even temporarily reverse the process of bone mineral density loss which immediately follows menopause.

HRT is associated with a number of both positive and negative side effects, including reduced risk of coronary heart disease, increased risk of endometrial cancer and breast cancer and discomfort (eg. menopausal bleeding, weight gain, sore and swollen breasts).

The long-term safety and effectiveness of HRT in the prevention and treatment of osteoporosis amongst middle aged and older women is not known largely because adequate long range studies have not taken place.

(3) Bone densitometry has been promoted heavily as a means of screening for developing osteoporosis among menopausal women. As the answer to Question No (1) indicated, there is no conclusive evidence that bone densitometry is a good predictor of future risk of osteoporatic fracture, which is the major health problem arising from osteoporosis. Such evidence is necessary if bone densitometry is to be an effective screening, and hence preventive, tool for osteoporosis.

Medicare benefits are not available for the measurement of bone mineral density for osteoporosis assessment. The Government's decision not to provide Medicare benefits for bone densitometry was based on advice from the Medicare Benefits Advisory Committee (MBAC). The MBAC is an independent statutory body, mainly composed of doctors, which advises the Minister on the application of Medicare benefits to specified services.

In developing its advice, the MBAC considered a report by NHTAP on bone mineral assessment and osteoporosis. It concluded, in the light of the evidence available on the effectiveness of densitometry as a diagnostic tool, that Medicare benefits should not be paid for bone densitometry screening for osteoporosis.
The NHTAP has since provided another report acknowledging further development of bone densitometry technology for specific purposes, but not recommending its use for screening.

Work is currently under way within the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services to develop a comprehensive policy for the prevention and effective diagnosis and management of osteoporosis. The Government's objective is to have a policy which best meets the interests of those members of the population at risk of osteoporosis and the wider community. The provision of bone densitometry for the management of patients with specific conditions is one of the issues being considered closely in the development of the policy.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 5 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did an unauthorised discharge of a firearm by a member of the Australian Protective Service occur in or about Cairns Airport in August 1991.
(2) Was an investigation report compiled; if so, to whom was it circulated.
(3) To what cause did the investigation report attribute the incident.
(4) Was a copy of the investigation report provided to the Cairns Port Authority; if so, when.
(5) Were copies of the investigation report provided to officers of the Australian Protective Service at Cairns Airport.

(6) Does the Australian Protective Service have a Quick Skill Target Shooting System in their office at the Cairns Airport; if so, is the Quick Skill Target Shooting System actually used in the Australian Protective Service office at the Cairns Airport.
(7) What guidelines apply to the use of the Quick Skill Target Shooting System in the vicinity of live ammunition or weapons which may contain live ammunition.
(8) What safeguards have been put in place as a result of the accidental discharge referred to above.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) Yes. An investigation report was prepared by the senior Australian Protective Service (APS) officer in Cairns. The report was sent to the APS Regional Commander, Queensland Region who was responsible for reviewing the report and taking follow-up action.

(3) The incident was attributed to carelessness and negligence by the officer involved during an unloading procedure prior to conducting a dry-fire exercise (without ammunition) with the Quick Skill Target Shooting System.

(5) No. However, the contents of the report were made known to the officer involved in the unauthorised discharge and the Regional Commander, Queensland Region, wrote to the senior APS officer in Cairns regarding remedial action and future precautions.
(6) Yes. This system is used by the Australian Protective Service at the Cairns Airport.
(7) Instructions issued in January 1991 at Cairns Airport indicate as follows:

"Before moving to the exercise area firers are to unload weapons and hand in all live ammunition. The conducting officer is then to inspect and clear the weapon at which time the firer is to declare he/she is not in possession of any live ammunition. The firer is then to holster the weapon and move to the exercise area."

(8) Since the time of this incident, all Regional Commanders have been reminded of the dangers involved when weapons handling procedures are not properly followed and when training and follow-up training is not conducted in accordance with national procedures. Posters regarding the safe handling of weapons are now permanently displayed at all APS locations and national procedures have been strengthened. In fact, national procedures now require any unauthorised discharge to be formally investigated by a senior officer from outside the State concerned and for the person involved to be removed from any duties which require the carrying of a firearm until at least such time as the investigation has been completed.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 5 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Were recent media reports which suggest that the Government is considering a request by major Japanese travel companies to grant 2000 temporary resident visas for up to two years for Japanese citizens to fill tour guide positions in Australia accurate.
(2) What measures have been taken in this instance to confirm the unavailability of qualified Australian residents to fill these positions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. My department has been considering a proposal by the Japanese Tour Wholesalers Committee of Australia to fill a large number of tour guide positions in Australia with Japanese temporary residents. There has been no decision reached about the number of Japanese temporary residents who may be permitted entry; to date, the focus of discussions has been the total number of Japanese speaking tour guides, both Australian residents and Japanese nationals, required by employers in Australia over the next few years. Employers' overseas recruitment needs have not yet been quantified.

The proposal has been the subject of discussions with, amongst others, the Departments of Employment, Education and Training and Industrial Relations, the Australian Tourism Industry Association, the Inbound Tourism Organisation of Australia and the trade union movement. Discussions with the appropriate parties are not yet complete.

ANSWER.PARA: If a Labour Agreement is concluded with the Japanese Tour Wholesalers Committee it will facilitate the development of a tour guide workforce strategy for a significant sector of the tourism industry and involving government, employers and trade unions. Employer commitments under consideration for inclusion in the Labour Agreement to achieve this include:

PARA.TAB: .an interchange program for Australians involving all companies party to the Labour Agreement
.a program to promote accredited Japanese language courses throughout the tourism industry within Australia, together with an analysis of future employment opportunities

.a scholarship program for Australians to study in Japan, funded by individual sponsorships by companies involved in the Agreement and/or from fees payable towards the management, monitoring and training by participating companies
.enhancement of professional recognition of tour guides through relating this program to the Tour Guides Accreditation Scheme
.development of a work experience program for Australians within Japanese companies operating in Australia
.a monitoring program which reviews the effectiveness and success of the above programs on a continuing basis.

Training, labour market and industrial issues must be satisfactorily addressed before the Labour Agreement can be concluded; there will only be an Agreement if there is endorsement from all the major parties involved, that is, government, employers and trade unions.

(2) My department is awaiting advice on the labour market aspects of the proposal, in particular, from the Department of Employment, Education and Training. It remains government policy that Australian employers may have access to overseas recruitment to meet their skilled labour needs only where appropriately skilled Australian citizens and permanent residents are not readily available from the local labour market or through employers' own training efforts.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 5 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why has no priority been given for funding for child care facilities to give women access to TAFE skills courses.

(2) Does the Minister acknowledge that TAFE courses are an extremely important way for disadvantaged women, particularly non-English speaking background women, to gain skills; if so, why is it that so little priority has been placed on this and the department could only provide a couple of child care places in Fremantle causing 30 migrant women who wanted to enrol to be turned away.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government has given a high priority to the area of child care funding for TAFE throughout Australia. This commitment is part of the Government's social justice strategy and the results of this activity have been excellent. Since its inception in 1989, $10 million has been provided to assist in constructing or extending 39 child care centres to create 1,100 additional child care places for TAFE students. In addition, approval has been given for $3 million for each of the next two years to provide further assistance.

(2) The primary objective of grants to provide additional child care places in TAFE is to remove one of the barriers to the participation of women undertaking training and in preparation for re-entry to the workforce. Government policies reflecting child care needs and priorities have been determined with this in mind. In respect to child care at Fremantle, a grant of $200,000 has been approved in 1992 for the establishment of a new 47 place child care centre for TAFE students. This project will be completed in 1993.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 9 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What proportion, if any, of shares in the proposed privatisation of Qantas and Australian Airlines will be reserved for employees of the airlines to purchase.
(2) If such provision is being made, will any concessions or incentives be given to assist employees in the purchase of such shares; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Government is firmly committed to the introduction of an appropriate employee share ownership scheme as part of the current process to sell equity in Qantas Airways Limited, following its acquisition of Australian Airlines Limited.

At this stage, the Government does not have any fixed views on the precise shape of the employee share ownership scheme, including the proportion of the total shares issued to be held by employees and any associated concessions or incentives that might be offered to employees to encourage their participation in such a scheme.

The timing of introduction and the precise shape of the employee share ownership scheme for Qantas will depend, in part, on the outcome of negotiations with the successful purchaser(s) of equity in Qantas during the current "trade sale" process, which are expected to occur later this year.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 9 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) How many resource centres for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women have been established; (b) where were they established; and (c) when were they established.
(2) Do the centres receive on-going government funding.
(3) Why has no on-going administrative staff funding been given to the Aboriginal and Islander Women's Congress of Western Australia so that support for Aboriginal women can be maintained.
(4) Does the Minister agree that it is ludicrous for this organisation to be given $130,086 for an establishment grant and then not to be provided with on-going funding for staff.
(5) What action has been taken to require a more rational basis for funding for Aboriginal women's organisations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) Sixty-six (66) resource centres for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women have been established.
(b), (c) and (2) are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: South Brisbane Aboriginal & Islander Corporation for Women1987Yes
North Brisbane Aboriginal & Islander Corporation for Women1992Yes
Injinoo Undamu Mayitjung Women's Resource Centre Inc1992No

PARA.TAB: (3) Decisions on funding to Aboriginal organisations such as the Aboriginal and Islander Women's Congress in Perth are the responsibility of individual Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) Regional Councils, within overall budget allocations approved by the ATSIC Board of Commissioners.
In the case of the Aboriginal and Islander Women's Congress, the Karlkarniny (Perth) Regional Council has not accorded the organisation the level of priority needed to secure on-going funding.
(4) No. No organisation has an automatic entitlement to continuing funding.
The establishment grant was authorised through the former Department of Aboriginal Affairs and was not subject to a Regional Council process as is the case with ATSIC.

(5) Regional Councils have been set up in an endeavour to ensure a more rational basis for funding for Aboriginal organisations. The Regional Council mechanism facilitates and enables Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to determine their own priorities and become self managing. To ensure women's organisations receive equitable funding, ATSIC has established the resource centres for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women.

The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission's Perth Regional Office has received approaches for funding from the Aboriginal and Islander Women's Congress. Their submissions have all been referred to the local Regional Council for a decision.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: NHMRC: First Aid and Safety Directions Panel

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 16 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it the role of the National Health and Medical Research Council's First Aid and Safety Directions Panel to advise the Drugs and Poisons Schedule Standing Committee on appropriate first aid and safety directions for drugs and poisons.

(2) Is Mr Peter Meadows, Group Technical Sales Manager for the pest control company, WA Flick, a member of the First Aid and Safety Directions Panel; if so, did Mr Meadows make a statement to a public meeting convened by Standards Australia in Sydney in 1991 to the effect that the organochlorine (cyclodiene) insecticides are no more toxic than common salt; if so, is Mr Meadows an appropriate person to be a member of the National Health and Medical Research Council's First Aid and Safety Directions Panel.

(3)Have health and safety information sheets been distributed by WA Flick to its workers and customers which state than [sic] when applied at normal usage rates (a) aldrin is 2.7 times less toxic than common table sale [sic]; and (b) chlordane is 13.7 times less toxic than common table salt; if so, are these statements: (i) accurate and (ii) responsible.
(4) If it is not accurate and responsible to describe aldrin and chlordane in this way, how should (a) the accurate [sic] toxicity; (b) the chronic toxicity, of aldrin and chlordane be described.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) Yes. I am advised that at a Standards Association seminar on 14 August 1991 Mr Meadows showed an overhead slide of a Health and Safety Information Sheet used by W.A. Flick and Co. Pty Ltd regarding a product named Gold Crest Heptachlor 400EC which contained the phrase "As a guide to relative safety, this product, when applied at normal usage rates is 9.6 times less toxic than common table salt".
Membership of NHMRC Committees is a matter for the Council to consider.
(3) Yes.

(i) to (ii) These statements address only two aspects of toxicology, namely oral and dermal LD(50) values and refer to the product diluted for normal usage. I am advised that they are accurate in this respect.

(4) The acute and chronic toxicity of aldrin and chlordane in their concentrated technical form is clearly described in documents published by the International Program on Chemical Safety and extensively documented in the draft report of the NHMRC Working Party on Cyclodiene Insecticide Use in Australia currently being finalised.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 17 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (a) How many officers from the department attended the Earth Summit Conference in Brazil.
(b) What was the cost over and above normal salaries.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a) In total fourteen DFAT officers attended the Conference. Of these, five (including one media officer and one AIDAB officer) were Canberra-based, three travelled from the Australian mission to the UN in New York, one travelled from the Australian mission to the UN in Geneva, one travelled from the Australian mission in Washington, three were based at the Australian mission to Brazil and one was based at the Australian mission in Santiago, Chile.

This number included those DFAT officers providing administrative support to the Australian delegation at the Conference (one officer from the Australian mission in Brasilia, one officer from the Australian mission in Santiago, one from the Australian mission in Washington and one from the Australian mission in New York).

(b) Final cost cannot be assessed until all bills have been received. However, the total estimated administrative cost (for the whole delegation of 42 delegates and six support staff) is AUD 88,150. DFAT's share of this cost is AUD 47,150; the Department expects to recoup the remaining AUD 41,000 in administrative expenses from non-DFAT State and Federal Government delegates under the user-pays principle. Travel related expenses for DFAT and AIDAB officers are AUD 137,122 (including accommodation and travel allowances). Total cost for the portfolio is, therefore, estimated at AUD 184,272.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 17 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Australian Country Information Services (ACIS)—

(1) Has this initiative to improve access to information about Commonwealth Programs and Services for people living in smaller towns and in the more isolated regions of Australia, which was announced in the then Prime Minister's 1989 policy statement on Rural and Regional Australia, and the 20 pilot projects established pursuant to that initiative, been fully evaluated.
(2) What has been the cost to the Commonwealth of operating each of the 20 pilot services established to trial the Australian Country Information Service over the last two years.
(3) Is it true that the funding provided over the last two years to each of these pilot projects is to be withdrawn from 30 June 1992 in respect of any or all of these pilots.

(4) Have the three shires, East Pilbara in Western Australia, Brewarrina in New South Wales and Flinders in Queensland, which have participated in the ACIS pilot projects been formally advised, as of the date of this question, of likely funding for 1992-93 and beyond.
(5) Is the Minister aware that 877 inquiries were made in February 1992 alone to the pilot service that operates at Newman in the East Pilbara Shire.

(6) What is the Minister's view on the continued usefulness of the service provided through these pilot projects, particularly in view of the strong support given by each of the three shires referred to in part 4 of this question to the contribution the pilots have made to their communities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(2) The Government's allocation for ACIS was $1.85 million across three years, including the trial period. (1) Is the Prime Minister aware that the New South Wales (NSW) Government has used the criminal code to deal with non-violent protest at Emerald Beach, NSW, that more than 250 charges are still pending, and that the average age of those people arrested was about 45 years of age, many of whom were family people, mums, dads and grandparents.

(2) Is the Prime Minister aware that as a result of the Supreme Court of Appeals decision, the Coffs Harbour City Council was found to be contravening their own Local Environment Plan and that people charged with the criminal code were actually defending the law.
(3) Is the Federal Government willing to express the same Australian concern about the actions of the NSW Greiner Government as they did about the situation in Indonesia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 18 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) hearings into the granting of a FM radio licence in Lismore:

(1) What specific circumstances have changed between December 1991 and May 1992 to make the ABT reverse its preliminary decision in December 1991 and decide that the Lismore market could not support an independent FM licence.
(2) Was correspondence by the then Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Richardson) with Mr Peter Westerway, Chairman of the ABT, one of these factors.

(3) In relation to correspondence of 6 March 1992 from Senator Richardson which informed the ABT that an application for a supplementary licence was to be submitted by the licensee of Lismore AM radio station 2LM; the ABT announced it had received such an application on 19 May 1992, 6 days after the ABT had decided not to award an independent licence in Lismore; (a) what was the reason for the delay in considering the supplementary licence; (b) when did the Minister's office receive the application; and (c) when did they forward that application on to the ABT.
(4) Why has the ABT called for submissions for its new hearing into the grant of a supplementary licence without waiting the 28 days for the appeal period on the last decision to lapse.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The ABT's preliminary view released on 17 December 1992 was that both 2LM Lismore, and 2MW in the adjacent Murwillumbah service area, would retain their commercial viability if a new licence were granted in Lismore. However, in the light of additional economic and financial evidence presented at the Lismore licence hearing in March 1992, the ABT changed its preliminary view and in its decision and report, released on 13 May 1992, concluded that a new commercial FM service would make the existing service, 2LM, commercially unviable.

This decision followed a thorough analysis of the Lismore market, its radio revenue potential and the expenditure required to generate that revenue. The additional evidence which the Tribunal accepted is as follows: financial data from the 1990-91 financial year, which showed a continuing decline in the revenue generated in the Lismore radio market; the impact of television aggregation (which commenced in the area after the publication of the preliminary view), in causing a loss of revenue from radio to television; the need, in a competitive market, for increased expenditure by 2LM on promotions and advertising and the limited capacity of the licensee to further reduce staffing costs.

(2) Correspondence between the then Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Richardson) and Mr Peter Westerway, Chairman of the ABT, had no bearing on the outcome of the Inquiry. On 20 February 1992 the Minister wrote to the Chairman seeking his views on the practicability of joining an inquiry into the grant of a supplementary licence for Richmond River Broadcasters with its Inquiry into the grant of a new commercial radio licence to serve Lismore. In his response Mr Westerway noted that the ABT can, and has in the past, joined supplementary licence and new commercial licence grant inquiries. However, Richmond River Broadcasters' referred application was not received by the ABT until 19 May 1992 after the Lismore new licence grant inquiry was concluded, on 13 May 1992.

(3) (a) The Minister wrote to the Chairman of the ABT on 6 March 1992, advising him that Richmond River Broadcasters had indicated that a supplementary licence application would be lodged with the Minister in the near future. Richmond River Broadcasters lodged an application with the Department of Transport and Communications on 31 March 1992. Senator Richardson referred Richmond River Broadcasters' Supplementary licence application to the ABT within 5 weeks from his receipt of the application on 8 April 1992. I do not consider this to be an inordinate delay.

(b) Departmental advice recommending that the supplementary licence application be referred to the ABT was forwarded to the Minister for Transport and Communications on 8 April 1992. The Act requires the Minister to either refer the application to the ABT or dismiss it on technical and planning grounds. As I noted above, the Minister responded to this application within 5 weeks of receipt.
(c) The Minister referred Richmond River Broadcasters' supplementary licence application to the ABT on 12 May 1992.

(4) The inquiry into the grant of a supplementary licence is a separate inquiry and there is nothing in the Broadcasting Act 1942 requiring the ABT to wait for the appeal period for a grant into an independent commercial licence to elapse. Once a supplementary licence has been received by the ABT it is a matter for the ABT to consider the application in a procedural sense and in accordance with the Broadcasting Act.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 22 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has there been any increase in the use of growth hormones in Australia over the past five years.
(2) What was the cost of growth hormones made available through the Pharmaceutic Benefit Scheme for the years 1985-86, 1986-87, 1987-88, 1988-89, 1989-90, and 1990-91.
(3) What is the total number of patients currently receiving growth hormone treatment.
(4) Is it true that the average period of treatment with growth hormones for a child is ten years and the cost $250

(5) Has the effectiveness of growth hormone treatment yet to be fully demonstrated, except amongst those children with a proven growth hormone deficiency who represent a small component of those being treated with the drug.
(6) Is the government prepared to consider a review of the present liberal guidelines for the use of growth hormone drugs.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.
(2)Expenditure on hGH as a pharmaceutical benefit under section 100
(3) The number of patients receiving hGH at 30 June 1992 is 1,936. This figure has remained just under 2,000 since 1990, following a sharp increase in patients between 1985 and 1990.
(4) The average period of treatment is approximately five years. Based on the cost per child in 1991-92 of $22,000, the average expenditure on a child receiving growth hormone would be $110,000.

(5) The effect of growth hormone treatment on children who are not growth hormone deficient has not been fully demonstrated. However, many of these children do show a good response, especially girls with Turner's Syndrome. Approximately 44% of the children receiving treatment are growth hormone deficient, 10% have Turner's Syndrome and 24% have other Syndromes which can be demonstrated to respond well to growth hormone therapy. The remaining 22% have familial short stature and the effect of growth hormones on these children is presently under review by the Growth Hormone Advisory Committee of the Australian Paediatric Endocrine Group.

(6) Yes. However, new Guidelines for the use of growth hormones were introduced on 1 January 1992, which tightened eligibility criteria. Furthermore, a conference attended by top Endocrinologists and Paediatricians from all over Australia was held in Canberra at the end of May this year and all aspects of the scheme were discussed. The analysis of data from the new OZGROW data base set up in 1989 and funded by the Department was presented. Most patients receiving growth hormone are now entered on this data base, and trends in use and response to treatment were demonstrated. The Growth Hormone Advisory Committee is currently considering the need for any changes to the Guidelines in view of the discussions at that conference.
