TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 24 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to question number 1887, which has been on the Senate Notice Paper since 18 April 1992:

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Request for Tender BG88 does include reference to possible review of the arrangements at any time during the period of the standing offer

(2) The operation of all common use standing offers is kept under review as part of good management practice. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 24 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is there any record at Melbourne Radio of Mayday calls having been received on VHF channels 4620, 4535, 4125, and 2182 or AM 27 megahertz channel 88 on the morning of Thursday 18 June from the fishing vessel `Gail-Jeanette II', which was in an emergency situation and eventually sank off the Friendly Beaches near Bicheno; if not, will the Minister instigate an inquiry to ascertain why the `Gail-Jeanette II' was unable to contact Melbourne Radio.

(2) Has the Minister or the department received complaints from any Tasmanian fishermen or recreational boating users regarding the difficulty in contacting either Melbourne Radio or Sydney Radio following the closure of Hobart Radio.
(3) Is the Minister or the department aware of any other instances where vessels off the Tasmanian coast have been unable to contact Melbourne or Sydney Radio in an emergency situation.
(4) Should vessels off the Tasmanian coast which are fitted with the most modern marine radio equipment experience any difficulty in obtaining weather broadcasts from Melbourne or Sydney Radio.
(5) Did the Government give an undertaking to Tasmanian fishermen and recreational boating users that their safety would not be put at risk by the closure of Hobart Radio.
(6) Does the Minister believe that the current situation adequately protects the lives of those in vessels off the Tasmanian coast.
(7) Will the Minister reconsider the decision to close Hobart Radio.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) There is no record at Melbourne Radio of any Mayday calls being received on 18 June 1992 from the fishing vessel `Gail-Jeanette II'. The circumstances relating to the sinking of the vessel are being thoroughly investigated by the Tasmanian Navigation and Survey Authority, which is being assisted by Radio Inspectors from the Radiocommunications Policy Division of the Federal Department of Transport and Communications in relation to the matter of the distress call not being received.

(5) No. However, the Commonwealth has clearly stated, and State and Territory Governments have agreed, that where the States consider that services beyond those provided by the Commonwealth are necessary to meet the needs of fishing vessels and pleasure craft, then they will be provided by the States. The Commonwealth is responsible for providing the maritime distress and safety radio communications service to commercial shipping. The service is, however, available to fishing vessels and pleasure craft.

I am assured by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority that the new system is designed to provide adequate coverage for vessels, providing that their equipment is properly installed and maintained and also that vessels carry an Emergency Position Indicating Radio Beacon (EPIRB).
(6) Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 24 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Could the new mechanical alloying process recently developed by Australian National University scientists and referred to by the ANU Reporter of 13 May 1992 be classified as innovative technology.
(2) Is it correct that the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce assessed the process as a multi-million export dollar earner for Australia by the turn of the century.
(3) What steps has the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce taken to secure Australian industry interest and involvement in the process.
(4) What are the reasons for denying a grant of $300,000, over three years, to the ANU for further work on the process.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) While mechanical alloying is a commonly used and proven technology, the process referred to in the ANU Reporter of 13 May 1992 has elements of innovation which could enhance the commercial potential of the technology.

(2) No. Following discussions with the ANU, the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce (DITAC) decided to investigate commercial potential and in June 1990 funded a review of the technology by a consultant. The review provided some indicative figures on the value of the technology based on capturing some proportion of existing markets.

(3) DITAC provided $7000 to fund the review referred to above. The purpose of the review was to assist the ANU in its negotiations with Australian industry. DITAC also assisted the ANU in holding workshops and demonstrations of the technology to Australian industry.

(4) A grant has not been denied. There has been a preliminary screening of Expressions of Interest in which this proposal was not ranked in the top group. Proposals in the lower group were not encouraged to prepare a detailed application but were offered the opportunity to discuss their case. Following these discussions, the Industry Research and Development Board has agreed to consider full applications from three lower ranked proposals, including this one.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 24 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What were the criteria and history upon which the decision was reached that the Systems Integration Panel, as proposed, will benefit the Government in its acquisitions, and Australia in developing its indigenous Information Technology capability.
(2) How will the benefits and disadvantages of the Systems Integration Panel be measured; is the panel expected to operate in a fashion similar to DESINE.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) In the "Building a Competitive Australia" statement of 12 March 1992, I announced that "Commonwealth IT services will in future be met from a panel of preferred suppliers through which agencies will either contract out the entire service or engage a systems integrator. The panel will apply to all IT requirements over $1 million involving systems integration, unless ground for exemption are established."

Members of the panel were selected on the criteria of competence, commitment to Government IT purchasing policy and local industry development. In addition, panel members were required to have experience in IT service provision, systems integration and prime contracting.
(2) There will be ongoing monitoring of the panel by my Department and a formal review will be undertaken after a year of operation.

The Panel will not operate in a fashion similar to DESINE. In DESINE the contractor advises on the selection of equipment to meet a functional requirement. With the Systems Integration Panel the panellists will tender, in competition, solutions to a functional specification and if successful will then be given a contract to implement that solution.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 1 July 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did a study by Malcolm Sears in the Lancet in 1990 suggest that patients regularly taking the bronchodilating aerosol Berotec worsened their asthma condition.
(2) What action has the department taken in response to that study.
(3) Are the findings of that study also applicable to Ventolin; if not, why not.

(4) Is the department aware of two studies by D A Henry of the University of Newcastle and published in the Medical Journals of Australia showing 95 per cent of persons buying bronchodilating aerosols over the counter without first going to a doctor were in need of more intensive therapy; if so, are these studies by Henry correct; if not, why not.
(5) On what basis is it considered that bronchodilating aerosols may be safely dispensed without prescription.
(6) Does the department have any evidence of suspected adverse drug reactions to the bronchodilating aerosol, Ventolin; if so, please provide copies of any such reports from 1 July 1990, to date.
(7) What studies have been undertaken by the department into the use of beta-agonist inhalers as a means of asthma treatment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The study suggested that patients with mild to moderate asthma who used inhaled fenoterol (BEROTEC) at fixed intervals throughout the day had poorer control of their condition than those who used bronchodilators on an irregular, "as-needed" basis.
(2) The department has taken no action against the drug fenoterol specifically as a result of this particular study.

However, in other articles in the medical literature, this drug has been the subject of debate concerning its possible association with an increased risk of death from asthma. As a result of this debate, the department has:
(a)removed the drug from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme;
(b)changed the recommended scheduling of the product from S3 to S4;

(c)negotiated with the company changes to the product information provided to prescribers. These changes include decreases in recommended dosages and the insertion of a paragraph outlining the results of the studies which showed an increased risk of death;
(d)arranged with the company the mailing of a letter to all doctors and pharmacists informing them of the situation; and
(e)arranged for the company to apply for the marketing approval of a lower strength formulation of the product.

(3) It is not possible to definitely state that the findings of the Sears study are applicable to salbutamol (Ventolin) without repeating the study using salbutamol instead of fenoterol. However, as a result of this and other studies with inhaled bronchodilators it is now accepted by a large number of clinicians that all such drugs should be used on an "as-needed" basis at the lowest effective dose rather than on a regular, fixed time-interval basis.
(4) Yes.

The first study published by Dr Henry and his associates was examined by the Drugs and Poisons Schedule Standing Committee, as it raised questions about possible links between the S3 availability of beta-agonist inhalers and an increased mortality from asthma.

The Committee concluded that the available evidence did not show a causal association between S3 availability and asthma deaths and that further research would be needed to establish whether such hypotheses had validity.
The details of the second study have yet to be fully published and therefore an accurate assessment of the validity of any conclusions drawn is not possible at this stage.

(5) The current availability of bronchodilating aerosols other than fenoterol is based on the NHMRC assessment that the preferred public health classification is Schedule 3 provided that the inhalers were used correctly within an overall treatment plan for asthma which involved professional input from doctors, pharmacists and in the case of remote areas, nursing sisters. In addition, the Public Health Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council has supported the need for an education campaign for users and health professionals so as to improve the use of these inhalers.
(6) The department has received reports of adverse drug reactions to salbutamol under its adverse drug reaction monitoring scheme. A printout of those reports has been provided to the senator.

(7) The department does not undertake clinical research projects itself. However, such research undertaken by academic institutions is supported by grants made through the National Health and Medical Research Council. There have been several grants made for research into asthma.
The following grant specifically looks at bronchodilator drugs for the treatment of asthma.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 1 July 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Have Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel been involved in advising and observing the Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF) on the conduct of military operations on the island of Bougainville; if so, at what level and over what period of time.
(2) How many PNGDF pilots have completed the two year RAAF training course pledged in July 1989.
(3) Does the ADF provide training in jungle warfare to PNGDF and have such ADF-trained personnel been involved in military operations on Bougainville.
(4) Has the RAAF recently been involved in transporting PNGDF personnel to and from the Solomon Islands while the military operations on Bougainville were underway.
(5) Have ADF personnel provided advice to the PNGDF on the safety and security of air assets operations on Bougainville.
(6) Are there any ADF personnel stationed at the Buka Island airfield.
(7) Has there been any confirmation of recent media reports suggesting that machine guns were bolted and strapped to Iroquois aircraft for use during operations from Buka Island.
(8) Has the ADF carried out an investigation into the events surrounding the so-called `St Valentines Day Massacre' and what were the conclusions of any such investigations.
(9) Was this investigation able to confirm whether Australian-supplied military equipment was used by the PNGDF or whether ADF personnel were involved in the atrocities committed.
(10) What are the implications for ADF personnel serving with the PNGDF in relation to the declaration under subsection 9(2) of the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act 1978.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Under arrangements established since January 1977, any use of Australian Defence Force (ADF) loan or exchange personnel serving with the Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF) in politically sensitive situations requires consultation with Australian authorities. As the dispute on Bougainville has been of this nature, visits by ADF personnel on loan or exchange with the PNGDF have been restricted to those occasions in which the personnel were required to perform technical functions for the PNGDF which it was unable to carry out for itself. There has been no direct ADF involvement in mounting or participating in PNGDF operations on Bougainville. The attached table lists visits to Bougainville by ADF loan or exchange personnel in performance of their normal duties.

In addition to the above, ADF members on the staff of the Australian High Commission as accredited diplomatic representatives to PNG also visited Bougainville in performance of their diplomatic duties, and to assist with the Australian High Commission's consular responsibilities for the safety and welfare of Australian residents.

(2) Australia agreed in 1989 to provide helicopter pilot training to PNGDF personnel of a mutually determined nature. The training has involved conversion of qualified fixed-wing pilots to rotary wing, conversion of pilots to the UH-1H Iroquois, and a period of on-the-job experience with 171 Command and Liaison Squadron in the Australian Army Aviation Regiment. Two pilots have finished this training as of July 1992.

(3) Since Independence, the ADF has provided training assistance to the PNGDF under Defence Cooperation. This training has not been provided for any specific contingency but rather against the full range of needs of the PNGDF. Since the start of the Bougainville dispute, Defence Cooperation training has included training of PNGDF recruits, and a number of specialist/technical military courses conducted in PNG. In addition, sub-unit training was conducted for four companies of 1st Battalion, Royal Pacific Islands Regiment of the PNGDF at the Australian Army Land Warfare Centre at Canungra from March to June 1992. This consisted of standard ADF military skills training, including map reading, navigation, patrolling, movement and living in the field, watermanship, leadership, orders, and physical fitness, but did not as such constitute training in jungle warfare. I have no doubt PNGDF personnel trained in Australia have taken part in military operations in Bougainville. The use of PNGDF service personnel, however, is solely a matter for the PNG Government and I am not privy to information relating to the deployment of PNGDF personnel.
(4) The RAAF has not transported PNGDF personnel either to North Solomons Province (Bougainville) nor to Solomon Islands during the dispute.

(5) An ADF officer on loan to the PNGDF as Director of Air Operations visited Bougainville on several occasions to advise on procedures for the management of air assets, safety of operations, and various related manpower, logistic and engineering aspects. In addition, loan officers working as

ANSWER.PARA: technicians in the PNGDF Air Transport Squadron have visited Nissan Island (part of North Solomons Province) in order to assist the recovery of a damaged PNGDF DC 3 aircraft.

PARA.TAB: (7) Both the former PNG Minister for Defence and the Commander PNGDF have confirmed recent reports that machine guns have been attached with slings to UH-1H Iroquois helicopters. This practice is not inconsistent with the use of defensive firepower from helicopters.
(8) The ADF has not investigated, nor is it in a position to investigate, the events purported to have occurred in PNG.
(9) As indicated in (8) above, as the ADF was not involved in operational activities in PNG, no investigation into the events has been carried out by the ADF.

(10) The declaration under sub-section 9(2) of the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act 1978 has no relationship to ADF personnel serving with the PNGDF, whose position is covered by the Status of Forces Agreement between Australia and PNG, and various other agreements.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 6 July 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the basis of the cost recovery formula used by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) in charging for meat inspection; and
(2) Are AQIS staffing costs for its offices in Geneva, Brussels or Washington included in the total operating costs recovered by AQIS meat inspection charges.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The basic methodology for setting AQIS meat inspection charges consists of a number of steps:
First, the quantum of AQIS costs attributable to the meat inspection program is determined. This includes both appropriated and non-appropriated costs.

Secondly, the cost of Government funded concessions, such as surplus officers and support for Quality Assurance activities, is removed from the meat inspection program cost to give the net cost of the program to industry.
Thirdly, the net cost to industry is divided into Veterinary Officer costs and Food Standards Officer (formerly known as Meat Inspector) costs

ANSWER.PARA: —some further adjustments are made to recognise the different costs of providing inspection services at non-slaughtering establishments.

PARA.TAB: Finally, the Veterinary Officer and Food Standards Officer costs are divided by the estimated number of chargeable Veterinary Officer and Food Standards Officer positions that industry will use during the year to give an annual charge per Food Standards Officer and Veterinary Officer

ANSWER.PARA: —non-annual rates (monthly, weekly, daily and hourly) are derived from the annual rates with appropriate loadings (12.5%, 15%, 20% and 30% respectively) to allow for unchargeable time associated with providing staff for periods of less than 12 months.

PARA.TAB: (2) The cost of AQIS representatives in Brussels and Washington are included in AQIS' costs for charging purposes. However only 30% of the Brussels position and 40% of the Washington position are attributed to the meat inspection program. The costs of the remaining portions of the positions are recovered through other AQIS programs or are funded by the Government. AQIS does not have any representation in Geneva.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 13 July 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What Australian design regulations apply to the depth of foam used in the pan of passenger seats for coaches.
(2) How many, and which, imported coaches or minibuses use seats which comply with these design regulations.

(3) If the design regulations applying to the depth of foam used in the pan of imported passenger seats for coaches differs from that applicable to Australian-made seats, what is the standard applicable to foreign manufactured seats.
(4) What Australian design regulations apply to the minimum strength of the back of passenger seats for coaches.
(5) How many, and which, imported coaches or minibuses use seats which comply with these design regulations.

(6) If the design regulations applying to the minimum strength of the back of imported passenger seats for coaches differs from that applicable to Australian-made seats, what is the standard applicable to foreign manufactured seats.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Land Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) There are no Australian Design Rules applying to the depth of foam used in the pan of passenger seats for coaches. This is not a safety issue, but rather a matter for individual coach operators to determine in the context of the market within which they operate.
(2) Not applicable
(3) Not applicable
(4) Requirements for coach seat strength are contained in Australian Design Rule 66/00 which came into force for new heavy buses on 1 July 1992 and will apply to new medium buses from 1 July 1993.

Australian Design Rule 66/00 in addition to covering requirements for seat strength includes requirements for the seat anchorages both on the seat and in the vehicle and for accessories and armrests on the seat.

A new Design Rule which, in addition to the requirements of Australian Design Rule 66/00, will require lap/sash seat belts to be fitted to all seating positions on new long distance coaches from 1 July 1994.

(5) Australian Design Rule 66/00 applies to all imported coaches or minibuses with 17 or more seats except those designed for route-service operation i.e. those with specially designed spaces for standing passengers and with a seat back height of less than 1 metre.
(6) Australian Design Rules apply equally to locally manufactured and imported vehicles.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Radiocommunications: Aircraft Station Class B Licences

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 15 July 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) When was a fee introduced for an aircraft Station Licence Class B.
(2) What was the original licence fee and what was the fee charged for each subsequent year.
(3) What are the grounds for the last increase in the fee.
(4) Why is a fee necessary.
(5) What service does the Department of Transport and Communications perform in return for levying this fee.
(6) If the Department of Transport and Communications does provide a service, what does it cost to provide the service.
(7) How many persons or organisations pay an Aircraft Station Licence Class B Fee.
(8) What is the aggregate sum received from all these Class B Fees.
(9) Does this money remain with the Department of Transport and Communications, is it transferred to the Civil Aviation Authority, or does it go to Consolidated Revenue.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The radiocommunications transmitter category Aircraft Station Class B Licence was introduced by this name on 1 September 1984 by the Wireless Telegraphy Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rule 1984 No. 223.
(2) The licence fee for an Aircraft Station Class B was set by the Radiocommunications Licence Fee Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1984 No. 222, at $35.
The following Table sets out the fees charged for an Aircraft Station Class B in subsequent years.

(3) The last increase in the fee for Aircraft Station Class B came into effect on 1 December 1991 and is based on the increase in the annual Consumer Price Index (CPI) to the end of June 1991 totalling 3.4 per cent.
The Government has linked the increase in annual licence fees to the annual percentage increase in the CPI since 1989. This ensures that the revenue from licence fees remains the same in real terms.

(4) Licence fees for radiocommunications equipment are levied as a charge for access to the radio frequency spectrum, which is a public resource. The fees also cover costs incurred by the Department of Transport and Communications in planning and managing the use of the spectrum.

(5) The tasks undertaken by the Department of Transport and Communications in managing the spectrum that are directly related to the licensee are the assignment of frequencies and the co-ordination of services to ensure that users can operate in an ordered environment substantially free from interference, investigation of interference complaints and dealing with the unlicensed or irresponsible use of radiocommunications equipment.
This is supported by additional functions involved in administration of the radio frequency spectrum, that include:
International responsibilities—to participate in international agreements and co-ordination arrangements through the International Telecommunications Union
National planning—development of the Spectrum Plan and making band plans, that enable allocations of the spectrum to be made within Australia in the most efficient way possible.

Development of standards—to determine and administer a framework of technical equipment standards that enable radiocommunications equipment to operate in Australia without interfering unduly with radiocommunications services and testing equipment against standards.
Policy formulation with associated legislation development and administration.
(6) The cost of managing the radio frequency spectrum in the year 1990-91 was $20.7 million.
(7) There are currently 6176 Aircraft Station Class B Licences.
(8) The aggregate sum received from these Class B Licences is $271,744.
(9) Radiocommunications licence fees are paid to the Department of Transport and Communications as a `receiver of public moneys' and pass into Consolidated Revenue.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 17 July 1992:

PARA.TAB: Has the Government banned the sale of vitamin capsules commonly known as KH3; if so, what was the basis of the decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth has had concerns regarding the safety and efficacy of oral procaine hydrochloride preparations such as KH3 for many years.

This drug is not a vitamin. It has been promoted as being effective in the treatment of the symptoms of ageing. In 1975, the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee (ADEC), an independent body of experts, recommended that KH3 not be permitted to be marketed in Australia on the grounds that there was no evidence to support the claims made for the product.

Despite this recommendation, the company concerned continued to manufacture and market the drug in Australia. As the Commonwealth only had power to regulate imported therapeutic goods, no action could be taken.

With the introduction of the new Therapeutic Goods Act, the Commonwealth assumed responsibility for ensuring the quality, safety and efficacy of all pharmaceuticals in Australia, whether produced locally or overseas. An application to register KH3 on the new Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods under the provisions of the new Act was made by the company concerned.

In view of ADEC's previous concerns the company was asked by the Department to provide scientific data to support the safety and efficacy of the product prior to it being registered. The data provided by the company were insufficient to demonstrate the drug's safety and efficacy for the proposed indications. The drug was therefore denied registration.

The company was offered the opportunity of having this decision reviewed by ADEC. However, I understand that the company's marketing agreement with the German manufacturer of the product has now been terminated and that it no longer intends to pursue the matter.
